Each of them is full of creative and original ideas that lead our instruction in so many diverse directions. The funny things they say give me dinner-table conversation each and every night. My students are learning how to be kind and helpful members of our school family. Each of them does a designated job in the classroom, and they take these responsibilities very seriously! These jobs strengthen the feeling of community in our class.I teach many kids who come from low socioeconomic families, many of them being raised by a struggling single parent or grandparent. It is important to me that kindergarten gives these children a place to experience amazing things, to learn by doing, and to feel important. My students and I watched a video of these Wobble Chairs in action and their reaction was clear: 'Can we have some of those??' Kindergartners love motion and I incorporate it whenever I can - songs and dances, hand signals, or body movements to emphasis new concepts. When it is time to sit still, they make a great effort, but are constantly moving, wiggling, and wobbling. These seats will allow to me to work with my students' natural desire to be in motion. My students will be strengthening their bodies while they strengthen their minds. This is the core idea behind this project! Our PE coach taught the students about getting plenty of exercise and moving their bodies. Our sate has the highest obesity rate in the nation, I want to start them off on the path to a healthy future. A donation of any amount brings my students closer to moving to learn!
needStatement: My students need these Wobble Chairs to keep their bodies moving while their minds are engaged!

name: Banishing Inequality One Book At A Time
description: A diverse group of thinkers and learners, my students bring a plethora of experience to our classroom community. I am continually learning about a wide variety of ways in which our community members live and interact. Being from outside of the community, my students help me to see how different life can be and yet how similar we all are in our needs and wants. My students are rich in life experiences. Though flourishing in life's lessons, my students require a wide array of support to continue their growth as an academically diverse lifelong learner. The students at our school know who they are and where they come from. Through their own life experiences and differentiated support, my students show up every day willing to put in the effort. The vast array of diverse cultures and economic situations in which our students show up to our classrooms creates a rich blend of experiences we can all learn about and draw from when analyzing the world around us. We have students who come from some of the most economically advantaged, and disadvantaged, situations. When nestled together in a building of motivated teachers who care deeply for their students, all those involved grow. In order to become lifelong readers that are successful, students require a wide variety of books to quench their thirst. My students require supplemental reading support in order to help them 'catch up' to their peers. Most of my students have never found a book that they truly enjoyed, that book which changes their reading lives. The one they 'just couldn't put down'. You can help to change the future of a student who struggles. By helping to build our classroom library, you are changing the outcome of a student who might never have known they can find success in reading. Successful readers are more likely to finish high school and continue on to college. Help us to build a classroom library where all students can find 'that book'.
needStatement: My students need a classroom library full of diverse, engaging books to help them become successful lifelong learners.

name: Blue Light Special for Special Needs Class
description: Temple Grandin, an advocate for individuals with special needs, said, 'There needs to be a lot more emphasis on what a child can do instead of what he cannot do.' This is the philosophy in our classroom. Our class is a self-contained unit for high school students with multiple disabilities located in a small, rural district in Ohio. Over half of the students in our district receive free and reduced lunch. The students in my room present a wide array of abilities and needs. Many of my students display sensory needs. Although they face many challenges, my nine students are always working to better themselves and their school. They are incredibly hard workers and constantly impress me with their 'can do' attitudes. Functional skills that students can apply to their daily lives are a main focus of our day. My goal is to make everything relevant to them and their needs. Outside of the classroom, the students develop job skills while giving back to their school and community. They volunteer around the school by mentoring elementary students and shadowing the custodians. Once a week, they volunteer in the community, learning job skills at local businesses. My students all have special needs. Many of them exhibit sensory needs that interfere with their learning. Some students can become distracted or anxious by lights, sounds, and smells. They need frequent breaks to move around or go to a quiet, dark area to relax when they become overstimulated by their surroundings. Overhead fluorescent lights contribute to these problems and can cause headaches, eyestrain, and anxiety in students sensitive to sensory input. These light filters cut the glare of fluorescent lights to create a comfortable learning environment for all students. They lessen the harshness of fluorescent lights by filtering them to a softer, blue glow. This minimizes the distraction and discomfort that many students face and allows them to focus on what is really important--learning! Studies have also shown that blue is a calming color. Many of my students display high levels of anxiety associated with autism or an emotional disorder. By casting a blue light, these filters create a relaxing and calm environment which will reduce anxiety and tension and create a safe place for my students to unwind and learn.
needStatement: My students need 6 sets of fluorescent light filters to help their sensory needs.

name: Plant. Grow. Eat Our Way to Healthy Living
description: All teachers believe their students are amazing. My students are superheroes! They are overcoming their high poverty home lives to learn and grow physically, emotionally and academically. They begin the school year as 'babies' who need guidance to make good decisions and end the year reading, writing, solving math problems, building and thinking through word problems and setting an example for the students that come after them. They learn that they are indeed superheroes because they can learn. This special power will make them a success in kindergarten and in life. My students see many vegetables and ask what is that? They ask what different vegetables and fruits taste like because they haven't had the chance to try them themselves. They ask what it is like to grow plants, because they don't live in a place where they stay long enough to watch something grow. These gardens will expose them to the experience of planting, nurturing and then harvesting and eating the fruits of their labors. These fresh foods will help them live healthier lives. My students have looked out at our courtyard and asked if they can grow things there. Our building is being rebuilt and an outside garden is not a feasible option. These supplies will give them the opportunity they have been seeking while giving me a chance to encourage a healthy lifestyle. The quick indoor growing cycle will also let them have time to be a part of the whole growing cycle.
needStatement: My students need indoor gardens and seeds to explore a variety of fruits and vegetables to encourage healthy living.

name: MC2 STEM Rhythm Project
description: The students at MC2 STEM come to us with varied skills and interests. The majority of our students are underrepresented, both racially and economically, and are looking to secure an education that will introduce them to new experiences and afford them the opportunities to build a bright future. Many of our students come to our school grade levels behind in reading and math and struggle with issues at home and in the community including violence, poverty, and a lack of access to proper nutrition, basic needs and resources. Our school is open to any student who wants to be here and we do not have any academic criteria for admission. Our mission is to engage and enrich all students' by developing critical thinking and problem solving skills, and empowering them to achieve their personal, academic, and community goals. Drumming is not only a way for individuals to make music and be creative, but is becoming increasingly popular as a way to manage stress and promote physical and emotional health. Often times, students do not have the tools to deal with the stress and challenges they face at school and in their personal lives and do not know how to be proactive, only reactive. Drumming can help students focus, relieve stress and aggression, express emotions that are hard to articulate verbally and build community among one another. It's fun, convenient, inclusive, and allows students to take on leaderships roles within the group. And like many schools and districts that have done away with art and music due to budget cuts, drumming provides a creative break during the academic day. More from writer Dave Robertson: 'Drumming does not require advanced physical abilities or specialized talents. It does not require participants to read music or understand music theory. Drumming, even a simple pattern, offers benefits to a huge range of people. Drumming is a universal language. It transcends gender, race, age, and nationality. In fact, nearly every culture on earth has some form of drumming tradition. Studies have shown that drumming lowers both blood pressure and stress hormones. The active component of drumming helps reduce stress in a number of ways. Group drumming creates a sense of community and a powerful shared experience. It has been used as a successful team building experience to teach groups to work together, to listen to each other, and to achieve common goals.' Thank you for considering this project!
needStatement: My students need a variety of small to medium, well-crafted hand drums/percussion instruments to participate in drumming activities.

name: Fabulous and Focused in First Grade.
description: I am a second year teacher and I have the honor of shaping 16 brilliant minds. My students are predominantly African American and we are a Title 1 school. As a teacher I pride myself on creating a welcoming classroom culture where my students are comfortable and have a active learning environment. The time on the rug is spent listening, building essential social skills and learning from each other. There is truly something special about congregating on the carpet and as a teacher, observing my students listening to one another as they share their highs and lows. My students feel valued when they're sitting on the carpet and feel encouraged and safe to share their thoughts as their classmates support them with snaps and smiles. The lessons and activities that take place on the carpet are an essential component to my first graders' learning experience. Carpet activities help build a strong and caring classroom community and help refocus students' attention. A teaching easel will give me a place to create and refer back to our class-created 'anchor charts' as we learn new concepts. They will later be hung around the classroom for all to see. A teaching easel will give me a place to work on a whiteboard or with magnetic materials when teaching whole group or small group lessons to students. Whiteboards will help my students practice an important life skill, accountability. By actively involving my students in the learning, my students ideas will come to life. They will be able to demonstrate their learning right at their desks as well as on the carpet. Having a class set will increase engagement amongst every student in a single lesson. This is extremely important for myself and my students because it provides an opportunity to see who needs a little extra support with the lesson and to be able to adjust my lesson accordingly. Personal white boards are fun for students and lends itself to flexible learning because my students are able to use them during learning centers, small group instruction, and even individual practice. It's also important for me to teach my students that we all make mistakes and that's okay. Mistakes during practice are easily wiped away, making learning fun and less intimidating.
needStatement: My students need personal white boards and a teaching easel so we can create charts together.

name: Bringing New Life To Our New School Year
description: Each day at school provides a window of opportunity for our students to learn new skills and develop their knowledge base. They are also learning social skills and cooperative play skills. Our classroom is made up of learners who work hard as they are learning to engage with people and social worlds. Each student has an autism spectrum disorder. Our goal is to learn to be an attentive student as well as an active learner in the world around us. The students work on listening to a speaker and following directives as they learn their academic skills. They also are learning to care for their own bodies, which includes learning how to regulate their bodies in the world around them. Over time, our class materials get worn out and need replaced. By having a new Pocket Chart System, the students will be able to utilize the pockets with ease. A wobbly old stand can be replaced and the students will be able to use the pockets with ease, manipulating new vocabulary and word building cards. The class mailboxes will organize the personal folders and papers for each student. Things will be safely stored for them throughout their school day. New magazine holders will keep our classroom library organized and cared for in secure, labeled holders. Supplies need replenished so that each new learner can have access to healthy snacks, new classroom tools and learning materials. Sharpie markers, sequins and glue help the students add artwork to their class projects. Lamination pouches bring longer life to our letter, number and word cards. By having access to new materials, the students are provided with the opportunity to use working systems that don't constantly need repaired from their daily use.
needStatement: My students need a Carson Dellosa Double Pocket Chart Stand and new pocket charts accessories to replace our worn out pocket chart system for whole group learning and our class reference center.

name: Searching for Super School Supplies!
description: Welcome to my 3rd grade classroom where the love and excitement for learning never ends. These 75 vivacious young minds are growing in many ways. I have the pleasure to engage these students in not only reading and language arts but also science and social studies. We are a low income school located in the state of PA. Our goal is to 'Dream Big, Work Hard' while encouraging successful citizens in and out of the classroom. Your support can help make this happen.3rd grade is a beautiful grade to teach because students start becoming more independent. Starting the school year off with the appropriate school supplies helps to foster that growth. Binders, folders and crayons are used in many ways. HOMEWORK BINDER with FOLDER: Every student should have a homework binder to place not only their homework but other important school information. COMMUNICATION BINDER: This binder houses student assessments/quizzes and is sent home bi-monthly to parents along with their child's current grade. LITERACY BINDER Students house their curriculum materials, writings, 25 book log, classroom work, rubrics etc...FOLDERS- I also teach science and social studies so it helps if each student has an additional separate folder for each subject.CRAYONS- Students have projects which require the use of crayons both in and out of school.
needStatement: My students need crayons, binders, and folders to start the school year off organized and ready to 'dream big, work hard.'

name: Carpet Diem!
description: My students are first to second generation American, coming from Hispanic families. They live within blocks of the school, with usually more than 5 people in their household. We are a tight knit community, in fact I was raised in this neighborhood. My students are very energetic and really enjoy learning. They come in speaking both English and Spanish. As a teacher, I take their knowledge and prior experiences of their dominant language to develop the English language. It's amazing to see how well these little individuals can dominate two languages. They hold such a great power and they don't even know it. Starting kindergarten can be very scary for students and even parents. Therefore, it is important that the teacher creates a warm and welcoming environment for the students. Giving students a carpet will make them feel comfortable and it is inviting to walk into. Some of the most important daily routines will happen on this carpet such as morning message, calendar time, phonemic awareness time, and read-alouds. It is essential to have a carpet because on this carpet is where students develop oral and listening skills. Not to mention, a carpet in the classroom can reduce/cushion slips and falls. Thank you!
needStatement: My students need a carpet area to feel comfortable. I want to create a warm, inviting, and positive environment. I would love this carpet for my students to sit on during morning message and calendar area.

name: Yoga, It Does The Body Good
description: 'What time do we go outside to play?' This is a question that I hear throughout the day from my curious class of active learners. They are always curious and eager to learn new things. They love to move about the classroom. And of course, they love to play outside. I teach at a Title I school in Georgia where the vast majority of the students we serve receive free breakfast and lunch. Sometimes limited resources and hardships at home can make their school life stressful. Even though they are faced with hardships, they still show up everyday happy and ready to learn. Recently I exposed my students to a beginners level of yoga. Yoga is the classroom is a great way to build concentration, increase confidence, and decrease stress. The children really enjoyed learning yoga poses and practicing each pose. The students are always more calm and focused after our mini yoga session. The students would like yoga mats and a yoga for kids DVD so that they can continue to learn new yoga poses and calming strategies. The students wanted to have a yoga session during outside time but were not successful due to lack of equipment. The students will be able to take their yoga mats, music, and wireless speaker outside to experience an outdoor yoga session.
needStatement: My students need yoga supplies to implement yoga for kids into our daily physical fitness routines.

name: Fidgeting to Help Us Focus!
description: My classroom is full of learning, love, and laughter, and more importantly the most amazing 3rd graders around! My students come from all different backgrounds and have different learning styles, abilities, needs, and interests. My students attend an Extended Learning and Time school, and are in school for 8 hours a day. For 3rd graders being asked to sit or be still for that long can be exhausting and challenging. However, my students come to school each day, excited and ready to learn and work their hardest! My classroom serves a very wide variety of learners! Some of the learners in my classroom have various sensory and movement needs. My students have been given many choices in our classroom, such as where they'd like to sit, and where they believe they work best. I have always allowed students to stand, sit, and lay on the floor if that's how they felt they could accomplish their very best work! However, this past year, many students said they wished they could bounce on a yoga ball. So, naturally, I thought that was an amazing idea, which is why I am requesting the yoga ball chair. Many students told me they like to move and rock in their chairs. I always understand, however it's not safe to rock in their chairs. So after exploring my options, I believe the Learniture Active stools will give my students a safe alternative to move and rock while they work. And, finally some students told me that they pick at their name tags and play in their desks during instruction, because their hands need to move, so I am requesting fidget toys to help some of my fidgeting friends stay focused while they learn!
needStatement: My students need Learniture active learning stools, a yoga ball chair, and a set of fidget toys to help them effectively redirect their energy and stay focused throughout the day, and to move and stretch!

name: Help Us Learn to Love Reading!
description: I have 25 wonderful, energetic, and curious first grade students. The students in my classroom speak a variety of languages, eight total. My school is 88% free or reduced price lunch, and is quickly rising. Forty nine percent of the students at my school identify as Asian, 26% identify as African American, 14% identify as Hispanic, 10% identify as Caucasian, and 1% identify as American Indian. My classroom is rich with diversity and we celebrate each student's identity and culture. My students are always moving. I use alternative seating, center based learning, and differentiation to target the needs of all of my students. In my school, the classrooms are co-taught and have a cluster of students who are just learning English or have special needs. I currently have a Language Academy room but next year, 2016-2017, I will have the special education room and I couldn't be more excited. First grade is when students go from identifying basic sight words and reading books from memory to actually reading books, decoding words, and reading for thirty minutes at a time. I am asking for a rocking/reading chair, engaging 'just right' books, book storage, and big books. My students need engaging books that are culturally relevant and at their reading level to help them develop a love of reading. One thing I have learned through teaching, is that students have to be really interested in what they are doing in order to be engaged, and by having these engaging texts, my students will develop a love of reading. My class also needs storage for books, storage for puppets we have to retell stories, which increases reading comprehension. My students also need a 'reading chair' to help motivate them to earn the privilege of getting to read in our special chair.
needStatement: My students need a rocking chair, engaging 'just right' books, book storage, and big books to increase reading comprehension, fluency, and encourage the love of reading.

name: MacBook Milestones
description: My students are hardworking, enthusiastic about speech therapy and learning. Many of the students that receive therapy are in special education classes with varying disabilities. The therapy that I provide is individualized and modified to each student's needs. Some students receive therapy in groups while others receive therapy individually. Technology is a major motivator for my students! From apps to research websites , technology is a key motivator in my speech room. Positive reinforcement, visual models, and auditory prompts are the main aspects to the therapy that I provide. All of these key components can be used along with a laptop to facilitate learning and success. Currently, we have no working computer in the speech therapy room which inhibits my students from learning at their absolute highest potential. Yet, they still come to speech therapy every day, ready to learn! They are very determined in all that they do which is why they are so special to me. This will be my first official full year of being a speech therapist in the DOE and nothing would excite me more than to provide my students with something as motivating as a laptop.I am requesting a MacBook Air for my students who receive speech-language therapy. We are currently a Title l school located in Rockaway Beach, Queens. Because we were impacted by Hurricane Sandy, many of the computers and desktops that are being used are either outdated or no longer working to their fullest potential. Many of the students that are receiving therapy do not have access to technology such as a computer at home due to the low-income area that they live in. Providing my students with a laptop will not only be motivating and rewarding but will help reach each major MILESTONE they have as individual students. The MacBook will be used to type up reports and learn the importance of proofreading. Additionally, students will be instructed to review and read research articles based on each student's grade and reading style, and download applications related to specific topics such as articulation, reading, writing etc. Lastly, providing my students with this computer will truly motivate them to want more for themselves and to learn about the advances in technology to prepare for the future.
needStatement: My students need a Macbook Air to explore, learn and research more about the world. Additionally, to access the most information as possible to allow for success in reaching specific learning milestones.

name: Books: Gifts to Open Again and Again
description: Our elementary school is a 'School of Innovation' within our district. We re-interpret traditional Waldorf methods to teach common core standards and meet the needs of our student population in a neighborhood of West Louisville, most of whom are from low-income families (95% free/reduced-price lunch).Using their hands, hearts, and heads each day -- this is how students learn at our school. We value children's social play, outdoor experiences, connection with nature, learning through arts, rich literacy, nutrition, sustainable living, and strong, positive relationships. My students spent their Kindergarten year practicing social skills, exploring nature, and making art and music. They listened to rich stories every day. Now that they've come to first grade, they're ready to start reading stories for themselves! As a new teacher, I need to build my guided reading library for these eager readers, and fast! This project will get us started with fiction books for the first few months of school. If you're enthusiastic about supporting literacy, then you've found the right teacher! I'm participating in the Bellarmine Literacy Project this year to develop expert literacy teaching skills. Check back with me soon, as I'm sure these brilliant children will be ready to move on to higher leveled-readers in a few short months, and I'll need more support to get great books into their hands.
needStatement: My students need to get their hands on some 'just right' books as they learn to read this year.

name: Wiggle to Learn!
description: My students are amazing. I teach kids from diverse backgrounds. Our school serves mostly English language learners. These children are problem solvers and innovators. Many of my students are from low income families, but that doesn't stop their desire and need to learn! My students are constantly inspiring each other to do better, be better and learn more. I'm lucky to work with such amazing kids who challenge me as a professional and a person. Given the right resources, these children can achieve anything! My students are begging for a change in the classroom! Let's face it, it's hard to be a kid today. School can be a difficult place to sit still and stay focused. My students want flexible seating in our classroom. If this project is funded, my students will be able to get their wiggles out in their new seats, while focusing on their work and learning. Instead of sitting in a typical school chair, students will sit on yoga balls with the freedom to bounce safely while working. Students who prefer a typical chair will be able to use the wobble cushions and bouncy bands to keep their feet busy while they work. This will also increase the amount of time students are up and moving, instead of sitting still all day. Some students want to lay on the floor and use the clipboards to write on. Students will take yoga and cardio brain breaks throughout the day, using the new seating. Many students need the flexibility of being able to sit, stand and wiggle during a lesson. Traditional seating does not allow students the ability to move and wiggle without distracting others. My hope is that through the use of these alternative seats, I will create a special place for students to wiggle, while achieving great things! We are looking to create a happier and healthier 4th grade class!
needStatement: My students need to move and wiggle. I am asking for alternative seating for my students. Some students can sit on yoga balls, while others will be in chairs using a stability pad or Bouncy Band.

name: Flexible Seating With Lap Desks and Wobble Chairs
description: My students are military family members. Many of them have a parent deployed overseas and others transferred to the military installation with their parents but are away from extended family. Some students will transfer during the year to another station while just as many will become part of our learning community during the year. Being on a military installation means students have sometimes been enrolled in several schools already. My students are very familiar in welcoming new classmates. They are excited for new students and are experts in helping each other become acquainted with their new surroundings and procedures. Our 2nd graders are 7 and 8 years old and love to move. Using whole brain learning and many brain breaks, our classroom is in constant motion. Many students in my classroom love movement and have a hard time sitting at their desks. Some classrooms use flexible seating successfully for all students. Students are supported by the Kore Wobble chairs that allow them move and wiggle without interrupting learning. Flexible seating has proven to help students pay attention and enjoy learning. Students love a change from sitting at their desks. They love to use clip boards while sitting on the carpet but lap desks would allow for a better work station and a neater finished project. Student have used these in other classroom and would like some of their second grade classroom. Students are excited to to use these and motivated to learn.
needStatement: My students need Romanoff Lap trays and Kore Patented WOBBLE chairs for alternative seating to keep them moving and interested in learning!

name: Balancing Education While Stabilizing The Core
description: My students are scholars who are thirsty for knowledge and are growing daily. They attend a small community school where differences are being made. The school is title 1 school and considered high poverty. Over 80% of the students receive free or reduced lunch. My scholars are dreamers, thinkers, talkers, and questioners. They are special to not only me but the rest of the community because they inspire the staff and myself to work harder, challenge creatively, and impact always. One area my scholars struggle in is focusing. With Gaiam Kids balance balls students will gain core stability and also be able to wiggle while sitting still and focusing. A study was published in the American Journal of Occupational Therapy concluding that sitting on therapy balls improved behavior and legible word productivity. My scholars will be active for at least 60 minutes a day when they are sitting on their balance balls during small group reading time. The floor hundreds charts will also allow my students to become active by interacting with one another in a hands-on fashion moving around the jumbo hundreds chart. During station time small groups of 4 or 5 students can learn on the large hundreds charts while engaging with one another. Both the hundreds chart and balance balls were kid- inspired/requested materials. My scholars read an article in Newsela titled, 'Exercise Machines in the Classroom' and after reading it they were inspired to incorporate some type of equipment into our classroom. We synergized and came up with a list which contained balance balls for seating. I am excited to help my scholars dreams of having balance balls in the classroom come true.
needStatement: My students need five Gaiam Kids Stay and Balance balls, two jumbo floor hundreds charts and a bean bag chair.

name: Meeting of the Little People's Minds
description: My students are small, bright eyed and eager to learn. Even though they are little, they have so much to aspire to be. One of their most favorite times to learn during the day is when they are sitting on the floor during whole group instruction. They also vacate to the floor during literacy stations, independent reading time and our all important brain break movement time. Being able to move around and get into different positions is vital for young learners. Supporting my project of this classroom carpet will provide the children a colorful, comfortable space in which to work their brain. They will be using this location (the carpet) for so many different activities each and every day. Assisting these under privileged children who are at such a young age, models for them lessons about community, kindness, and geography, among others. They will learn that other people do care. That the world is good. That when they grow up, they can make a difference in someone's life, the same way supporters of this project will change their Kindergarten life. Thank you for caring!
needStatement: My students need a carpet to sit upon, listen, read, count, think, dance, explain, interact, problem-solve and so much more. This will be our classroom meeting space for the meeting of the minds!

name: Meeting and Reading Comfort
description: My students walk into the classroom every day motivated, excited to learn, and eager to see what is in store for them that day. They love reading and learning new math skills. I believe that all of my students can learn to the best of their ability and I work hard to make sure they know how special they are. My school has a creative arts focus and the students enjoy drama, dance, music, and art classes on a weekly basis. Many of my students live in the apartment complex located next to the school. Despite so many hardships, my students are eager to learn and do their best. They want to be in school because they want to learn all they can so they can be successful one day. The large area rug is a place where Morning Meetings, Reading and Math mini-lessons, independent reading time, and many other community building times occur in our classroom. Students engage with other students, encourage others to be the best they can be, and are on-task and focused during lessons. A fresh, clean, and comfortable large area rug will improve their school lives because it will provide an inviting area to sit and read on a daily basis. Because our current large area rug is old (over 20 years), my students have to sit at their table spots during independent reading where they sit during other lessons. When they enter the room, they can smell the mildew from the rug. Morning Meeting and Reading and Math mini-lesson times are not inviting because of this old rug.
needStatement: My students need a comfortable seating rug for our Morning Meetings, Reading and Math mini lessons, and an area for them to sit or lay down for independent reading time.

name: Enriching our Youth through Yoga & Mindfulness!
description: My classroom is full of learning, love, and laughter, and more importantly the most amazing 3rd graders around! My students come from all different backgrounds and have different learning styles, abilities, needs, and interests. My students attend an Extended Learning and Time school, and are in school for 8 hours a day. For 3rd graders being asked to sit or be still for that long can be exhausting and challenging. However, my students come to school each day, excited and ready to learn and work their hardest! My students come from all different backgrounds, and some from chaotic home lives and circumstances. They come to school to learn, be loved, and have fun! This past year we were fortunate enough to take yoga once a week with a real yoga instructor! My kids absolutely LOVED every minute of it! They giggled with excitement on Wednesdays, because that meant we had yoga during our enrichment block! Unfortunately, I don't think that we will be having the same yoga classes this year. After hearing how excited my students were, I knew I had to act fast to make sure that I could continue to provide them with such a great experience. My students would say, 'Miss Boisvert, can we have yoga EVERY DAY?!!?!' And unfortunately, we couldn't due to the lack of materials. So, thanks to my students excitement, begging, and pleading, I've decided to request these materials so I can embed yoga into our daily routine during our daily enrichment block! I am asking for yoga mats, so that each student has their own space, cleaner to keep the mats fresh and clean, and a hamper to store them all in! I am also asking for an active stool, balance board, and wobble cushions for students who may like or require some extra challenge! I know that with these amazing tools, my students will become more calm and mindful, while having fun and controlling their little bodies!
needStatement: My students need Yoga mats, a hamper to store them in, and mat cleaner to keep them fresh and in good condition! They also need wobble cushions, balance boards, bouncy bands, and an active stool!

name: Run! Hop! Skip! Jump!
description: Our elementary school is in an urban neighborhood in St. Paul. Many of our students are new to the United States and are learning English. We also have many students with special needs. About 85% of our families experience poverty. Imagine what it is like to be six years old and attending school for the first time and that you need to find ways to make friends and play and work together with your classmates. This is what it is like for many of our students. Our wonderful first graders come to school with a lot of energy and are excited to learn. They also love to jump and move and run. Active play helps us to build community in each classroom and helps our students get ready to learn. It helps our students develop social skills to work together and make friends. All students are able to participate and all students are valued. After reading the book, Walk, Ride, Run, a story about a brother and sister racing in a park, my students became excited about having a race. It quickly became about more than just running. They began imagining all the ways that they could move and all they ways they could go fast. First graders began to shout out: 'We can jump and we can run!' 'We can hop!' 'We can climb!' 'We can crawl!' 'We can swing!' 'We can slide!' Everyone was excited about the idea and wanted to start running right away. We realized that in order to be safe, we would need to plan carefully and figure out how to make the course for our race fun and safe, and how to add as many activities as possible so more kids could be running it at the same time. We imagined how to use playground equipment already in place, and what we would need to make it more exciting and active. Our dream is to have a variety of materials such as hoops, cones, stepping stones, and jump ropes so that first graders can learn to set up an obstacle course during our afternoon recess time. Recess is a time for teachers and students to play games together, to be active, and to create a spirit of belonging in our classroom communities. This project will help get our first graders become more physically active and moving. We do not have gym class every week, so they really need more time to run and play. An obstacle course will get students to participate in a variety of activities that they might not choose on their own. It will help students develop confidence and cooperative skills as they work together to set up the course and then get set to run, jump, and hop through it.
needStatement: My students need hoops, cones, stepping stones, jump ropes and other supplies to create indoor/outdoor obstacle course races.

name: Bringing Out the BOOKWORM in Children Today, Leaders of Tomorrow
description: Our school serves students in grades K-5 and focuses on working together to develop life-long learners and responsible citizens. We provide special education, academic intervention, Title I, and ESL services. As a fifth grade educator, I have observed many success stories of students who challenge themselves raising their expectations to higher levels, take on more responsibility, and become an independent student. My goal is to prepare my students for middle school leaving them with a passion, excitement for learning, and confidence. My diverse fifth grade classroom molds together 28 unique students, many of who come from bilingual households and receive free and reduced breakfast and lunch. My students come to school every day eager to learn and put their trust in me. Every student has a unique learning ability, and I want to give each individual the best learning experience by adapting my lessons to meet their individual needs. Incorporating engaging resources and hands-on manipulatives allow my students to work through self-discovery ultimately leading to abstract reasoning. This educational philosophy, I believe, will promote not only good decision-making in the classroom, but also establish a fundamental life long skill. Imagine going through your local library only to find the same books month after month. Last year student reading interest in my classroom became stagnant with many students having already read some of the same books the year before. My classroom library is limited in contemporary and culturally relevant literature, so the best resource was the school or public library. By fifth grade, students have already had a few years to sort through the school library and read what peaked their interest. I need my students to WANT to read instead of having it be a chore either as a school or home academic obligation. My students spend at least 30 minutes a day reading independently not including the time spent reading at home. I want to give my students choices, variety, and exposure to different sources and points of view when it comes to the literature they are reading so reading is always enjoyable. I believe my students would be thrilled if our library contained more contemporary resources such as Out of Abaton and Counting by 7s as well as more culturally relevant resources such as The Red Pencil and Serafina's Promise. Expanding our library would be beneficial not only for independent reading as well as for our weekly book clubs. It would also give students choice and a variety in the quality of books they are reading to help light and maintain the fire in becoming a life long reader.
needStatement: My students need a variety of books to choose from as well as sets for our weekly book club.

name: Secure Storage For Students' Stuff
description: I teach at a small school with a population of a little over two hundred pupils. Many of the families in our school community are struggling to make ends meet, and are doing the best they can with what they have. The poverty rate is so high in the district, that we recently qualified for a grant providing universal breakfast and lunch. The saying 'It takes a village' exemplifies our situation here, as parents and staff continuously must pool resources and think creatively to meet the needs of our students. This year, I have been given the assignment of sixth grade homeroom teacher. My classroom happens to be our school's art studio. It is sometimes the sight of massive glitter explosions, paint-tastrophies, and other messes that are to be expected in a space shared by about two hundred young artists. There is no coat closet or otherwise separate space for student storage. My students are in need of a secure place to hang coats, backpacks, and stow personal items without worrying that they'll be ruined. Please help me provide my sixth grade homeroom students with lockers. I know they will love them!
needStatement: My students need lockers to organize and store their personal belongings.

name: 'Lettuce' Create a Farm to Table Classroom!
description: My students are energetic and eager to learn about STEM through hands-on activities related to real life problems and scenarios. They are budding scientists, who love to learn and explore. Our school's magnet theme has a focus on Science, Technology, Engineering and Math. I want to give them a head start on a long and successful STEM career. These students are the future doctors, engineers, and computer programmers. My students love to learn through first-hand experiences by completing design challenges in engineering or planting and harvesting our own plants. Getting materials and supplies for my students is costly and not always easy to provide. Please help me make their dreams become a reality!My project is 'kid-inspired' because my students decided we needed small appliances to create a farm to table kitchen in our classroom. We have tried cooking simple food, but is it very difficult without the proper appliances. With these appliances, students will be able make pizza with nutritious vegetable toppings and use the vegetables and herbs that we grow to add to delicious and nutritious healthy smoothies. Having a farm to table classroom kitchen, will encourage our students to make healthier food choices in school and then bring their knowledge home to help their parents make better food choices as a family. It will also help our students learn about how important it is to fuel your body with healthy foods to have a healthy mind and body. Using the blender and nutribullet I will have the students learn the importance of the vitamins and nutrients in wholesome fruits and vegetables by creating smoothies. Students will harvest the vegetables from our garden or the supermarket. Using the fan it will keep the room cool while we make veggie pizzas and other delicious recipes. My students will be thrilled to have their own farm to table kitchen right in our classroom! Since I am trying to teach my students about the importance of eating healthy, being able to cook healthy items in my classroom will motivate them to make better choices when it comes to food. I can't wait to see their excitement as they begin learning how to prepare and cook nutritious meals. We will document this farm to table journey on our iPads and invite parents and other classes to taste our delicious meals!
needStatement: My students need a convection oven, blenders, Nutri-Bullets, and Crock-Pots to create a farm to table classroom.

name: Singing And Moving To The Music!
description: Our elementary school is in an urban neighborhood in St. Paul. Many of our students are new to the United States and are learning English. We also have many students with special needs. About 85% of our families experience poverty. Our wonderful first graders come to school with a lot of energy and are excited about school. They love to jump and move and run. They love to make up games and songs and are creative about adding movement to the songs we learn and sing from our class song books. Playing together, especially during our afternoon recess break and morning meeting, helps us to build community in each classroom. Our students work together and make friends. Active movement and singing make it possible for all students to participate and be valued for their participation. All students have fun, and all students get ready to learn. When I first began teaching my students songs about the colors, my goal was for them to learn basic English vocabulary, oral language, and beginning reading skills. They quickly showed me that singing can be about much more! Soon they began adapting the songs I taught them. Singing became much more active and student centered. My first graders figured out how to make up their own version of the color songs by adding movement and changing the words, which added to the fun! Now they are clamoring to to turn the songs into games! What better way for first graders to make a game than to use rainbow colored parachutes while singing color songs, and to jump and spin and shake the parachute! The parachutes will get the kids even more active and moving faster and in different ways. For example, the students holding the red part of the parachute might jump up every time they use the word red. The blue students might have to run under the parachute and change places while the others shake it. Green students might run around the perimeter of the circle! This will lead to whole new way for students to be creative. First graders will quickly be ready to take turns leading parachute games and activities, and making up their own games with a lot movement and laughter. Moving and playing and singing will help my first graders to become confident of their place and their value in the classroom community. They will feel more sure of themselves and secure in their use of English. They will learn how to cooperate and take turns. This will lead to greater academic success. They will also learn that active playing is a way of exercising and being healthy.
needStatement: My students need colorful parachutes, soft balls, and a music CD to engage in active, cooperative play.

name: Technology For Researchers
description: My students come into my classroom everyday with a smile and a high five for me. We love to have fun and have classroom discussions to get our brains working. In a Title I school, we are faced with many challenges. Many schools have students that are very familiar with all kinds of technology. My students and I are lucky if we have Internet in the rural community we are from. But everyday, they are ready to learn and tackle whatever Mrs. B throws at them! With the advancement of technology in education, my students are still lacking technology in their classroom. We do not have in-class computers, so with these iPads, we will be able to do research everyday. In the community we live in, internet is hard to come by. My students' minds are constantly coming up with questions and I want to teach them how to find out those questions on their own in order to create more inquiry learning. Along with research, we will be using them for throughout the week spelling tests, math facts, reading presentations (Apps), and any other group activities for our other subjects.
needStatement: My students need iPads and cases in the classroom in order to do more hands-on research at anytime throughout our day.

name: Stability Ball Chairs to Get Our Wiggles Out!
description: I teach at a Title 1 school, and all of our students are eligible for free breakfast and lunch. We have a diverse group of learners, and all come with different funds of knowledge. My students are dynamic, unique, and eager to learn. They are active and lively learners! My students range in all ability levels. They LOVE to wiggle and move! I have the sweetest group of kids and they are so appreciative, passionate, and eager to learn! They ROCK!Stability balls are replacing chairs in classrooms all over the country. The benefits are staggering. Students who use stability balls benefit from improved posture and increased attentiveness in the classroom. Instead of leaning back in a chair and growing tired, students must sit up and be a part of the classroom. Students who need to fidget while they focus have a great outlet! Stability balls provide students a way to wiggle in a controlled manner. Movement stimulates the brain and helps us stay awake and focused! Students will be able to sit on their exercise balls throughout the day. Having the exercise balls instead of regular chairs will allow them to 'bounce out' some of their energy throughout the day.
needStatement: My students need 22 stability balls to improve their focus, allow for movement, and activate engaged learning!

name: SENSORY CORNER
description: The students in my classroom are Autistic. Our school is located in small town in Alabama. All the students in the county with ASD come to our school. My students are between 12- 21 years old (7-12th grade). Each one of my students is different and in different parts of the spectrum. We have verbal and non-verbal students. My team and I decided that our theme for this school year would be 'You don't have to be perfect to be amazing '  I want to be able to provide my students the sensory setting to release some of their frustration and anxiety. I have started to create a setting where my students can feel safe and comfortable when they most needed. They will be working hard throughout the day in their academics and life skills and need a place where they can relax. I know that with the right setting and sensory toys that we will be able to provide this for them. This will improve their lives because they are able to have a place to escape to and then be able to come back and continue their daily tasks.
needStatement: My students need a place where they can sit and lay in the sensory corners of our classroom. The Video Rockers allows my student to get that sensory stimulation that they seek.

name: Quill You Help Us Print?
description: Our elementary school is a culturally rich school with a diverse population of 580 students in Pre-K through sixth grade. Our Title I school population has 92% of students qualifying for free or reduced priced lunches and high concentration of English Learners. I believe student engagement is the key to learning. Students must be involved in order to learn! Recently, I have discovered that movement is essential to a positive classroom environment and academic success. Children who are able to move and collaborate are also eager to learn. My students wish for a colored printer and ink to bring their projects to life. Something as simple as a printer, will involve all my students and hold them accountable during their learning process. One of the steps of our engineering design process is to create. During this phase, students explore student-friendly sites on the Internet to gather evidence and material to include and produce a prototype. Having a printer in the classroom with ink will cut out a lot of wasted time during the creative phase. By having a printer in the classroom, students will be able to neatly publish their work by printing their ideas directly from the computer they published it on in their classroom.
needStatement: My students need a colored printer and ink to bring their learning to life!

name: Movement Stools for Active Learners
description: As a teacher in a low-income/high poverty school district, my students are faced with several challenges both in and out of the classroom. Despite the many challenges they face, my students arrive at school every day ready to learn with a smile! My students are motivated to learn and I want to be able to provide the resources they need to do their best! Since our school is home to many low-income families, few resources are available to support our students in their learning. My students need alternative seating to help them engage their bodies in movement to activate their learning success!“Not the hard chairs again!” I hear this statement every school year! So, I am leaving it up to my new students to change that! It is now their turn to make it THEIR classroom and they want Hokki stools that allow them to move! My third grade students work very hard, but many of my third grade students have a difficult time sitting in their seats, especially for long periods of time. The Hokki Stools will help to transform stationary sitting into an activity to engage them while learning and keep them active for more than 60 minutes a day! My students want a way to keep their brains active by keeping their bodies active! Research shows that flexible seating can help students burn more calories, use up excess energy, improve metabolism, increase engagement and motivation, and improve core strength and overall posture. This “kid-inspired” solution of Hokki stools will create all-day movement to increase focus while stabilizing muscles throughout the body! Thank you in advance for your support in their project that will impact the success of these active learners!
needStatement: My students need six Hokki Stools to allow them to move while they learn!

name: Building Language Confidence & Vocabulary
description: My students come from many diverse backgrounds and each student brings unique life experiences to our classroom. Our classroom is a self-contained special education setting where instruction is adapted to meet the specific needs of young students with hearing loss. My students are ambitious, creative and hands-on 3-5 year old early childhood special education learners who all are Deaf/Hard of Hearing. Our school's mission is to build a respectful, successful learning community through art-centered and technology-enhanced practices that develop intelligent behaviors in all students. Our school is an inclusive setting that accommodates the needs of all learners, even our very young Early Childhood Special Education students. These materials will provide my students with opportunities to connect our daily skills practice to independent exploration time as well as small, large and individual work time. With these supplies, my students will be excited to use their voices to speak into the echo microphones. They will enjoy using the sound phones to hear their voices better. These pieces will be critical to helping increase participation in speech activities. The materials in this project will allow a hands-on way to add excitement to practicing using their voices and building vocabulary as well as increasing their confidence in using their voice.
needStatement: My students need an Alphabet sounds teaching tub set with storage and hear myself sound phones along with echo microphones in order to practice their language and build their vocabulary and confidence in using their voice.

name: Music Therapy for Early Childhood Special Education
description: My students have unique learning needs and learn and process new information in many different ways. One aspect of our learning day, that brings all of my students together, is music. Music is a powerful, engaging, and creative time that my students thrive on. Having the opportunity for a music therapist to work with my students would be a wonderful opportunity for my students to express themselves, to be engaged, and to create. “Music gives a soul to the universe, wings to the mind, flight to the imagination and life to everything.”--Plato. My students range from 3-5 years old. They have delays in 2 or more areas (cognition, motor, communication, social/emotional, and or functional/adaptive) of their development, however, this does not define who they are or limit their learning capacity. My students are loving, caring, and eager to learn and try new things. I am blessed to be their teacher and couldn’t ask for a better group of learners. The mission of my school is to provide a quality, comprehensive, arts-infused education. Having music therapists come into the ECSE classroom at my school, will provide students and staff the opportunity to bring music and creativity to our youngest learners.A teaching artist will come into our classroom once a week throughout the school year to provide music therapy lessons to our students. Teaching artists are board certified and have experience working with young children with special and unique learning needs. Staff and students will be fully engaged during this special opportunity to learn, create and experience music in different ways. Donations to this project will help fund Learning Through Music groups for 15 weeks in our classroom. During Learning Through Music, students will learn academic and arts concepts that are embedded into the music activities (instrument play, singing, finger plays, sensory/relaxation, and movement). The students will also have the opportunity to transfer skills practiced and learned during music group to the classroom as the teacher and special education aides will also participate in the learning.
needStatement: My students need donations for direct service hours for teaching artists to come into our classroom.

name: No Art Teacher? No Problem!
description: Kindergarten days are jam-packed with learning everything from letters to numbers to sight words to basic addition and how to read. Now imagine learning all of this new content, but not being able to express yourself in the language the teacher is using. Many of my students are English Language Learners who need a way to express themselves as they learn and grow. Most are from east African countries, many who have experienced life as refugees and are new to our country. As a public charter school, we have students attending from Minneapolis, St. Paul as well as a number of surrounding communities. We are focused on becoming authorized as an International Baccalaureate (IB) Primary Years Programme. This means we are focused on helping scholars live out the IB Learner Profile by being inquirers, knowledgeable, thinkers, communicators, principled, open-minded, caring, courageous, balanced and reflective. We are constantly thinking about how to raise the academic bar for students in conjunction with helping scholars understand what it means to be internationally minded global citizens. There are 20 scholars in my classroom who are full of energy and hungry to learn, grow and reach the dreams they have for their futures. These art supplies will be used on a daily basis during choice time for students to use their imaginations and sharpen motor skills! We do not have an art teacher at our school which means students do not have a dedicated space to explore the world through color and creativity. Students will be able to express themselves through painting, drawing, and creating which will help them grow as learners and people. As students engage in learning a new language, these materials will help them show what they are thinking and feeling, providing a valuable window into their worlds and minds.
needStatement: My students need art supplies such as an easel, crayons, watercolor paint, colored pencils, markers, ink pads, pipe stems, glue, paper, paint cups, feathers, tissue paper, and pom poms.

name: A Salsa Garden & High School Health Students.
description: Kim and Sandy are excited to tell you about the request that came from the 10th grade Health Class. They want to make a Salsa Garden. Once they started talking about this project it just started to get bigger and bigger. I had Maria talk about bringing community members to talk about the Hispanic culture. I had Grace mention how much fun eating school grown salsa would be. I had other kids raise their hands and say, I like Peppers in my Salsa, a Hmong student mentioned that he has sweet tomatoes in their own grown salsa. I had a hmong student whose parents do Farmer's Market every saturday say my family could donate some seeds for the garden. The students are loving this idea of having a school grown salsa garden here at school. They can't wait to watch it grown and then share in having a salsa party after the garden grows. My students will develop skills to be able to grown a garden of their own some day. We are teaching them a life long skill to be able to grow vegetables and herbs to make a Salsa garden. A academic skill is stress relieving. We also have team-work and life-long skill of learning how to grow a garden and be able to feed your family through a garden. We will also deal with problem solving on where to put the seeds in the garden, we will need to research how long certain vegetable take to grow and how much sun light they will need. A lot of life-long skills and survival skills are learned in growing a garden. The kids are so excited about a Salsa garden. The goal is to learn how to grow vegetables to then eating what we have grown. We have a diverse population and salsa brings every ethnic group together. We want to grow a garden and reap the rewards. We want to eat our produce. We will make the most by allowing all students to participate in the garden. Being able to grow a garden is a life-long skill that all students need to know. Ka, took the lead on the project and really has shown leadership on what vegetables are needed for a salsa garden. Why this project is important is because we are in Health class and eating healthy is very important. Maria, stood up and stated how important eating healthy is to her and her family. Jesse stated that he just loves Salsa and can't wait to watch our garden grow and flourish right before our eyes.
needStatement: We need everything to start a Salsa garden. My students will be starting from scratch on setting up a garden. Many students have never grown anything let along a Salsa garden.

name: Supplies And Books Galore!
description: I am extremely fortunate to be teaching in a unique and powerful 21st Century Learning Studio, filled by a diverse group of students. In this type of learning environment there are 4 teachers, each with a homebase of about 20 students, as well as an English Language teacher for our large group of English Language Learners. The Studio has only partial walls and a variety of large and small group spaces filled with easily movable furniture--couches, stools, and tables, but no traditional desks--to allow for flexible learning and space for students to learn in the way that works best for them. We are all one 'class,' and teachers share students, and students share teachers interchangeably. Our goal is success for each student. We understand that success looks different for each student, so we focus on personalized learning. Personalized learning lets each student work at their own pace and at their own level. We also focus on preparing students for the 21st century and the future by allowing for extensive opportunities with Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math. The Studio and our STEAM focus allows for more small group and individualized time for students, which benefits everyone. Setting up for a new school year comes with lots of organization and decorating. Throughout the year all this work can be quickly worn down by use- which is exactly what we want! To make the materials last so that students can continue to use them it helps to laminate paper items. With a laminator our supplies will last longer and get used more often! Our Studio also needs anchor charts and other documentation of learning. Post it chart paper is the most convenient way to do this and is a student and teacher favorite! We are also looking for new books that are reflective of our diverse class and community. Reading will be a focus in our Studio this year and we want to make sure students have all the supplies needed to enjoy it the most! Our Studio will look ready, welcoming, and alive, with these supplies and books!
needStatement: My students need durable materials that will last, which can be made possible by using the Scotch thermal laminator. We also need books so that our Studio library is reflective of our diverse class!

name: Learning through Music for ECSE
description: My students come from many diverse backgrounds and each student brings unique life experiences to our classroom. Our classroom is a self-contained special education setting where instruction is adapted to meet the specific needs of young students with hearing loss. My students are ambitious, creative and hands-on 3-5 year old early childhood special education learners who all are Deaf/Hard of Hearing. Our school's mission is to build a respectful, successful learning community through art-centered and technology-enhanced practices that develop intelligent behaviors in all students. Our school is an inclusive setting that accommodates the needs of all learners, even our very young Early Childhood Special Education students. While we use music in the classroom, the money from this project will give the students an opportunity to work with teaching artists that are also board certified music therapists and have experience working with children with special needs. Donations to this project will help fund Learning Through Music groups for 15 weeks in our classroom. During Learning Through Music, students will learn academic and arts concepts that are embedded into the music activities (instrument play, singing, finger plays, sensory/relaxation, and movement). The students will also have the opportunity to transfer skills practiced and learned during music group to the classroom as the teacher and special education aides will also participate in the learning.
needStatement: My students need donations for direct service hours for the teaching artists to come into our classroom.

name: Wobble While You Work
description: Imagine a classroom where students can learn in their own way! I work in a Title I school where 99% of our students are on free/ reduced lunch. Not only are my students one of a kind, but each one of them learns in a different way. Most of my third grade students are active learners who need to be able to freely move around my room with flexible seating. These students deserve an active classroom for the best learning possible! The more movement, the more oxygen to the brain the better the learning. Wobble stools help those students in my classroom who just need to move! These stools allow our room to be in harmony as I still have them working on important skills but they are getting the movement they need. Over 50% of my classroom are males and they need movement while learning. The students who need constant movement in order to focus will benefit from this project because they can move and wobble while they work. The importance of this project hits close to home as I was that student who needed constant movement and I want to give this to my students in my classroom.
needStatement: My students need more movement. Movement gives more oxygen to the brain. The more oxygen the better their growing brains learn. The addition of the wobble stools in my classroom will help students move while working.

name: Absent Narratives Through Spoken Word
description: My students, first and foremost, are incredible young people! They are intelligent, funny, compassionate and resilient! We are a racially, ethnically, and economically diverse school. Our demographic breakdown is about 30% African American, 30% Asian/Pacific Islander, 25% Caucasian, and 15% Hispanic. Our free and reduced lunch students make up 78% of our total population, with another 24% of students receiving Special Education services, and 31% being Multi-Language Learners. My students come from backgrounds as diverse as their demographics; single-parent households, lower-income, homeless, abuse, mental health issues, and others come with very little trauma to face. Honestly, many of my students struggle, some with previously mentioned issues, many with academics. I am grateful to be able to share this time with them and to support their growth and independence. Together, we work together to learn, play, grow, and create a community of hope and respect in classroom 2112.In an effort to bridge the 'opportunity gap' facing many of our students, and to begin the school year by building a strong, culturally centered learning community, I would like the opening unit to incorporate Common Core reading, writing, and speaking standards through student interaction with each other, the classroom teacher, and professional spoken word artist, Frank Sentwali. Students are encouraged to trust, take risks, and make connections with one another as they examine a variety of poems and are guided to understand, analyze, create, and perform original work throughout the week. The week-long residency culminates in a performance of final pieces at week's end Open Mic celebration. Mr. Frank Sentwali joins each of the six English Language Arts classrooms for one week. During this week, he is the facilitator of students’ learning. He teaches the elements of spoken word, performs his own pieces, and engages students in discussions about topics relevant to them. Some past topics of student created poetry have included racism, bullying, and family relationships. Mr. Sentwali takes students through the artistic process of creating their own pieces of writing. He teaches and reminds students about various poetic devices and performance techniques to enhance their original pieces. He encourages them with a masterful balance of compassion, respect, and high expectations. He encourages teachers to join in and share their own artistic journeys and poems with students as well. Mr. Sentwali fosters a sense of community and sharing that encourages learners of all ages and abilities to participate.
needStatement: My students need a week-long Spoken Word workshop with professional poet, Frank Sentwali.

name: Drifting Away With Audio Books
description: Our school serves students in grades K-5 and focuses on working together to develop life-long learners and responsible citizens. We provide special education, academic intervention, Title I, and ESL services. As a fifth grade educator, I have observed many success stories of students who challenge themselves, raising their expectations to higher levels, take on more responsibility, and become an independent student. My goal is to prepare my students for middle school leaving them with a passion, excitement for learning, and confidence. My diverse fifth grade classroom molds together 28 unique students, many of who come from bilingual households and receive free and reduced-price breakfast and lunch. My students come to school every day eager to learn and put their trust in me. Every student has a unique learning ability, and I want to give each individual the best learning experience by adapting my lessons to meet their individual needs. Incorporating engaging resources and hands-on manipulatives allow my students to work through self-discovery, ultimately leading to abstract reasoning. This educational philosophy, I believe, will promote not only good decision-making in the classroom, but also establish a fundamental life long skill. Imagine trying to read through a physiology textbook or a 40-page proposal for work. You struggle to stay awake but know the assignment has to be finished. Now, imagine if your teacher gave you the option to follow along while William Shatner, Kevin Spacey, or Morgan Freeman narrated the text. These famous voice actors change the way we hear the text as we become entranced in the literature regardless of the topic. Audio books have the same impact on children. Audio books can help children become better readers and more effective learners. Listening to audio books will be used as an accommodation for struggling readers as well as an enrichment tool for students reading at grade level. Incorporating audio books and five iPod shuffles will give my students the opportunity to develop listening skills, understand complex language, learn punctuation and enunciation, and become familiar with accents and dialects. In addition to becoming stronger readers, I want my students to develop a passion for reading, which is why I chose some of my own favorite children’s books such as Matilda, Where the Mountain Meets the Moon, and The Mighty Miss Malone. I also chose literature within a series such as Harry Potter, The Series of Unfortunate Events, and Artemis with hopes that I have captured their interest as they continue reading the series.
needStatement: My students need five iPod shuffles and rich audio books to help meet the needs of auditory learners. Audiobooks will also benefit the English Language Learners in my class.

name: Strategy Old School Style
description: My students are all from the Flint, Mi area. They are very resilient children. Most of them live in areas of high crime rate and have recently been through a water crisis that has attracted world wide attention. Every day they come to school eager to learn and are extremely excited when they are given a new challenge or a new way of learning. I recently started integrating a lot of technology into my classroom and I was amazed at the response that the students had. After a few short weeks, they were actually showing me how to use it!I have recently integrated a lot of technology into my teaching. Students work on every media device that I can get my hands on. I have found that students are struggling with strategy situations. I introduced a few board games to students and was amazed that many of them hadn't played simple strategy games like the ones that I selected. Once I put checkers out as an activity, students lined up to play instead of other activities that were available. I want to incorporate these strategic games into my math workshops so students can think and show sportsmanship while playing games that most of us adults grew up playing.
needStatement: My students need UNO, Trouble, Sorry, Connect Four, minute math flash cards, uncle wiggly and other strategic games to improve critical thinking and sportsmanship during a math center.

name: Flexible Seating: Choosing the Seat That's Right for You!
description: Though I have not officially met the students in my room for the upcoming school year, if they are anything like the other three classes of kiddos I have had at this school, they will be curious, energetic, and hard working. Our school is great at building students for success, and they respond positively to challenges. Each student deserves the best education and we work hard to find accommodations that allow all student to be successful. The kids we work with from year to year are responding and learning. They take ownership over their learning and all want to do their best. After teaching Kindergarten for 9 years, there is one thing I know for sure, Kindergarten kids need to move! Not all students work successfully in the same way. Not everyone has enough control over their bodies to sit in a standard chair and work. Some students feel more comfortable sitting on the ground, working at a standing table, or sitting in a chair that allows them to wobble in a safe way. Introducing flexible seating into my classroom will allow students to choose the type of seating that works best for them. It is giving them ownership over their learning and gives them a voice and choice each day.
needStatement: My students need ten different seating tools to provide flexible seating in our classroom. The balance discs, wobble cushions and stools will allow students to sit and work at a table, but also the ability to 'wobble'.

name: Books, Books and More Books!
description: My students are like no other. They want to be loved, accepted and grow. I want the best for them. I want to provide them with things that will help them grow as individuals and academically. Our school is located in a rural town in Mid-West MN.
