The majority of my students communicate in a nontraditional way, meaning they utilize alternative modes of communication rather than a typical voice for vocalization. Some students use a communication device, picture symbols, or use a head turn to answer yes or no. Together we must be motivated as a community to give these students as many opportunities as possible to learn how to communicate and socialize with others in a meaningful way. This project will bring artists from Upstream Arts to our school to provide an arts residency. Students who participate in this residency with Upstream Arts will have an opportunity to work with local artists who are specifically trained to support individuals with disabilities and live in the area. By collaborating with Upstream Arts, students will have the opportunity to experience the arts in a unique way that is accessible to their needs. Upstream Arts will focus on communication and encourage students to participate in social interactions using all artistic mediums. Through this artistic experience, students will be given the opportunity to communicate and learn the complicated nuances of social interaction and communication. Students will learn new social and communication skills, as well as build upon skills already mastered. Individuals participating in this residency will create positive social and communication experiences, which will carry over into other environments throughout their daily lives.
needStatement: My students need the Upstream Arts residency to come to our school to support our unique social and communication needs through art education!

name: Art is in the Eye of the Beholder!!
description: My students are very special because they have very diverse backgrounds. They bring many different views since there home life is very different from each other. They enjoy coming to school each day and are ready to learn even when dealing with obstacles at home. They are very energetic and caring. There are many role models in the class. They are hardworking and want to learn. All of them participate in different activities and enjoy trying something new. Also, they like science. They are a unique bunch of students!These arts supplies (watercolors, trays, mold and play moon sand, paintbrushes and magnetic hooks) will give students the opportunity to practice and use their art skills. Since students are low income they may not have access to any art supplies at home. We do many different art projects throughout the year using watercolors and paintbrushes. We use the paintbrushes and watercolors to make murals, lines for texture, and to show how to create shadows in a painting. Students also connect the pictures they paint to writing and write about what they created. The trays are used so students can paint on them and the magnet hooks are so students can display their artwork in the classroom and feel proud of what they created. These supplies give students a chance to express themselves through art who may not have the chance to do it at home. It is great to be able to do art and get exposure to that. It also gives students a chance to feel successful in a subject who may not get that feeling in reading, writing, or math. Art is a universal subject so my students who are new to the country will get a chance to show what they can do.
needStatement: My students need basic art supplies (paintbrushes, watercolors, trays an mold and play moon sand) to help foster a love for art.

name: Wiggle Room
description: Imagine walking into a classroom in a new school, a friendly student approaches you and asks your name. You answer, but your new friend can't understand what you've said. You clarify a few times, but you fail to communicate the one word that should come naturally to every child. Sounds like a bad dream, right? For many of my students, this is the case. My students are fun and hard-working; they want their world to know it! Let's provide them the tools they need to make them more effective communicators so that they can grow socially and academically! Our speech sessions are filled with exciting, relevant learning and activities but for me and many of my students, movement is a must. I feel that movement helps keep many of my students engaged and actively learning. I have seen lots of success from the use of these Wobble Cushions in students with active bodies and minds. These tools would give my students the opportunity to let the wiggles escape in an appropriate way. I am requesting wobble cushions as well as an exercise ball chair and 3-legged folding camp stool to give students some choices of where/how they would like to sit and work. My students are hard working and want to learn and become more confident communicators. Many of my students require a good deal of cueing and assistance from me to be able to achieve good placement to produce speech sounds. The garden stool will help me get to a good level in order to see in their mouths and provide the assistance needed to achieve their goals!
needStatement: My students need some wiggle discs and a yoga ball chair to help get their bodies moving and their brains working!

name: Spheros to Spark Students' Minds
description: Our school is a member of the national network of EL Schools, which promote rigorous and engaging curriculum; active, inquiry-based pedagogy; and a school culture that demands and teaches compassion and good citizenship. Our curriculum is designed around Learning Expeditions – projects that allow students to investigate issues in our school, the community and the world. The study of big ideas enables us to weave together work in multiple subject areas. Students are given time to think about important issues, time to experiment, and time to understand what they’ve learned. Our “small school” learning environment inspires students to ask questions in a culture that demands and teaches compassion and good citizenship. When the school day begins at Open World Learning Community (OWL), you'll find students and staff from diverse cultural backgrounds sharing a common goal: the desire to discuss, explore, investigate and learn. It is a world designed for student-centered learning - a place where innovative programs and hands-on methods encourage curiosity and discovery. You will hear students and teachers having real conversations about their lives. My students will use the Spheros to not only develop their own coding skills but to help other students learn about coding. Students will be presenting at a conference on how to code and we would like to use the Spheros to teach other students how to code. Students just returned from a field trip using the Spheros and would use the Spheros to learn more about coding, geometric shapes, time distance, acceleration speed per second, distance around specific shapes and objects. Spheros to Spark Students Minds, My Project: Spheros to Spark Students Minds, My students will use the Spheros to not only develop their own coding skills but to help other students learn about coding.
needStatement: My students need Spheros to learn more about coding, geometric shapes, time distance, acceleration speed per second, distance around specific shapes and objects. Students just returned from a field trip using them.

name: Support Our Tumbling with New Mats!
description: Our students are diverse and many of them are first generation Americans. Most of the students speak their native language at home; Cantonese, Spanish, Emharic, Somali, Tagalog, and Vietnamese. Our students are encouraged and supporting in maintaining their home languages as well as English. Our students are special because they grow up in a diverse urban neighborhood. They have a unique perspective on languages and cultures. It is normal for them to encounter others who speak a different language or experience a culture than their own. Our students love to learn how to do somersaults, cartwheels and do back bends. Do you remember learning this as a child in school? The students feel so strong and confident when they can accomplish a cartwheel and round off. These mats will make a difference in our program because the current mats we are using are over 50 years old. They are worn and the stuffing is exposed and they are beginning to break down. The exposed stuffing is hard to clean and new mats would keep the gym clean. These mats will also have stronger velcro to adhere together for a tumbling station.
needStatement: My students need new mats to support our tumbling project. Our current mats are over 50 years old and are worn and falling apart. Our students love to do somersaults and cartwheels.

name: VR 360 Maker Space for All Abilities Upgrade 1.2
description: My classroom consists of transition-aged students (19-21 years) who are on the cusp of entering the world as adults out of post-secondary school. Beyond our doors, they will be entering the workforce without the supports and protection offered by our staff. They will need to be able to fend for themselves. Each student is unique and their needs are all different. Every day they are honored for their abilities and praised for their successes! Our school focuses beyond graduation when it comes to teaching our students to be successful in post-school life. Our school is broken down into 3 'Pathways' to independence. Our Pathway students attend a federal setting 4 special education program to support their needs and get them ready for post-graduation life. Many of the students at our school are diagnosed with severe and profound developmental disabilities including Autism and Severe Multiple Impairments. Our school is filled with committed staff who create a meaningful school experience for all students and their unique needs. Our last project funded a Virtual Reality 360 Maker Space for students and staff to invent, adapt, dream, and overcome disabilities in and outside of class time. Combined with our 3D printer and LEGO Ev3 systems, the new Raspberry Pi systems and VR headsets have made our Maker Space a buzz of excitement at school. It is time to add functional sensors and haptic feedback systems to the Maker Space so that our students can reach their STEM goals through the creation of a fully immersive virtual reality cockpit. With customizable haptic feedback pressure suits paired with our VR 360 camera's footage, the physical limitations of my students will 'virtually' disappear and allow them to experience life beyond a window pane. Some of my students have great anxiety about traveling to new places whether it be in the community or the greater world. Their anxiety can sometimes produce behaviors that can be detrimental to their ability to experience things along with their peers. Students and staff will have the opportunity to record their travels along the same routes and arrive at the destinations using our 360 VR cameras, we can then use the Raspberry Pi systems along with touchscreens and VR Goggles to broadcast the footage to the students having anxiety. If they are able to view the route with 360 degrees of perspective, they may gain familiarity with it and possibly have reduced anxiety when they travel the route in person. The Maker Space will be available outside of normal school hours, as well as on weekends for students and staff to access. Skills in math and science can be taught and learned through coding for the Pi's, creating CAD designs for the 3D printer, and creating / adapting assistive technology.
needStatement: My students need the technology to to bring our VR 360 Maker Space to the next level!

name: Any Dream Will Do
description: Our school is working tirelessly to close the learning gap by challenging the norm of education through our creative and innovative strategies to reach our black and brown scholars. Many of our scholars live in poverty or are homeless. By providing city-wide transportation, our scholars that move frequently can have a consistent spot to call their home school. We believe that having a stable learning environment will move our scholars ahead to greater successes in higher education. We inspire our scholars to reach high levels of academic and social achievement and become future leaders through a collaborative support system. Our Kindergarten scholars have not gone on an end of the school year field trip for the past couple of years. We would like to take a class trip to the Children's Theater this year to see Frog and Toad. Our scholars are learning about creating and constructing in their world. As part of the process, they are learning to present for their peers and also how to be a good audience member. We practice reading, singing, making music, dancing and many other things in front of each other to build confidence. We are looking ahead to the end of the school year and want to create and make a memory for our scholars to treasure. The Children's Theater of MN is performing Frog and Toad on June 8, 2017 and we want to be there. What a fun and exciting way to send them off to first grade.
needStatement: My students need funding to see Frog and Toad at the Children's Theater for an end of the year celebration!

name: Solving Science Mysteries with MysteryScience
description: I have the privilege of spending my days with eager, curious, and enthusiastic 7 and 8 year olds who want to do their very best at everything they try. They are growing up in a world that allows them to be individuals and respects their individual differences and learning styles. Each year, I try something new to allow for greater flexibility and to encourage collaboration and deeper learning. I am very excited about the dream I have for the students I am working with this year!Our school has found a web site that compliments our science curriculum wonderfully and 'hooks' our students through the world of mysteries! On MysteryScience, every lesson begins with a mystery and then uses captivating videos and images, combined with discussion opportunities and hands-on activities, to fully immerse our students in the science content we teach. Right now, many of our teachers are using this site through free trial memberships. We would like to request support to continue our membership so we have the wonderful opportunity to continue to engage our students through this site! The introductory mystery, videos, and hands-on activities enable our students to engage in three-dimensional learning that is key to successful implementation of the Next Generation Science Standards and allows our students to feel the excitement and real-world applications of the science content we teach at each level. A school membership will allow all of our students, kindergarten through fourth grade, age-appropriate and content-appropriate lessons that excite our teachers and students alike! The Next Generation Science Standards require three-dimensional learning of science and this site will be a wonderful resource for every one of our teachers and students!
needStatement: My students need a school-wide membership to MysteryScience to support our science curriculum and our implementation of the Next Generation Science Standards.

name: Super Builders and the Wonder Inventors: Stem With Comic Books
description: Our second grade class is filled with 24 highly motivated students . Students are continually working collaboratively throughout the school day in progressive learning activities like STEM projects, math workshops, Writer's workshop, etc. This is a focused class that is eager to learn, to share, and to encourage each other. This is my fifteenth year in the classroom and this is the most impressive class I've taught yet. They prefer hands on projects and enjoy taking risks. This class perseveres when tasks are challenging. As a member of the committee to create a school wide makerspace I was inspired to create a classroom makerspace for my students. A makerspace is a place where students can share ideas, engage with materials, and create collaboratively based on their interests and unique skills. The comic book series Howtoons is an incredible series that promotes student STEM projects at home and at school. By presenting science, math, and engineering challenges through the dynamics of a graphic novel students will be engaged and excited to lead their own makerspace projects. My hope is that these books will be the basis for a new makerspace library in our classroom.
needStatement: My students need an engaging choice of graphic novels to create our first makerspace program in our classroom.

name: Dynamic Seating for Dynamic Students
description: I teach in a high poverty district, where 100% of our students receive free lunch due to their socioeconomic status. My classroom is a second home to my students. We are a tight knit family that spends our day discovering and learning together. I want to create a collaborative learning space that promote relevant, engaging, active learning. My students are allowed to choose where they work and learn best. Some choose to stand at their desks, while others choose to sit on the floor. My students are very active and we take many 'brain breaks' throughout the day to release energy. We live close to the Mexican border so many of our students are English Language Learners. My students learn best through multi-modal instruction where they are able to express and receive information in a variety of ways. As a classroom teacher, I see the need for movement in the classroom. I am unable to sit straight in a seat and study or take a test for an extended amount of time. That is not how I learn best. If this is something I struggle with, how can I expect it from my students? I currently allow the students to sit in their chair, on the floor or stand at their desks. Not only will it strengthen their core and posture, it will also allow them the much needed movement while they are still in their seats and working. I have a data and research based driven classroom. Research has found that the benefits of alternative seating include: emission of excess energy, improved focus, engagement, legible handwriting, and listening comprehension.
needStatement: My students need 4 therapy balls, 3 wobble chairs and 8 bouncy bands for chairs to stay focused and engaged.

name: CPSHS Cougar Football Trying to Keep it Classy
description: My students live in the inner city and attend a public high school. They are typical high school students trying to find their place in the world. Our demographics are, as follows: 1% American Indian, 35% Asian American, 28% African American, 10% Hispanic American, 26% Caucasian American, 32% English Language Learners, 15% Special Education Learners and 72% Students eligible for Free and Reduced Lunch. Rich in diversity but often lacking in resources. My students are looking for positive experiences and role models. It is exciting to see when they find something that becomes their passion and that often leads to making more positive choices in the classroom and community. Football is a positive outlet away from many of the stressors and negative influences our inner city students face each day. We have a dedicated core of players on our team that work hard in season and year round to better themselves as athletes and young men. However, much of the teams practice equipment is more than 10 seasons old and is falling apart. We are trying to replace some of our worst pairs of practice pants which are downright indecent. These committed and hard working young men deserve to be able to practice in something better than pants with several wholes in them. With new practice pants they can feel valued as a player and have more pride in the positive things in their life. This can hopefully encourage more students to choose to participate in the positive extra curricular activities we have.
needStatement: My students need practice pants with out rips and wholes for the up coming season.

name: Mathematical Reasoning Starts in Kindergarten!
description: My students walk into our classroom every day buzzing with excitement. Kindergarten is an exciting experience for most children, but for my students, all of whom come from a high-poverty neighborhood, it is a chance to escape what may be a negative environment. Our classroom is a safe haven that gives these wonderful students the chance to become explorers, critical thinkers, mathematicians, scientists, authors, artists, and caring, responsible friends. Their excitement for learning is something that I truly wish to nurture and develop into a lifelong passion for education. I do not let the obstacles of minimal to no resources discourage me on this mission. It only motivates me to strive harder to provide them the best and most comprehensive education possible. My students have a daily mathematics period, where they get to learn new skills such as adding, subtracting, and place value. We do not have textbooks for math so as a teacher I always look for the most engaging ways to introduce these topics. My students will benefit from having interactive math centers, in which they can use mathematical reasoning to apply the skills we learn in class. Mathematical reasoning is not just about solving equations. These operations activity centers allow students to use counters, draw models, or mental math to solve given problems. The place value center will give my students the solid foundation of understanding how the base ten system and place value work, so they can apply this knowledge in all future grades. Lastly, an important skill in kindergarten math is to be able to quickly solve sums of ten. This skill is the crucial prior knowledge needed for regrouping in subtraction, that comes in first grade.
needStatement: My students need activity centers for the following mathematical skills: counting and place value, basic operations, and making sums of ten.

name: Help Us Become Sharper Writers
description: I work at a Title 1 school located in Burien, Washington. My class is filled with bright students from diverse backgrounds, most of whom will be learning English as a second language. My students are future engineers, teachers, and politicians, and we are working hard in first grade to prepare them for college, career, and citizenship. We love writing and work hard to write creative, well-crafted pieces in many different genres. We also use writing to learn more about reading, science, and art. Writing, writing, and more writing is the best way to become a better writer. In first grade, we spend over 150 minutes a week writing. We write stories, letters, personal narratives, informational pieces, opinions, poems, and more. The most basic materials we need are pretty simple: pencils and paper. We have pencils and paper already, but to keep our writing workshop running smoothly, we need a high quality pencil sharpener to help keep our pencils sharp and ready to write. In addition to the basics, we need staplers and tape to revise and edit our writing, high quality children's books to motivate and inspire us to write more and more, and boxes to store books in.
needStatement: My students need a high quality pencil sharpener, a stapler, a tape dispenser, books, and book boxes.

name: We Can Read and Learn Science!
description: My students come to first grade eager to learn about the world around them. They love to sit down with a friend to read, and they love to talk! Our school is an urban elementary school in St. Paul with many bilingual students who are learning English. Some of our students have recently arrived in the United States and did not have an opportunity to attend school before. Everyday I see first graders working together, playing together, and engaged in learning about math, reading, writing, and science. They are a community of learners that cares about each other. This year I am engaging the families of my first graders through home visits and academic parent-teacher teams. The families of my students are excited about helping their beginning readers by reading books at home and helping them develop a deeper understanding of the book by talking about the books they read at home. First graders love learning about the world and they love reading books with their family. In my class, I have students who are new to the United States and are learning to speak English as well as learning to read in English. They need interesting books at an early first grade reading level to take home to read with their families. While learning to read, they also need to be introduced to the content of our first-grade science standards. First graders are very interested in science. They especially like reading about animals, the earth, space, the ocean, the weather, and how to make things. Books on these topics capture their interest and make them want to learn and read more. These books will give early readers just the right amount of support to handle the challenge of more difficult concepts and vocabulary. The students also need three boxes to organize their books. Your support of this project will help our first graders to become readers and thinkers, and help our families to become involved in and supportive of their students' learning.
needStatement: My students need twenty non-fiction science books. The books will help beginning readers in first grade learn science concepts and become better readers!

name: Bridging the Gap Through Reading and Writing
description: Low-income. Homeless. High poverty. These are words that people often use to describe our scholars. However, the words people should concentrate on are: high achievers, determined learners, and creative thinkers. We are scholars who have a hunger to learn, a passion for knowledge, and a need to succeed. We are looking to expand our critical-thinking skills, explore our creativity, and develop our talents for twenty-first century learning. We are looking to develop our gifts and talents and need your help to do so. Many of my scholars are currently below grade level in literacy. As a class, we want to be life long readers but currently we have gaps in our knowledge. With these materials, we will be able to emphasize word work and help build an awareness of letter patterns. By donating to this project you will help to scholars practice word work to increase their language knowledge. With the letter recognition center we will continue to build our knowledge base of sounds. Using the magnetic letters, we will then put our phonics skills to use by building words. After learning how to sound out and spell words, we will work on writing stories that incorporate our new vocabulary. We will be using our new writing center and mini books to create stories to share with our families and school friends. By creating a fun new learning space with manipulatives scholars will be able to take their word work to a new level.
needStatement: My students need a writing center with magnetic letter, mini books, reading trackers and more to let their creativity grow.

name: We Love Reading Science Books!
description: My students come to first grade eager to learn about the world around them. They love to sit down with a friend to read and play math games, and they love to talk! Our school is an urban elementary school in St. Paul with many bilingual students who are learning English. Some of our students have recently arrived in the United States and did not have an opportunity to attend school before. Everyday I see first graders working together, playing together, and engaged in learning about math, reading, writing, and science. They are a community of learners that cares about each other. This year I am engaging the families of my first graders through home visits and academic parent-teacher teams. The families of my students are excited about helping their beginning readers by reading books at home and helping them develop a deeper understanding of the book by talking about the books they read at home. First graders love learning about the world and they love reading books with their family. In my class, I have students who are new to the United States and are learning to speak English as well as learning to read in English. They need interesting books at an early first grade reading level to take home to read with their families. The books will engage their interest in science and the world around them and introduce them to the content of our first-grade science standards while they are learning to read. First graders are very interested in science. They especially like reading about animals and learning about plants, insects, the ocean, space, and our planet. They wonder about the weather and different climates on our planet and the animals that live in different environments. Books on these topics capture their interest and make them want to learn and read more. These books will give early readers just the right amount of support to handle the challenge of more difficult concepts and vocabulary. Your support of this project will help our first graders to become readers and thinkers, and help our families to become involved in and supportive of their students' learning.
needStatement: My students need 26 life science books to engage their interest and knowledge of the world around them. They will read the books at school and at home with their families.

name: Are You Ready for Some Football(s)? Because We Are!
description: My students live in the inner city and attend a public high school. They are typical high school students trying to find their place in the world. Our demographics are as follows: 1% American Indian, 35% Asian American, 28% African American, 10% Hispanic American, 26% Caucasian American, 32% English Language Learners, 15% Special Education Learners and 72% Students eligible for Free and Reduced Lunch. Rich in diversity, but often lacking in resources. My students are looking for positive experiences and role models. It is exciting to see when they find something that becomes their passion and that often leads to making more positive choices in the classroom and community. Football is a positive outlet away from many of the stressors and negative influences our inner city students face each day. We have a dedicated core of players on our team that work hard inseason and year round to better themselves as athletes and young men. However, much of the team's footballs are several seasons old and not in great shape. These older footballs do not have the grip that new quality game balls do and can lead to dropped passes and fumbles. These game footballs will ensure that the results of our players' hard work will not be hindered due to worn and weathered footballs. Adequate equipment helps the players feel valued as an individual. Also, it encourages participation in positive extra curricular activities which is a crucial for the success of some of our students.
needStatement: My students need game balls to make the most of this upcoming season.

name: Reading Fun with Storyworks and Time For Kids
description: As a special education resource room teacher, my student roster isn't static. Children come and go throughout the day and throughout the year. Meeting every child's individual academic and social needs is a fun challenge. My day is never boring! My students are a wonderful group of 2nd, 3rd, 4th, and 5th graders attending a high-poverty, urban elementary school. They have a wide range of disabilities that make it challenging for them to learn exclusively in a general education setting. They come to my room for small group instruction in reading, writing, math, and/or social skills. Most of my students are also English language learners. My students rely on consistent routines and access to models and visual examples of the tasks they are completing. They depend on engaging learning experiences that meet them at their individual instructional levels and tap into their personal interests. Most importantly, they depend on having access to the resources that support their individual instructional needs. My biggest challenge as a special education teacher is providing my students with an ever-changing supply of reading materials at their individual reading levels and interests. My school's community is very supportive of all of our learners, but our budget is very tight. While we are fortunate to have a great leveled library, it doesn't have enough breadth for my learners, who take longer to progress from one reading level to another. Likewise, the titles that span the 2nd and 3rd grade reading levels are unlikely to appeal to my older students. In order to read more, they need access to reading material that piques their interest. That's where Storyworks and Time For Kids come in. Every week, my students will have access to Time For Kids' quality, up-to-date news, social studies, and science articles that are relevant for kids of all ages. Monthly, they will receive Storyworks literary magazine, packed full of fiction and non-fiction passages from well-known and up-and-coming authors, often paired with non-fiction passages or poems. With these high-quality resources I'm sure not to run out of materials for my learners. These materials will ensure that my students have non-stop access to high-quality reading material that will pique their imaginations and encourage them to read more, which is key to reading success. After the magazines are used for instruction, they will be the child's to keep and continue enjoying at home. Additionally, students will be able to access online content that pairs their reading with short videos and other interactive activities.
needStatement: My students need yearlong subscriptions to Storyworks literary magazine and Time For Kids weekly news magazine to keep their reading materials fresh and exciting.

name: Special Education Class Needs Multi Sensory Activities!
description: Our room is a classroom for students with severe disabilities and although it is a room of non verbal children, they sure can make a lot of noise and have fun! They enjoy taking walks around the campus, cooking up new recipes and exploring the world through multi sensory activities. It's not the diagnosis that makes these students special; it's their heart and personality that really makes them special. Everyday my students make gains toward being more independent and I love celebrating every milestone. My students are all non-verbal multi sensory learners. They explore their environment through vision, sounds, tactile and oral sensory exploration. Throughout the day I work to make the required curriculum relevant and cognitively appropriate for my students. This has become increasingly difficult for me to do as a first year teacher of students with severe disabilities since I don't have many supplies. These materials will cover a variety of academic and functional skills. During my morning meeting, I will use the calendar supplies to teach patterning, counting, name recognition and eye tracking skills. The musical instruments will help to engage the students and follow along to calendar songs with musical beats. The students will be exposed to common daily words in an engaging manner. This is especially important for my English Language learner students. The academic materials will be used to help the students learn to work independently by doing tasks such as sequencing events and sorting colored bears. They will learn important fine motor skills by using adaptive scissors and use the foam paint to expose themselves new textures and colors. These materials will help me to build creative and engaging curriculum everyday.
needStatement: My students need access to activities that are cognitively appropriate and meet their sensory needs in a safe manner.

name: Organization in Kindergarten
description: Do you remember sitting in class when the teacher asked you to get out an assignment from a previous day and you couldn't find it? I want to set my students up for success by providing them with organization skills in kindergarten that will last them throughout their years in school. My students are from Northeast Houston. They come to school excited to learn and work hard everyday. One of my goals is to show them how to be more organized, in order to help them be more successful throughout school. Most of my students come to kindergarten without ever going to preschool and some have never been away from Mom or Dad. The school environment is new to them and their success depends on keeping all of their materials organized. Organization is a skill they must learn early on in school. In kindergarten students are expected to learn how to read beginner books, fluently complete math facts and write readable stories. All of these tasks require different materials that students need to be able to sort between. These chair sacks will put students on the right path towards becoming autonomous and able to take control of their own learning. Students will use these chair sacks everyday in class to hold books, folders, notebooks, as well as pencils, crayons, and erasers. Students will learn how to keep their materials organized by being responsible for their individual chair sacks. Each day in our classroom we transition between multiple different subjects including phonics, reading, writing and math. Students will be able to make this transition much more smoothly with all of their materials conveniently located on the back of their chair in one of these chair sacks. Transitions take up a lot of time in any elementary classroom. I am hoping to minimize transition time in my classroom with these chair sacks. Shorter transitions means more time actually spent learning. Every minute for my students is precious and the more minutes we can spend learning rather than transitioning will greatly increase their achievement. Donating to this project will make a huge difference in my classroom by saving transition time and helping my students become more organized and self sufficient. With these chair sacks we will be able to focus more time on learning rather than organization and transitions because these chair sacks will make organization easier for my students. My students will be able to organize their own supplies which is a skill they will use throughout their lives.
needStatement: My students need to be able to organize all materials at their seat with Buddy Pocket Charts in order to maximize the learning time.

name: Sprout Into Reading
description: Our class serves inner city students with a range of disabilities, which include: specific learning disabilities, emotional behavioral disabilities, autism spectrum disorders, other health disabilities, developmental cognitive disabilities, and developmental delay. The typical student in my class struggles with basic reading skills, phonics, number sense, writing, language, social skills, and self regulation. Our classroom budget to spend on materials for my students this year was $80. Our students could benefit from new technology in our room to help engage the diverse learning needs of each student we work with. One area my special education students struggle the most in is reading. Students in my classroom are typically performing two grade levels or more behind their grade level peers. This can cause a great deal of frustration and embarrassment in the classroom. When students come to my room we practice working on phonics, sight words, and reading comprehension. With the use of Headsprout my students can engage in an online and mobile reading program that focuses on the critical reading foundation skills and comprehension strategies needed to be successful in the classroom. This reading program allows my students to work at their individual level and pace. Using this reading program will help my students to practice their 21st century skills while improving their reading skills.
needStatement: My students need a subscription to Headsprout for access to highly engaging, technology based programs to help increase their reading skills.

name: We LOVE Brian P. Cleary
description: I work with a bright, high-energy group of third graders. These kids are from the North Woods and love the outdoors, especially the lakes, rivers, and forests that surround us. My classroom consists of approximately 30% Native American students. Our district motto is to ACHIEVE, and my class does that daily through academics, character, and behavior. I am continually impressed at how motivated my students are when it comes to their learning. They are always up for a good challenge! High-interest books are an important piece of the literacy puzzle. Brian P. Cleary's books have a way of hooking a reader and making them want more. That's why our classroom would love more Brian P. Cleary books. The titles we already have are constantly flying off the shelf! Any time we can get a child interested in a book, it is a win! The titles we don't have in our classroom library are mostly science themed or themed around the food groups. Not only will these books help my students improve their reading skills, but they will have the opportunity to learn about life science, math, and health.
needStatement: My students need grammar, math, and science books by Brian P. Cleary.

name: Novels Needed to Expand Horizons
description: Our school is composed of students that come from a community that often struggles to make it. They are amazing kids and families that deserve the best! They work hard and have great attitudes! They need extra support physically and financially to help them be successful. One hundred percent of our students receive free breakfast and lunch. Their lack of resources does not stop their drive to learn. They are motivated kids that once they have the proper tools their success is endless. My 3rd grade classroom loves to read. They are at an age where their imaginations run wild and they can fall into a book and become a part of it within the first few pages. Reading takes them to new places and exposes them to different times and cultures. Our students come from a low poverty community and go without in many things in their lives. I would love to provide them with a classic award winning books that is coming out as a movie next year! 'A Wrinkle in Time', is a classic I remember reading when I was their age, and it will let their imagination run wild. Not only will this provide them with a wealth of knowledge, it will also help them become better writers and learn from other Authors. Reading is power and providing new titles means the world to them. These books will make a big difference for our classroom and will light up their passion to read. We will be using the items in collaborative centers during our Reader's workshop and Writer's workshop daily. Reading truly is a dream with open eyes. It allows our students to have experiences they may never have in their real lives. Please help us provide new resources for our classroom. Thank you for your time!
needStatement: My students need 20 copies of the book 'A Wrinkle in Time' by Madeline L'Engle to continue to expand our love of reading.

name: Help Children See the Fun in Learning
description: My ninth and tenth graders attend a campus high school comprised of four other high schools. These students travel from Brownsville, East New York and as far as Queens to attend our school. Placed in a self-contained classroom where they learn Global Studies, Living Environment and English, these young minds are energetic, curious, and helpful. Everyday they are excited to learn new concepts and skills despite their learning and/or physical disabilities. My observant group of students love the opportunities awarded in and outside the classroom and are a pleasure to teach. This visit will change my students' lives because many of them have been waiting for years to receive eye care. The activities the visitor will take my students through will teach them about:-structure of the eyes-importance of eye exams (annual)-ailments that occur to the eye over time-importance of glasses on eyesight The parents of my students will learn a lot as well. First they will read about the program and learn about the importance of eye exams. Next, parents and students will have opportunities to sit and discuss their health history in regards to eye sight. Students will get to interview family members to determine eye sight trends within their own families.
needStatement: My students need your support to get eye care and glasses to make learning fun again. Their biggest complaint is that they can not see the words on the board or the paper.

name: We Are Wiggly and Need to Practice for Special Games!
description: Our room is a classroom for students with severe disabilities and although it is a room of non verbal children, they sure can make a lot of noise and have fun! They enjoy taking walks around the campus, cooking up new recipes and exploring the world through multi sensory activities. It's not the diagnosis that makes these students special; it's their heart and personality that really makes them special. Everyday my students make gains toward being more independent and I love celebrating every milestone. Every year my class is invited to participate in the local Kiwanis Special Games event. It is an exciting event! All of the area schools come together to play. But before my class can get there, they need to practice their sports skills. My students will learn how to play adapted soccer, basketball and bowling with the sports equipment. To help my students maintain attention and stay calm, we use a lot of sensory toys. My students will learn to follow instructions, wait in line, and self soothe themselves. Slinky toys, pop tubes and sensory balls give the students something to fidget with while standing in line to participate in Special Games activities and most importantly, help them cope when they are upset. Please help the wiggly students train for Special Games!
needStatement: My students need sports equipment to practice for Special Games events. We will use the slinky toys, pop tubes and sensory balls to meet sensory needs of wiggly students.

name: Sports for Recess!
description: My scholars consist of a wide range of personalities that all have one thing in common, the eagerness to grow as scholars. With your support of my project, I will be able to provide my scholars with resources for success. I want to set my 5th graders on a path for college readiness. My scholars are growing up in a low-income area that does not predict their educational trajectory. They will work hard to get smart, have fun, and will be college ready. I have a class of twenty-five, brilliant scholars! They are researchers, mathematicians, scientists, authors, historians, etc. My students are the future of Dallas and members of our future society. Every day, they come into my classroom excited to learn and ready to take on the challenges I have set up for them. These youngsters deserve the absolute best education they can get, and they deserve to be supported in every way possible in their most important year of their educational career. My 5th graders are very active, which is a great thing. However, they say how bored they are at recess because I do not have sporting equipment for them and their peers to play with. They want to stay active and healthy. Getting them to move at recess is hard when they don't have the right equipment. Having these sporting items, I believe, will help my students to play together and learn about sportsmanship, all the while not being so bored at recess. I want to give them the opportunity to explore more sports other than just soccer. I have added a couple of Frisbee, putting machine and putter, flag football, kickball, whiffle ball, and cornhole. With so many options my 5th graders will have no choice but to stay active. The fitbit watch will allow them track their activity and movement and see which sport keeps them the most active!
needStatement: My students need additional playground recess sporting equipment to help expand their curiosity and interest in other sports.

name: Beanbag Blitz
description: My school is one of the largest elementary schools in Greenville County. It is a Title I school, and over 90 percent of the population is high poverty. The students come from diverse backgrounds. I teach the ESOL inclusion class. Half of my students speak English as their second language. Several of my students have learning disabilities. Despite all of these challenges, this class strives to learn from each other. Project-based learning benefits my classroom because it is student led and very engaging. My students often come to the front of the room to take notes and learn in a small group. They need a place that is inviting for them to comfortably sit. These beanbags will allow to feel that coming to small group learning is an honor not a punishment. I have recently modeled my classroom after the flexible seating trend. The students have thoroughly enjoyed the wobble seats and butterfly chairs. These beanbags will complete my new classroom design. The students are able to collaborate easily with this new style of learning. The kids are always eager to receive new seating options.
needStatement: My students need comfortable beanbag chairs so they can come to the front of the classroom to learn independently or in a small group.

name: Life on the Oregon Trail
description: I once asked my students, 'What do you deserve?' After providing standard kid answers: video games, dessert every night, better food in the cafeteria, I clarified my question, 'No, not what do you want? But what do you deserve... as a human being?' The tone in the room changed immediately. Students grew quiet, reflective, thoughtful. As they patiently listened to each other, I was floored by their answers. One of my girls told our community she deserved a dad that was at home with her, not in prison. One boy said he deserved a quiet place to read at home. Another said he deserved neighbors who did not play loud music in the apartment next door so late at night. Another girl told us she missed an uncle who could not attend family events, reason unknown. These are my students, racially diverse, from a low socio-economic background, urban, creative, engaged and endlessly growing. Our school is 100% free and reduced price lunch. We are isolated in a distant pocket of our city and we are a community who is proud to support one another. The Oregon Trail Overnight field trip is amazing opportunity for our students: bonding, community, learning about an important part of Oregon's history and getting out into nature. Upon arrival, students are whisked back into life in the 1840s on the Oregon Trail. In teams, they role play different aspects of life on the trail. Some of the activities students participate in are making candles, twisting rope, and taking a nature hike. They also get to explore tools, build a log cabin, pack a wagon, knead bread and churn butter. For many of our students, this is truly a once in a life time experience. In addition to the Oregon Trail activities, students also bond as a community. They cook their dinner together outside on handmade stoves, participate in a campfire and dance the Virginia Reel. Seeing the smiles and laughter that emerge from this experience makes this trip more than worthwhile. The memories and learning generated from this 2 day adventure are sure to last a lifetime.
needStatement: My students need funding to allow them to participate in the Oregon Trail Overnight Field Trip.

name: Shin Guards for Soccer Players!
description: The students athletes in my program are quite unique as over 80% are immigrants. They arrive with passion and energy to demonstrate their excellence in soccer. These student athletes respond to the high expectations we set for conduct, commitment, and community as we volunteer throughout the year running summer camps and helping in local youth recreation leagues. With the right support, we can level the playing field between the affluent communities we compete against, and the complex challenges my student athletes struggle to overcome. Students gain critical self identify qualities when the participate in extra curricular activities. Sports, specifically high school sports, provide opportunities to learn team work, commitment, and sportsmanship. Each player in our program has the opportunity to represent their school and community in a positive way. Not only do student athletes learn critical skills through sports, they perform better in the classroom. My students need the right equipment (shin guards) to play high school soccer. Your donation will give a student athlete the opportunity to participate by providing required equipment that many will not have the money to purchase. The opportunity to play means that these student athletes can demonstrate their excellence and passion for soccer.
needStatement: My students need the right equipment (shin guards) to play high school soccer.

name: Wobble Wobble Your Way to Learning!
description: My students are hungry for learning but are so fidgety that can't stay still to learn. The students attend a school where 98% of the students live in poverty.I teach a self-contained class with different leaning styles and interests. I teach a wide variety of students from ADHD, Autistic, learning disabilities to speech impairment to English Language Learners. Our school try to provide our students with resources they need to stay focus and learn. However, the public schools funding is extremely limited and can't provide my student with flexible seating so they can move, wiggle and giggle while they learn. These flexible chairs will be a life saver for my students. The wobble chairs have been researched, well thought out and designed for kids that can't stay still. My students are up and moving around because they can't sit still on the traditional chairs. With your help we can help these students that are hungry to learn but their little bodies can't control themselves. Providing these chairs the kids can get the most out of the learning experience. Flexible seating options will positively impact the emotional, social, and academic needs of my students. For example, instead of our current chairs, students will have the opportunity to use the wobble chairs for help get out their fidgets.
needStatement: My students need 6 wobble chairs in order to focus in reading and writing.

name: We Need Diverse Books for First Graders Too
description: My students are a very diverse, multi-lingual group of children. Portugese, Spanish, Japanese, Dutch and French are all spoken in our classroom. We are diverse in religion, ethnicity and socio-economic background as well. Many of my students are first generation or second generation immigrants. My students love reading and the books they read shape the way they see the world! In first grade children discover what it is to truly understand a book, fall in love with a character, go on an adventure or learn about their favorite nonfiction topic. My students are exploring this new world with eagerness and enthusiasm and reading up a storm. Our classroom library needs more diverse books. The books that come in pre-created sets that are delivered to the school overwhelming feature white characters and white families. Some of our books are very old and out of touch with the times. All children should have an opportunity to see themselves represented in the books they read. Children get excited about characters that they feel they can identify with. The added benefit is that their reading levels improve when they are more excited about their books. All children need to see diversity in books to better understand our world. Adding the books I have selected will help me provide a more diverse selection of books for my children when they come to pick out their books for their book bags each week. Thank you for helping build a better world for our kids one step at a time!
needStatement: My students need diverse book choices at their reading level for their classroom library.

name: STEM Learning through 3D Design, Coding, Electronics and Woodworking
description: Our school is in the heart of Uptown, New Orleans but our students come from all over the city - bused in from places far removed, both geographically and economically, from the site of our school. Many come from areas still ravaged (and never rebuilt) by the flooding that followed Katrina. 83% of our students qualify for free school lunches, making us among the poorest schools in America. Undeterred, our students received the 3rd highest ACT results statewide, behind two closed-enrollment schools. We also boast a 94% graduation rate, one of the highest in the state, which is no small feat considering 80% of our seniors are enrolled in AP courses. Our students are doing amazing things and leaving adversity in their wakes. They reflect the unsinkable spirit of the city in which they live. It seems whatever challenge we toss their way, they're prepared to answer with pride. Sci High Makerspace is the 21st Century answer to shop class, combining traditional hard skills like woodworking with future-oriented soft skills like computer programming and 3D printing. The class also introduces kids to the numerous stem pathways they can pursue at Sci High, including Computer Science, Engineering, BioMedical Sciences, Digital Design and Construction Technologies. In a rigorous, project-basing environment, our kids learn Engineering, Computer Science, Skilled Craft and Computer Aided Design. The 2017 year-end final project is Tabletop Pinball Machines, combining all skills acquired in previous units. Kids are going to design their own pinball machines and construct them, complete with arduino-driven scoring and 3D modeled and printed ramps, slides, bumpers and more!
needStatement: My students need materials to build table top pinball machines. This is their culminating Makerspace year-end final project.

name: Help Us Not Be Hungry
description: My students all attend a Title I school, which means almost seventy percent receive free or reduced-price lunches and breakfasts. They attend a magnet school, which requires most students to maintain a B average throughout the year. The students are part of Pre-Med, Engineering, Environmental Science, or Computer Technology programs. Our students come from diverse backgrounds of thirty different countries. This makes our school pretty special in so many ways. They all work so hard and are very deserving of this grant. My students are inner city students who have to overcome so many obstacles before they even walk through the doors at school. I hate to see them get here and not be able to focus on anything else because they are hungry. This grant will allow my kids to grab snacks for before and after school if they need it. This way instead of being focused on their growling stomach they can focus on my math lesson. Since we started this at our school I have seen an increase in their grades and actually in their participation in class. This has made a huge difference.
needStatement: My students need lentil snacks, water, health bars, and nuts to help combat there hunger before and after school.

name: Books and Beauty Salon
description: I am lucky enough to teach third grade in the heart of Montana. Our school has a high percentage of families living in poverty. I can easily say that my students are some of the strongest people I have ever met. Many of them have been through more challenges during their short lives than most will face in a lifetime. The fact that my students are able to come to school each day and stay focused on their work is something to be celebrated!The 'Books and Beauty Salon' will allow students to schedule before-school appointments with 'stylists' (staff members). During their appointments, students will receive a new hair style while reading a high-interest book to their stylist. This is an idea that is being used successfully at other schools, and our staff members are eager to get our own salon up and running! Not only will the students be working on their reading skills, but they will be building positive relationships with school staff members as well. We want our students to want to come to school. Attendance and tardiness are both common problems at our school. This project will encourage students to be at school on time, every day. Our students also need to feel good about themselves. Many of our students live in less than ideal conditions. Some don't have the resources available to come to school with their hair done nicely, ever. Our students deserve to have strong, positive self-images.
needStatement: My students need books and hair styling products, so that we can get the 'Books and Beauty Salon' up and running!

name: Flexible Seating for Flexible Minds!
description: My students currently attend a year-round school that loops! This means that we are together for first grade as well as second grade! We are in the middle of second grade and we have grown close having spent many months together in the narrow confines of a crowded classroom, we have grown close, have become a part of each other, and we shall always retain a little of each other. My students are full of life and joy despite unstable homes, mental illness, and having to grow up way quicker than need be. I have an active bunch of children who truly love being at school and being part of the family our community has created. I am looking to try flexible seating in my classroom to fit the needs of my students. My students are very active and would benefit greatly by having options that allow them to move while they work. By offering flexibale seating to my class it would offer student choice and voice in how they choose to learn from day today. Students would be introduced to each choice of flexibale seating with lots of modeling and then have a choice of how they choose to learn that day. Iwant my students to walk into our community and be welcomed by an environment that is open to collaboration, communication, creativity, and critical thinking by creating flexible seating in my classroom.
needStatement: My students need different seating options to allow them to learn at their best.

name: 'Empowering Students through Art and Literacy'
description: To tell a story! Do you remember what it was like when your teacher read a wonderful story to you? Think about all the fun you had drawing, coloring or creating objects that represented your favorite fairytale characters, like a crown or a sword. We are a multi-cultural pre-K classroom. We speak English and/or Spanish. Our families are hard working, poor to middle class citizens, who send their precious children to our school. We love to sing and dance. Our school is a public school in NJ that serves approximately 450, 4 and 5 years old students. We love to read and tell stories about different kinds of animals or fairy tale characters. Our classroom is in need of some art supplies and literacy materials such as paint, letter sponges, Handwriting Without Tears materials, level one reader books, wiki sticks, and craft materials to support our learning of literacy skills and the imagination. The art supplies will encourage the children to express themselves and be creative. A first school experience can be difficult for some children; therefore, these materials will give them an opportunity to bring a story to life. With this in mind, the children will be able to learn to adjust and express themselves better through art. All donations will make a tremendous difference in the lives ofthese children, as well as their families. Giving the children a head start in learning to love school will increase their chances of succeeding in life. Academically, socially, and spiritually, these children and their families will be given a platform to build their future. I am only a servant to these families and with these materials, I will be able to positively motivate and mold the children to learn and succeed.
needStatement: My students need literacy materials such as ABC Wiki stick cards, Wiki sticks, alphabet sponges, Handwriting Without Tears materials, level one reader set, and other craft supplies.

name: Flexible Seating for All
description: My students are growing up in the age where educators need to be attentive to all types of learning styles. 'Fair is not giving everyone the same thing, but rather giving everyone the things they need to be successful.' They crave learning with technology, partner work, and a variety of hands-on activities. My students come from low socio economic backgrouds where most students receive free breakfast and lunch daily. My students are all English Language Learners. My students are eager to learn. Our schools distingushing practice is 'Technology'. I am always looking for ways to integrate technology into all subject areas (STEAM- Science, technology, engineering, art, and math). I believe that keeping students engaged in learning is the key to success!Our classroom environments should be conducive to open collaboration, communication, creativity, and critical thinking. This simply cannot be done when kids are sitting in rows of desks all day! Flexible classroom seating invites collaboration, communication, creativity, and critical thinking by helping students manage their physical energy and comfort as they learn on their own terms. Alternative seating can improve student focus, increase student participation, and motivate my learners. This type of classroom seating encourages kids to learn and practice healthy posture while benefiting from active sitting. Studies show it will help increase focus because physical activity is linked to higher academic performance, better health, and improved behavior. When students can choose the type of seat they can best focus in, during that particular task, their attention to the lesson at hand increases. Some students prefer to stand, especially after lunch. Others prefer to work at an independent lap desk on the floor. Many students have 'wiggles' and need to keep moving during lessons, without making noise or bothering others. Some of my students have a physical need to move, I can offer the students many options with these requested Bouncy Bands for Chairs, plastic stack stools and Stay in Play Balance Balls. Choice can help my students become more self-aware of what types of seating and environment helps them learn best, and they're empowered by the opportunity to have choices. My eager students are mostly English Language Learners from homes where love abounds, but money is for basics, not extras. We need to practice our communication skills all day long, so they will improve. My students need to stay engaged to stay focused on their learning and flexible seating will help student engagement.
needStatement: My students need Bouncy Bands for Chairs, plastic stack stools and Stay in Play Balance Balls.

name: Movement for the Mind!
description: Determined, caring, spunky, accepting, enthusiastic, gentle, fearless. These are just a few words I would use to describe my kindergartners that come bouncing into my room everyday. With smiles on their faces they give me their all! All their triumphs, all their try-agains, all their surprises, all their aha's, all their owies...I get them all and I LOVE it! My students attend a kindergarten center, which houses 15 kindergarten classrooms under one roof. It is AMAZING! With 360, five and six years-olds in one location we have the unique opportunity to adapt our building to meet their specific needs. In my class, I have 23 exceptional students who come from a variety of backgrounds and social experiences. My school district is located in a high poverty area with 58% of our students receiving free or reduced lunch and many qualifying for English as a Second Language support. A number of my students' families struggle to meet essential needs and live far from comfortable lives.57,420 is the number of minutes my kindergarten students spend in my classroom. Considering that they spend more awake time at school than at home, I want to make sure our space is comfortable and inviting for all learners; especially those who come from unstable homes. One way to create an inviting, student-centered classroom is to offer flexible seating to meet the ever diverse needs of my students. The movement provided through wobble chairs and stability balls will allow students to 'get wiggles out' and find a 'just right' seat for their minds to grow and learn. As John Dewey once said, “If we teach today how we taught yesterday, we rob children of tomorrow.” The children that enter my classroom have different needs than those 30 years ago so I want my classroom to reflect that change.
needStatement: My students need seating that allows for movement and flexibility so their minds can grow. My students need wobble stools and balance balls.

name: Boogie Board Jot Memo Pads Make Everything Easier!
description: I am a teacher at a Title I school in an under-served community in the South Bronx. The children in my class love to learn new things and are working very hard. My class is self-contained and consists of students in grades K, 1 and 2. They all learn differently and all need extra support throughout the day. Most of my students are visual and multi sensory learners. My students are enthusiastic about learning and enjoy the arts and technology very much. I encourage my students daily to try their best at whatever they do because that is what is most important during their learning. I am extremely proud of my students and all that they have accomplished thus far. I have had students who started with me as non-readers and now have moved up three reading levels. I will continue to work hard to push my students to their fullest potential because I believe that anything is possible no matter what the circumstances. However, my class is in need of boogie board ereaders to use to develop their phonemic awareness skills during phonics. My students will benefit from these jot memo pads because it will eliminate the need to replace dry erase markers. My students use dry erase boards daily during phonics, writing and mathematics. With continued use we constantly need to purchase new dry erase markers. If my students had these Memo pads they wouldn't need to use the dry erase markers and boards. This memo pad will assist them when they are in need of writing and erasing easily. They can practice their phonics skills with the use of this board. The clicker will be used by myself to help with instruction via the interactive white board and the laptop. There is a program available which assists with the noise level in the classroom and it does require the use of a clicker. By using the clicker discreetly students will recognize when the noise level has gone to the point of being a disruption to others. They will then be reminded to use indoor voices.
needStatement: My students need boogie board jot memo pads to practice their phonics skills to better their reading. No more need for dry erase boards if they have these!

name: Help Use Learn About Media Literacy Through Exciting Graphic Novels!
description: In a city known for its challenges, my primary goal is to provide my students with a safe and rigorous environment where they can take the many skills taught within the classroom to a successful future ahead! I teach a group of thirty-four fourth-grade students with a combination of various special needs students mainstreamed within. My students are a very energetic, inquisitive and highly motivated group! They absolutely love to learn new information in a tactile and hands-on way! One thing that sets my group of students apart is their motivation and drive to make this world a better place! They strive for change and to make a positive impact on society! At such a young age, they are already able to describe how their future actions will affect those around them! With such a positive outlook on their future, it is my duty to provide my students with enriching activities that will make them productive future scholars in society! Through the help of DonorsChoose.org, I am able to provide more learning opportunities for my students through the use of materials that are not easily accessible in public education. My students are in need of new Non-Fiction books in order to learn about Important Events, Historical People from History, and Media Literacy. They are also in need of Comprehension Cubes and an Assessment Activity in order to develop their Reading Comprehension. These resources will help develop Reading Comprehension for my students at all academic levels, as it is relevant, and exciting to read in Graphic Novel formats! Through a collection of books, such as 'Who is King Tut, Johnny Appleseed, Mark Twain and Anne Frank,' my students will be able to become inspired by many Historical Figures in History! These books are written at a higher level for Advanced Learners, but also have many graphics to meet the needs of Struggling Readers. The graphics will help promote reading and Media Literacy at all academic levels within the classroom! These books will also excite my students, as they have already read all of our classroom library books! The Comprehension Cubes will be used to help my students with their Comprehension of the books. By using cubes and being able to roll them, students will be excited about discussing the book they just read. The Assessment Cards will be used as a final step to assess student overall understanding!
needStatement: My students need non-fiction books, comprehension cubes, and assessment cards in order to learn about media literacy.

name: Moving & Learning
description: Pre-K for All is a new program within the New York City Department of Education that provides all four year olds with full day quality education. Pre-K for All gives children stronger reading and math skills. My site is a Pre-K Center exclusively dedicated to pre-k students. We are located in Brooklyn and have a diverse population. We have a center based learning model. The students learn by engaging in purposeful play while teachers engage the students in meaningful conversations. In my program we like to provide lessons that are interactive so the children can learn by doing. Each day we have sixty minutes of movement. Some days we do yoga, aerobics, traditional games such as duck duck goose or parachute play. Other days we do a center based model where children select which gym equipment they want to use and rotate accordingly. We have a large indoor play space and limited gym equipment. The gym equipment I selected also allows for learning while moving. It reinforces letters and numbers. The equipment helps develop fine and gross motor skills. The activities will help promote social growth and development as well. We need new gym equipment to keep us moving and learning.
needStatement: My students need gym equipment to use during their movement period. We need a ring toss, alphabet bowling and let's get moving mats.

name: Scholars and School Supplies, The Perfect Match
description: As a para-educator teaching at a school that is located in a low income, extremely high crime and poverty area school district, I only want the very best for my Amazing Scholars. Our scholars and their families are struggling just to make ends meet. Sometimes their rents are past due, they are constantly in need of the basic necessities, such as food and clothing, therefore, our scholars even come to school without having pencils, notebooks, crayons, backpacks,etc.A kid cannot learn without having the basic school supplies. Living in poverty is tough enough and then having to borrow supplies from others, sometimes makes it worse for our scholars. Research clearly shows that a proper education can help children to overcome poverty, especially if they have the basic tools that are necessary to help them succeed in school. Can you imagine, children having to show up on the very first day of school without supplies or a used and dingy backpack, that has probably been already put through the test of time? Unfortunately this happens too often and no child deserves this kind of humiliation, especially when it can be so easily avoided. Having necessary supplies such as colored pencils, pencil sharpeners, crayons, composition notebooks, folders and glue sticks and new backpacks can be an icebreaker amongst students, allowing a chance to express themselves and gain confidence. I just want my Scholars to have the vital tools needed to flourish successfully inside and outside of the classroom.
needStatement: My students need backpacks, pencils, colored pencils, pencil sharpeners, crayons, composition notebooks, folders and glue sticks to have the tools needed for a successful upcoming school year.

name: Fluttering First Grade Learners!
description: I truly love my job because of my fun, energetic, and loving students! I work in a high poverty neighborhood, and we are an EL magnet school. We have students from over 20 countries represented, and we receive students that are brand new to the country. I have many New Americans that come to my classroom that speak no English. It is such a delight to watch them grow and learn. I believe in every one of my students. They strive to do their best every day. They come to school each day ready to learn, make friends, and have fun! Having such a unique variety of students makes my job so rewarding and challenges me to be the very best I can be! I strive to create an environment that is warm, friendly, and safe. My students trust me. My students are empowering; I want to give them the best chance to succeed!I want to allow my students flexible seating choices in my first grade classroom. With a wide diversity of learners in my classroom, I believe this will be a powerful way to help all my students be successful. I would like to no longer have my students just use desks and chairs. My little learners need to move! I believe using the wobble chairs, rug, balance balls, and stools I have in my project will allow my students to keep their bodies comfortable while working independently and whole group as well as maintaining their stamina their brains need while thinking and learning! Flexible classrooms give students a choice in what kind of learning space works best for them, and helps them to work collaboratively. I spend numerous hours preparing lessons to meet all the diverse needs in my classroom, and I would love to allow my students to be able to choose a flexible setting to succeed to their fullest potential. Students will do their very best in a space where they are comfortable and confident. I love learning from my students, and they make me smile on a daily basis! It is an incredible feeling! I would love to be able to make my classroom a place where students have a choice. Thanks in advance for helping me update my learning environment for some great young minds and amazing kiddos.
needStatement: My students need flexible seating options in our classroom to improve their stamina and focus!

name: We Are Writers!
description: My PreK scholars are amazing! The are the only full day class in our school. They are eager to learn and love being in school. Our school is very diverse and takes pride in welcoming and engaging all scholars and families. We are committed to creating a school where kids feel safe, loved, and motivated.
