As a school, we take pride in creating an environment where we celebrate diversity, discuss and study racial equity, and 'inspire all scholars to reach high levels of social and academic achievement and to become future leaders through a collaborative system of support' (our School's Mission Statement).My Prek scholars are writers. They enjoy writing their name and names of their peers and teachers. They enjoy writing words and letters from our word wall. It is so fun to see them use their knowledge of letters and sounds to spell out words on their own. They like to draw pictures and add words/letters to their pictures. Having a new writing center will encourage all scholars to visit the writing center and build on their writing skills. I know my scholars will feel motivated to write and will feel like writers in their new writing station. The Lakeshore Writing Center is not just a piece of furniture, it is a new, inviting space that will allow my scholars to create, explore, and strengthen skills. I'm so excited to have this for my scholars!
needStatement: My students need a new, inviting, and organized writing center to explore and strengthen their writing skills.

name: Pre-K Loves Hands On Science Activities!
description: My Pre-K scholars are amazing! The are the only full day class in our school. They are eager to learn and love being in school. Our school is very diverse and takes pride in welcoming and engaging all scholars and families. We are committed to creating a school where kids feel safe, loved, and motivated. As a school, we take pride in creating an environment where we celebrate diversity, discuss and study racial equity, and 'inspire all scholars to reach high levels of social and academic achievement and to become future leaders through a collaborative system of support' (Our School's Mission Statement).My scholars will have a whole new set of science materials! Children learn so much from hands on and engaging science activities. Each of these materials will allow my scholars to explore science in a variety of ways. In Pre-k, one of our areas of study is cycles and I can't wait to have hands on materials to help teach about cycles in our world. The Life Cycle theme box and Life Cycle Sequencing kit will be a perfect hands on model. Also, the Growing Things theme box will allow my scholars to plant seeds and watch them grow. We look forward to these and other new materials to help us learn more about science. My hope is to get my scholars excited about science. I want my scholars to have fun and enjoy making connections about the world around them.
needStatement: My students need new science materials to support learning and create a fun, engaging science center!

name: Second Grade Library
description: Our second grade students work very hard all year on a variety of projects in all subject areas. They do several science projects as well as an integrated writing history project. They do an amazing job being resourceful even when they have to share. Often with few books to research we end up researching on the few classroom devices to share, which is often not grade level reading level. We think they deserve a variety of leveled nonfiction books they study as well as more read aloud choices relating to the content. Teachers check books out from the public library for read aloud as well. Students will be able to research at reading levels they can access for all research projects and enjoy read-alouds related to grade level topics to support a rich literacy foundation. They will also have more variety of independent reading choices. We also would like some sturdier bins to keep them organized attractively for students. Overall, a variety of print resources can benefit our entire grade level in several areas, including research, read aloud related to all content areas, and more independent reading choices.
needStatement: My students need a grade level library of nonfiction books to research in as well as read aloud and independent reading fiction options.

name: A Spaghetti Bridge
description: When the school day begins at our school, you'll find students and staff from diverse cultural backgrounds sharing a common goal. They share the desire to discuss, explore, investigate and learn. It is a world designed for student-centered learning and a place where innovative programs and hands-on methods encourage curiosity and discovery. You will hear students and teachers having real conversations about their lives, beyond tests and homework. Each of our 450 students is known and respected, and exclusive cliques scarcely exist.I want my students to explore the field of engineering by making bridges using spaghetti as their primary building material. Then they test their bridges to see how much weight they can carry before breaking. We need spaghetti noodles, strings, and hot glue guns. This project will give students the opportunity to take math and science out of the textbook and into a project involving design, planning, and construction. Because the process is instructive and fun, and it exemplifies the difficulties of putting theory into practice. Of course, students can build a bridge without math and science. However, if they want to build one that can carry a maximum load, then they need to understand the material properties of spaghetti, the theory of beams, and the physics of canceling forces (statics).
needStatement: My students need hot glue guns, spaghetti and strings to build spaghetti bridges.

name: Being Flexible in Our Room!
description: This classroom serves Special Education students with emotional disabilities with two co-teachers. Students in this classroom not only work on academics, but also spend a large portion of the day working on social skills and managing their emotions. Since we spend most of our day together we have become a close knit community. We have celebrated Friendsgiving, gone ice skating as a class, and get very competitive in classroom Uno. One thing about this classroom is that due to high needs, we are very flexible. Sometimes students need to get up and move around, tap their pencil, or go for a walk to take a break. We are very supportive of healthy coping strategies! Sometimes this can be as simple as changing their seat. Right now, our students' options are either a desk or on the floor. We would like to purchase some more flexible seating for our classroom. This would include two bean bags, three wobbly stools, 2 foot bands to keep their feet moving, and a lap desk that let these kids move while still sitting in their seats. Our budget is not enough to fill this need so any help would be greatly appreciated!Don't we all need to be a little more flexible sometimes? Our students are always on the move, and often need their personal space when working in the classroom. These different seats will allow them to spread out in the classroom and get their work done! Providing these students with a variety of seats will give them the chance to make a choice for themselves which is often very important to them. Having seats that they are still able to move around in or spread out their work will be a much better alternative than them laying on the floor!
needStatement: My students need a variety of seats to have in our classroom such as wobble chairs, bean bags, bouncy bands and lap desks!

name: Let's Impact Our Learning at Home
description: My students build a love of learning in kindergarten! They love to bring their learning home and show their parents what they know. 'Tell me and I forget. Teach me and I remember. Involve me and I learn.' -Benjamin Franklin My students learn through enriching games and engaging activities! They come to school every day full of joy, energy, and love. As a Title I school, more than 80% of my students qualify for free or reduced priced lunch. We start every morning with breakfast in the classroom, preparing our bodies and minds for a busy day learning through play. Because many of my students are labeled as 'at-risk' of not graduating, we make the most out of every moment we have together, making sure every activity planned is pushing them towards success. Many of my kids have never been to school before kindergarten, and I try hard to make it a fun environment, creating memorable experiences, so they fall in love with school and learning. My favorite parts of teaching are reading aloud amazing books and playing partner games! I try to include a read aloud in every subject multiple times a week, and we play lots of games in the classroom to build reading and math skills! To continue the fun at home, I print games monthly to send home for them to play with family. I believe these games are more appropriate than homework and contribute to quality family time. Many of my students ask to take home supplies from our classroom to complete their homework and games that I have sent home, such as crayons and dice. I would like to create a 'Kindergarten Success Packet' to share with parents at our beginning of the year Parent Night. This packet will include an alphabet picture book for students to begin building a home library, as well as sight word flash cards, printed alphabet, and math games, and the basic supplies they need to play each game. The dry erase sleeves, expo markers, dice, and game counters will allow students to play their favorite games repeatedly. Each month I would like to create a video for parents with information about what we are learning at school and introduce a new set of games, and a new picture book to add to their growing collection. With this project, I envision families gathered around the table, playing math racing games and CVC reading games; students and parents are building a bedtime routine that includes important family bonding time and a bedtime story. It is my dream these games and books give my children a head start at school success, and show them reading and math are not just for the classroom, but also for home and for life.
needStatement: My students need alphabet books, crayons, glue, dice, math manipulatives, and storage materials to create a success packet to practice their skills at home.

name: Color our PreK World!
description: Imagine your Kindergarten classroom for a moment. When you step into my classroom it is a welcoming and happy place, but lacks all basic materials. I work in a Title I school where 100% of my students qualify for the free or reduced price lunch program. Despite their disadvantaged backgrounds, these students are enthusiastic about learning. My school is in session from September-June and services very socioeconomically disadvantaged students. My students are eager learners who are always striving to do the best they can despite the limited resources, materials and support from home. If we had colored toner for our printer in our classroom, the possibilities would be endless! There are so many educational games and activities that could help encourage and motivate my students, including my PreK students with special needs, that need to be printed in color. We would be able to print leveled reading books for the kids to take home and read with their parents. My students who struggle with vocabulary could use colored vocabulary cards to help them learn what things around them are and what they actually look like in color. Lower readers, who really don't enjoy reading, may fall in love with it if they could look at a book in color and take it home and read with their families. The possibilities are endless, and the benefits we would reap are infinite! This project would benefit all of my students. It would help make learning exciting and engaging all while making it individualized. I think the colored toner would continue to inspire my students and promote their passion for learning. My students deserve the chance to learn, think, and create in a 21st century way. Please help us become 21st century learners by putting color technology in our classroom!
needStatement: My students need printer ink to color their PreK world with colorful experiences.

name: Simply Put...We Need Dictionaries!
description: My students come from different backgrounds. A lot of them are new to the country. I strive to differentiate and incorporate a lot of engaging, hands-on activities that help vocabulary development and ensure that each student is met on his/her own level. What you could expect from my classroom: noise (all kids are noisy), high energy, lots of higher order thinking questions, and a lot of laughter. My students strive for their best, they want to prepare themselves for high school and college. They strive to meet and exceed the expectations of state standards. By helping my students and my classroom, you are taking a step to ensure the future for younger generations. My scholars do a variety of guided reading and literacy-based projects that require a dictionary. Right now we have a handful of dictionaries (around 5) or so that we share. Towards the end of the year, we read books and each student could benefit from having their own dictionary to use. Even though a dictionary seems like a fundamentally basic item, we are in desperate need of a class set. We are reading Charlotte's Web and Chronicles of Naria and my scholars are needing to look up words by themselves, individually. With having only a handful of dictionaries to use, sharing is becoming impossibly difficult and time-consuming. Thank you
needStatement: My students need 31 dictionaries. Simple as that. We only have a handful of dictionaries right now, and students cannot complete their tasks with only 5. A class set would be wonderful!

name: Bring the COW (Cart on wheels)!
description: I am a Pre-Algebra and Algebra 1 teacher and will be teaching all 8th graders that have various learning abilities. My students are from a small community that is very family oriented. A lot of students that were born in the area will continue to live in the area beyond graduation. My students come from various socioeconomic statuses. Some can afford to get calculators, however, some can not. I do not want any to be at a disadvantage because of their home life. Every student deserves the tools to perform at a high level. The materials that I am requesting will help with the security, preservation, and maintenance of our classroom laptops. We were lucky enough to acquire these computers through generosity and funds allocated by the school. These computers will be vital for them as classroom lessons, videos, worksheets, and testing are moving toward the digital world. It will allow students to maintain tools that they are allowed to use in the classroom. It helps with showing students responsibility and taking care of items that they use. If they understand how taking care of things preserve those things, they are more likely to take care of items that are useful in the rest of their education and in their personal lives.
needStatement: My students need this laptop cart to protect and preserve their laptops! Currently, they are just stacked on tables and cords are all over the place. This will make for easy storage and charging!

name: Math Skills Practice + iPads = Success!
description: Our school mission is to build a respectful, successful learning community through art-centered and technology-enhanced practices that develop intelligent behaviors in all students. Our elementary school is a creative arts magnet school in an urban district that uses interdisciplinary teaching and daily arts instruction to positively affect all students in the school through hands-on, interactive learning experiences. In our overall school population, 81% of our students qualify for free/reduced lunch. Our 5th grade classroom has students from diverse backgrounds and experiences who are bused to our school from all over the city. The students are highly motivated to learn but they have a wide range of learning needs. In our classroom, we have 30 students of which 41 % are English language learners from El Salvador, Mexico, Ethiopia, Somalia, Myanmar, and Vietnam. Additionally, 6% of the students have IEP’s (individualized educational plans) because of identified learning difficulties. My school has many diverse learners and interactive learning with a whiteboard system will help all students achieve success. Our district has made a commitment to using iPad technology to provide student-centered learning opportunities as well as increasing student engagement. Each student in our class will be using an iPad to gather, process and communicate information. In order to maximize the use of technology within the math curriculum, my students need additional resources to use with our iPads. Specifically, my math students would benefit greatly from a classroom license to use the Sumdog app for math skills practice. My students love having choice and competition, and Sumdog allows them to choose math practice activities that are individualized for their ability levels in a competitive game format. This app also has a teacher component that will allow me to monitor student activities and chart their individual progress in their skill level. By donating to our classroom you will make a huge difference in these students' lives.
needStatement: My students need a year’s subscription to the Sumdog iPad app that provides math practice games individualized for each student’s ability level.

name: Wobble Out Our Wiggles
description: We are an eager class of 22 students! We love to learn and especially love reading! Our students come from a variety of diverse backgrounds, but our elementary school acts as an all-inclusive family to meet the social and academic needs of our learners. Over 60 percent of our scholars are English Language Learners and over 95 percent of students identify themselves as African American, Asian American, or Hispanic. Over 90 percent of our students qualify for the USDA's Free and Reduced Price School Meals program, meaning that over 250 of our approximately 277 students come from families whose incomes are below the poverty level. Learning for first grade is full of movement! These wobble stools will give my students a chance to move during learning! When students sit in one spot too long it can become too much! Incorporating movement into learning is a way to keep students focused on the task at hand. Our classroom currently has two wobble stools and they cannot get enough of them! Bringing four more stools into our classroom will complete our small group area. During small groups is when student's receive targeted instruction, these wobble stools will be used during that time to help students stay focused during the most critical instruction of the day.
needStatement: My students need a chance to move around while learning! We love to tip and wobble to get our wiggles out, so these wobble stools are a perfect addition to our classroom!

name: Donate Soccer Cleats for Immigrant Students New to the Country
description: The students athletes in my program are quite unique as over 80% are immigrants. They arrive with passion and energy to demonstrate their excellence in soccer. These student athletes respond to the high expectations we set for conduct, commitment, and community as we volunteer throughout the year running summer camps and helping in local youth recreation leagues. With the right support, we can level the playing field between the affluent communities we compete against and the complex challenges my student athletes struggle to overcome. At our high school in Saint Paul, new arrivals to the country enter our community eager to learn and access the privileges that come with an American education. We offer high school soccer, but have little resources to provide the basic necessities of balls and uniforms. These students want to play high school sports, but don't have simple equipment such as soccer cleats. Every pair of shoes donated means another student becomes a student-athlete. As a student-athlete, these immigrants will have the opportunity to play the game they love and represent the school in our community, as well as connect and develop relationships with peers. In high school sports, student-athletes get the opportunity to develop critical skills like teamwork and interdependence.
needStatement: My students need soccer cleats to play high school soccer this fall.

name: When Nothing Goes Right, Go Left!
description: Inquisitive, caring and balls of energy are three ways I would describe the kids I teach. I teach special needs grades 3-5. Being part of a team of seven teachers, we are on the front lines of teaching these sponges for knowledge. Utilizing research-based and hands-on strategies, auditory and visual learning techniques really tackle each child's unique learning style. Each of my kids are unique in their own way. While one kid may learn with a hands-on approach, another may just need to hear it. Many of my children have dyslexia where they switch numbers or letters backwards. But I also teach children who have ADHD, Autism, development delays or other health impairments. So to reach each and every one of their special personalities, I use centers in my classroom. We also use many positive reinforcers at school - for instance, a point system where they can buy things like teachers chair, small snacks or raffle tickets. They also get rewarded monthly if they reach their behavior goals. Our school is a fun and interactive environment where learning and strengthening our minds is the goal!My students come across opportunities to judge, befriend, accept, get angry, be tolerable, and much more multiple times everyday. I want to have an active learning class in my school to teach tolerance to many different themes. Being a kid with special needs I need to incorporate different kinds of learning opportunities for my students. The emotion stones will be used in our morning meetings where they will identify what emotion they are feeling, why, and different startgies to cope. By talking about their emotions and why they feel this way, my other students learn empathy, how to help friends, tolerance, and honesty. I also asked for a CD program to teach my student students about diffferent experiences they will find out in the community. They will learn how to approach new experiences with tolerance. My Worry Monster will be available to eat any worrier or complaints they have. This is a coping skill to learn to write thing a down and store them in a separate area other than in themselves. Lastly, I will use the book to look up different strategies that I can use to teach tolerance in the classroom.
needStatement: My students need a worry eater monster, emotion stones, a Social Emotional computer program and a strategy book to learn tolerance through active learning.

name: Learning About Ourselves Through Reading
description: When I tell people that I teach middle school, they either look at me like I am crazy or like I'm a saint. That is because people don't know how amazing my students are. I teach in a low income/high-poverty school with a high immigrant population. My students often struggle with language and a lack of resources (such as books) at home. Yet they come every day with a thirst for knowledge. As an 8th grade teacher, the key to keeping students engaged is to relate their learning to their own struggles. It matters to them -- if it is about them. I love teaching English, because there are so many engaging, relatable stories written for and about the teenage experience. But my students won't read books at home if I don't provide them. This project will allow me to send home books with my classes for at home reading practice. Many of my middle school students like to tell me that they don't read. But what if they could see themselves in the characters they read about? What if they could relate to the struggles of the characters on the page? Would they change their minds about the importance of books? I know that if provided with the right books to take home, my students will experience a change in attitude about reading. My goal for my students is for them to develop a reading habit through books which they find relatable, engaging, and appealing. I've picked 3 selections to rotate among my classes for nightly take-home reading. The Maze Runner is a dystopian novel where a boy named Thomas finds himself trapped in the center of a maze with no memory of his previous life. It is a compelling adventure story in which the main character must not only survive, but escape. The Giver is a story about a boy, Jonas, who lives in a society where grief and discord have been eliminated and 'sameness' is a virtue. Jonas struggles as he learns the painful truth of individuality and emotion. Last, A Wrinkle in Time is a classic science fiction novel about a girl named Meg, an awkward teen who struggles in school. She must travel across time and space to save her Father and her younger brother from a dark force trying to take over the universe. All of these selections have teenage protagonists who struggle in some way with survival and navigating through the difficult circumstances of life. Each story inspires the reader to never give up, no matter how difficult the circumstances. When we relate to the characters in stories, we develop empathy for others and insight into ourselves.
needStatement: My students need engaging books to take home for nightly reading.

name: Character Counts! Teaching Tolerance in Kindergarten
description: Our kindergarten program consists of a full day schedule with an emphasis on rigorous academic instruction along with age appropriate activities to encourage personal growth and development. The students come from diverse backgrounds and speak a variety of languages. Every student is valued for their unique strengths, culture, and learning style. Kindergarteners are naturally inquisitive about their world. In our integrated curriculum, science, math, art, and literacy are combined during active learning opportunities to provide experiences that are real and relevant to the students. Our classroom is full of learning opportunities! Kindergarteners learn about themselves and their world through hands on exploration with guidance from teachers in the classroom. With this project I hope to provide opportunities for students to develop tolerance by understanding themselves and those around them. Tolerance is an essential component of character education and a foundation for our classroom beliefs. Students will have the opportunity to build tolerance as they learn to value everyone for their unique gifts! The books, art materials, and dolls will help students to explore similarities and differences in others. The materials will be used during the first six weeks of school, but also incorporated throughout the school year. We will use the books to learn about ourselves and our differences and similarities. The students will use the art materials to show themselves and their uniqueness. The dolls and dollhouse students will provide students with the opportunity to represent themselves through play. All of these materials together will help students understand themselves, their families, and value others as a part of our community!
needStatement: My students need multicultural art materials, books, dollhouse and dolls to help them explore and understand that all people are different and unique.

name: Flexible Seating for Flexible Learning
description: The students that I teach everyday are students who have many obstacles to overcome on a daily basis. Some of them are first generation American citizens, and some of them are immigrants without stable status in this country. Their parents are hard workers, who have multiple jobs to keep afloat, while losing precious parent-child experience time. My students are bilingual, multi-cultural and have to live balanced between two separate worlds. One world is their school and academic life, maintaining their background and culture, while also trying to assimilate and conform to their monolingual peers. The other world is their family life and struggles at home. Trying to distinguish who they are without having to be labeled is a huge stress for them. I am lucky to work with such amazing students, who by no fault of their own, have been thrust into a new civilization, a new beginning, and a new space. They are hard workers, people pleasers, and respectful to every and any adult, teacher, mentor who spends time with them. These soft seats, balance balls, lap trays, and storage crates will help make a difference in my students' learning because it will give them the opportunity to pick which seating environment is better for their learning style. Every student will be engaged, comfortable, and focused. It will help create a classroom environment free from restrictions, and old expectations. Students will be a huge part of the decision making and will quickly learn how to balance their wants to better fit their needs. They will be fostering positive working experiences with all their peers, as well as building trust and respect with their teacher. It will also allow me, the teacher, to walk freely around the room, check in with each student, make observations and allow myself time to connect with each student and learn their learning style.
needStatement: My students need flexible seating and storage for a classroom focused on student achievement and engagement.

name: Help Students Move and Learn!
description: We are a multiage (1st, 2nd and 3rd grade) Montessori classroom. Students are free to work in a carefully prepared, inspiring, and nurturing environment. We have 27 kids, ages 6 to 9, in our classroom community. Our students represent the community of St. Paul. I am fortunate to teach students for 3 years - their 1st, 2nd and 3rd grade year. Students are given the opportunity to take responsibility for their own learning. Each child is an important member of the community who also is responsible for the health and well-being of the community. Older students can be role models for younger kids. I carefully prepare the environment so it is enticing for students. They are encouraged to work independently and together, continually building curiosity and delving deeper into each content area. We are hoping to create some alternative seating options for students in our first, second and third grade classroom. Six-nine-year-olds are full of energy. These seating options (exercise balls, balance boards, wiggle cushions, and stools) will give students an opportunity to move and increase their focus while they work. Brain research shows that movement and cognition are powerfully connected. The same part of the brain that processes movement is the same part that processes learning. It is vital that students have a lot of opportunities for movement throughout the day. These seating and standing options will be available to all students.
needStatement: My students need exercise balls, wiggle cushions, stools, and balance boards.

name: Flexible Seating for First Grade
description: My Elementary school has 460 students in grades K-5, including 16 students in the district's Autism Special Day Classes. The interaction of special needs students included in the larger school population promotes a very positive and unique flavor to our neighborhood school. Our children come from a variety of socio-economic backgrounds. We are a Title 1 School. Seventy-two percent of our families are of Hispanic backgrounds making for a very diverse and unique school experience. I currently have two students receiving social-emotional support with Americorps peer tutoring and a student with an IEP with modifications for hearing impairment. Our need to focus and learn in an environment that invites flexibility is key in my first grade classroom. Flexible seating offers students an opportunity to sit in a place that works best for them to learn. This way students use choice to stay engaged in their learning. This seating choice provides a comfortable alternative to traditional classroom chairs. I have students who rock and sometimes fall out of their traditional classroom chairs (which are mismatched and damaged). My classroom seating is in desperate need of a 21st Century makeover. Our seating needs to match our collaborative student-centered curriculum. Wobble chairs help improve posture and allow wiggly first grade students a chance to move and learn. The Gaiam Kids Balance Ball Chairs also offer the students an opportunity to choose seating that is comfortable for them. These chairs also improve posture, and the frame that holds the balance balls in place are a more stable option for first grade students. Additionally, I have requested more ergonomically friendly chairs, the Contour School Stack Chairs. These chairs are more of a traditional style seat, but with increased comfort for growing children. Any help is appreciated, thank you for stopping by.
needStatement: My students need a choice in their classroom seating. Flexible seating provides students with an opportunity to find comfortable, ergonomic, learning spaces in our 21st-century classroom.

name: Getting Our Speech Game On!
description: Communication is paramount to student success. All of my students have one or more disabilities which adversely affect their ability to communicate their wants and needs, thoughts, and ideas. Though communication is not easy for my students, they have a determination to learn like none other! All of my students have one or more disabilities, ranging from speech sound disorders to autism and down syndrome, which negatively affects their ability to effectively communicate their wants and needs, thoughts, and ideas. They come to speech to work on expressing themselves more effectively, as well as their articulation and language skills. My school is phenomenal and always strives to include our students with special needs in all activities school-wide. Though many of my students come from difficult backgrounds, they have a desire to learn and succeed. Many of my students require visual picture reminders to follow a schedule, use good behavior, and answer comprehension questions about what they have been learning. Some of my students have more severe needs, which hinders them from communicating verbally at all. These students rely on using gestures and pictures to communicate with others. My students all have a burning desire to interact with others and express themselves. New books keep the students engaged in learning. Because my students have disabilities that cause them to struggle with attention, we often play board games in speech as a way for my students to continue to work on vocabulary, practice communicating with others and turn-taking, practice social skills such as how to win and lose graciously, and also for short breaks to help them decompress. The board games chosen for our project were carefully selected to go along with our themes throughout the year, so as to be a continuation of the vocabulary words we are targeting. For example, Pop Up Pirate will be used during our Pirate theme week. We'll decorate our classroom with pirate decor, read pirate books, learn pirate vocabulary, and practice talking like pirates. Then, we have a pirate-themed game for reinforcement of their speech goals! Likewise, the selected books such as Pout Pout Fish and Pierre the Penguin, as well as the game Thin Ice, specifically relate to other themes we will be studying, such as the Arctic and ocean! My school's resources are extremely limited. Budgets for new games and books are non-existent at this time. My students look forward to coming to speech to read books and sometimes play games. What may seem like play time to them, is really a carefully designed social skills lesson or communication opportunity. My lessons change as themes and vocabulary change, and as the students' needs change. It is vital for me to continue to provide activities that keep my students engaged in their learning so they can find a voice that they so desperately want. Every one of my students can be successful if they have the tools they need learn!
needStatement: My students need new books and games for our speech room.

name: Moving While We Work
description: Students come to me with a positive attitude and an eagerness to learn mathematics, but when their learning environment is not adequate to meet their needs it becomes a distraction and a learning disadvantage. By the end of third grade, students are expected to master multiplication and division facts to 100. One of the biggest challenges that I face is getting students to meet grade level expectations without the proper supplies to meet their learning needs. Students don’t come in a cookie cutter shape, they are all individuals from different backgrounds and with different types of learning abilities. Let me introduce you to my classroom! I am a third grade math teacher in a low income school. I teach three math periods throughout the day with ninety minute blocks and sixty students transitioning in and out of my classroom. Some of my students are English Language Learners, special education students, and highly capable and gifted students. Student ability levels range anywhere from intensive, strategic, and benchmark. Approximately 48 percent of the students receive free or reduced lunch. Expecting students to sit still in a chair for a ninety-minute block is a big expectation, especially for eight and nine year olds. This is something that students are expected to do on a daily basis. Something as simple as sitting on a chair becomes an enormous task for students that are already at a disadvantage in their education. Students are all expected to meet grade level expectations, no matter what level they were at in the beginning of third grade. It is up to me, their math teacher, to meet every single students' needs. Students don't come in a one size fits all, and their learning styles most definitely does not. My students need more seating options that fit their needs. I am requesting 2 wobble chairs that allow my students to continuously be moving while they are working. The wobble chairs will help my students stay engaged in their learning during the entire 90 minute math block.
needStatement: My students need 2 wobble chairs as a form of seating in my classroom.

name: Scholastic News for Second Graders!
description: My second graders come to school full of energy! We are an active classroom that loves to learn. We love to write and read. My students would benefit from Scholastic News Magazine. The students would love having the magazines to take home and read to their parents and siblings! My students come from a range of socioeconomic backgrounds. At least one third of my students come from low-income households. We are a suburban school that has students from around the world! My students come from a variety of backgrounds. I have students from around the world that are learning English. I also have many students from low-income households. Many have nothing at home to read. By having Scholastic News the students will be able to read and take home the magazine to share with parents and siblings. Students are excited to read, take home and share what they have read in school. These magazines will reinforce my science and social studies standards in a way that will excite my students! Students LOVE reading these magazines and sharing what they have learned!
needStatement: My students need Scholastic News! They love to read and this will give them reading that they can take home and share.

name: Creating a High Interest Series Library
description: My students are a diverse group of thinkers and learners who come together in the spirit of learning. We are a public, urban Montessori middle school, and as a school that opened four years ago, we are still emerging and growing as a community. We are located in a historically diverse and low income community. About 77% of our students receive free and reduced price lunch. My students come to middle school with an enthusiasm for their education and form a strong community. Our Montessori classroom experience is focused on educating the whole child and creating lifelong learners. My students love reading! While my students come to middle school as readers, my classroom lacks enough high interest books to sustain a year of daily reading. We need updated books in our 6th grade classroom library. We love having books in our classroom, and it would be nice to have some fresh titles, especially series, so students can continue on with characters they have fallen in love with. I would like high-interest, engaging, young-adult series to promote a culture of literacy among my 6th grade students. Specifically, students are always asking to read more books about sports, graphic novels, horror and popular YA titles. Book series are an incredibly useful tool in a middle school classroom, and my students cannot get enough of them. I would like to provide them with as many complete series as I am able, so they can enjoy the story in its entirety. I want to make sure there is enough reading material available to cultivate and sustain a lifelong love of reading and learning for my students.
needStatement: My students need a variety of book series across several genres.

name: Writers in the Making
description: I teach in a Title I school with a large population of Hispanic students. 100% of my students receive free lunches and come from low-income families. My students come to me with little to no English. They are experiencing learning in a public setting for the first time and sometimes come to class without the skills needed for academic success. Since many of my students do not speak English, they need to build up their communication skills and their vocabulary. My students also are building other communication skills through writing. My pre-k students as well as the second pre-k classroom will benefit from the use of these writing journals. The two classrooms have 40 students who will each receive their very own write and draw journals. My school district is facing a $12 million cut in funding to our schools. With these cuts, our school is unable to purchase the writing journals our students need in order to enhance their learning and their writing skills. Each student will use both the two different types of 'My First Journal' books in both as a writing journal and as a science journal for when we do our STEM time with our students. The students will work in their journals each day to record their findings during STEM time and also in practicing their writing skills.
needStatement: My students need two class sets of 40+ my first journals, 40+ draw and write journals and 40+ softcover books.

name: Start Our Second Grade Year With Success!
description: My students live in a high poverty neighborhood, but are all typical second graders. They love to play with their friends, sing, draw, and talk. My students are kind, funny, and smart. We start every day off with breakfast in our classroom, family style. Everyone gets free breakfast through a grant our school received. We sit around our tables eating and talking about what we did last night or what we will do after school. My students love to play, learn, talk, and interact with everyone! They love sharing their writing papers or drawings with the whole class! My school is a Title I school in Missouri. Our school has over 75% of students who receive a free or reduced lunch. The teachers and staff of our school love all our students and only want the best for them. My students need basic supplies to be successful during their second grade year. We will use the notebook paper for basic assignments. The card stock paper will be used to make science projects, cards, and artwork. They will have everything they need when they arrive and feel great about their learning from the start. We will use the graph paper in math to keep our numbers lined up to add correctly. My students use pencil pouches in my classroom to hold their pencils and reward tickets. Having these will ensure everyone has access to one and no one is left out. I will use the expo makers to explain assignments on the board. The students will also use the expo markers to show what they know using small white boards at their seats. Having these supplies at the beginning of the year will really mean a lot to my students. Some of my students walk into my room with literally nothing. Their families cannot afford the expensive school supplies. This will make my students feel successful from day 1.
needStatement: My students need basic school supplies such as paper, expo markers, cap erasers, graph paper, lysol wipes, and pencil pouches.

name: Classroom Carpet Time: A Place to Create! Collaborate! Connect!
description: My students enter our classroom each day full of energy and wonder! Each day I have the amazing opportunity to see twenty smiling faces ready to interact, learn, and become the future leaders of our society. I teach at a Title I School in Alabama, where a vast amount of my students come from low-income family backgrounds with approximately 99 percent of the student population receiving free or reduced lunches. Our school serves approximately 450 students from diverse backgrounds. Most of my students receive governmental assistance for food and housing. Despite so many challenges, my students are eager to learn and do their best. Make a difference and help build an interactive and caring first grade classroom community! Brighten the day of first graders and encourage meaningful interactions through carpet time that will support collaborations, creations, and connections! This carpet will have a lasting impact throughout the school year and in years to come! This valuable classroom resource will help close the communication gap that often occurs with assignments and projects. An educational carpet area will support positive interactions to target social skills and strategies needed to effectively and authentically discuss classroom announcements and complete daily assignments. Interacting with my first graders on the classroom carpet will bridge the communication barriers by supporting natural conversations that promote the understanding of the curriculum while considering students' diverse backgrounds and personal interests.
needStatement: My students need a bright, colorful classroom rug to keep them organized and focused during learning.

name: Color Our World
description: My students are bursting with energy and have a strong desire to grow and learn. The majority of my students are Native American and due to the low socio-economic area we live in, 100 percent of my students receive free breakfast and lunch at school. I am aware of the challenges many of my students face and I make sure that when they walk through my classroom door, they are all given an equal opportunity to learn in a positive, encouraging environment.I've worked hard to create a calming and colorful classroom for my students. We're surrounded by a beautiful array of blues and greens that create a relaxing and safe place to learn. But what about the tools we use? I want my students to have colorful tools so that they can express themselves and continue to grow and learn. One of the best feelings is cracking open the lid of a new maker and watching the juicy color flow onto a fresh piece of paper. By providing these amazing and colorful markers, scissors, folders, and sketchbooks for my students you are giving them the best tools to learn and an awesome start to a new school year.
needStatement: My students need new markers, fresh crayons, bright colored pencils, untouched sketchbooks, gleaming folders, crisp post-it notes, colorful dry erase markers, and turquoise scissors.

name: Sustainability and Recycling Starts Here in Coney Island!
description: What sets our school a apart from other schools is that the students themselves have taken the initiative to collect all the recyclables from each classroom every single day. The students collect 3-4 times per day, which includes after breakfast in the classrooms, pre-K lunches, general classroom collections and after school snack collection. No recyclable is left behind! It is incredible to witness how much pride our students have developed caring for the overall Environmental Concerns our school and the world. In order to expand our reach and continue our push to zero waste at 90, the students are in need of more supplies. We need more gloves because right now our 50 member team has to share and they are very time consuming to clean. The trash grabbers would make the students lives easier during recycling collections and during lunch duty. We are currently borrowing recycling bins and rolling dollies and with the purchase of new bins we can collect more and cut down on the time needed to clear a school of 700 people. Hours collecting will turn into minutes. The other supplies will also be used to make recycling the main focus in our school and community. The most important lesson we have learned is that although the work that we do takes much time and planning, it is all worth it when we see the pride that has developed in our students. The students of the green team have spread their knowledge and joy over recycling to their peers, and there has been a paradigm shift within our school because of these students. Although there are limitations with beginning to implement new protocols in a school, when we see the gratification that recycling brings to our students, it is all worth it. The acquisition of these recycling materials would make a significant difference in our students' learning because they will see that the public cares about our plight. In a community such as Coney Island, which is affected by poverty and pollution, our students have broken the stereotypes that plague our society. Many of our students and their families live in poverty, but that does not stop them from promoting environmentally sustainable practices in school and at home. We want to show just how committed we are to the environment and community wellness. Our students' school lives will be improved because with this donors choose project, we will finally have the correct resources to make our recycling dreams come true. Title I schools have limited funding, but with a little creativity we can acquire all the materials we need as well!
needStatement: My students need affirmation that they truly are changing the world.

name: Painting Our Way to Learning
description: My students are amazingly energetic and eager to learn, but they are a diverse group, with different academic and social/emotional needs. Many are English Language Learners, with little to no exposure to the English language outside of school. They crave learning opportunities that reflect their diversity and teach them the academic and social-emotional skills they so desperately need, in authentic and engaging ways. In my classroom, there are 22 unique, creative, diverse, and brilliant students, each bubbling with potential. However, there are many barriers that get in the way of them achieving what they are capable of doing. My school is a Minnesota Focus school, meaning it is in the lowest ten percent of schools that receive Title I dollars in our state. Many students are English Language Learners with little to no exposure to the English language outside of school. Over 90% of students qualify for free or reduced-price lunch. The student body is very diverse, including African American, Latino, Somali, Asian, Native American, and white students. Our school has a high population of homeless and transient students, and many students have experienced great deals of trauma in their young lives. These art materials will connect the arts and the Minnesota Common Core English language arts and math standards, while helping students use their creativity to build their critical thinking, collaboration, and comprehension skills. Students will be able to create hands-on art projects with the paint. To practice literacy standards, they might retell a familiar story by painting pictures of the beginning, middle, and end. To explore math concepts, students might paint a picture using various two-dimensional shapes we have learned about this year. The options are endless when students have the opportunity to apply their learning through art! This project will allow students to truly practice the literacy and math standards they are learning in a practical way while also building social/emotional skills by integrating the arts into their learning. Students' lives will change for the better because this project will give students the opportunity to be creative with their art creations, to collaborate with other students in hands-on projects, and to ultimately build skills to expand their critical thinking skills, which are skill sets that will help them in their futures.
needStatement: My students need art materials, including paint and paper, and art tools, such as a drying rack and stools and cushions to sit on, to get creative while learning!

name: Know Thyself; Know Thy Peers
description: VECA's Museday Tuesday Club is a place where almost 25% of our student body meets after school on Tuesdays to explore the arts. As an early college academy, all of our students, from grades six to twelve, participate in a rigorous, accelerated academic program whose primary focus is to prepare the students to become the first in their families to graduate from a college or university. Because we begin collegiate coursework in the tenth grade, there is little time for an arts education during the school day. Created by three English teachers, the focus of MuseDay Tuesday is on the students and what they want to discover. So far, our members have asked for lessons in everything from dance, drama, and music to painting and sculpting. Thanks to a supportive community, we have been able to take our students to local museums, theater programs, and the fine arts department at a nearby university. We also coordinate and put on a fall showcase, black history program, and spring poetry slam each year. Students continually show up and show out for this little grassroots program of ours, and as teachers we are seeing the fruit in the classroom!Valdosta Early College Academy's MuseDay Tuesday fine arts club will begin the 2017-2018 school year with a series on identity, inspired by Plato's famous line, 'Know thyself.' This is a unique way for us to get to know our new students, and for the students to begin to bond with one another, all the while expressing who they are and learning to navigate a new school environment. Students will create three art pieces to introduce and express who they are: Cursive Name Painting, I Am Board, and a Stand Up Self Portrait. What's in a name? MuseDay Tuesday Students will learn to write their name in cursive, then use the requested acrylic paint and brushes to paint their name in cursive in a one-of-a-kind art piece with a mirrored effect. These will be laminated and displayed at our fall student showcase. Who Am I? Inspired by a creative Girl Scout's project, students will use the canvas and photographs of themselves to create a mixed media board in which they define who they are. With their picture in the center, students will use magazines to cut and paste affirming words. Lastly, they will personalize the piece with patterned paper, craft notions, gems, and other accessories. Stand Up and Be Counted! Students will use the stand up self portrait paper to paint an image of themselves that stands out-literally! Students will use the multicultural paint, along with yarn and tissue paper to depict themselves in an original work of art that will serve as center pieces in our fall showcase.
needStatement: My students need art supplies for the first series in our 2017-2018 MuseDay Tuesday fine arts club, centered around Plato's famous quote 'Know thyself.'

name: Follow the Rules: Math Teachers Have Enough Problems!
description: Our almost 1,400 students are 95% hispanic and are English Language Learners. 100% of our students receive free lunch and breakfast. Students come from a variety of different home lives, and a varied level of support systems around them. Locke's mission is to foster meaningful learning for all by increasing rigor and student engagement. My students are excited to learn and held to super high expectations. Students want to be successful and play an important part of our society today and in the future.A guided math table would be a great addition to my math classroom for my students. It is super important for students to be able to work in small groups, one-on-one with the teachers, or independently with teacher guidance to succeed in the 5th grade. As I reflect on my past teaching years, I am a strong believer that guided math and reading is the best way to run a successful classroom. Students enjoy working independently while I myself, as the teacher, can focus on skills that students are missing and need to master to succeed. A small group table would be so extremely helpful to my classroom for many reasons, one being that we are not constantly moving desks around taking valuable class time away.
needStatement: My students need a small group table to help support their guided math instruction!

name: Colorful Learning in Kindergarten Needs a Colorful Gathering Carpet!
description: My students are a diverse bunch of energetic kindergartners! We have cultures that span the globe and smiles to last through the entire school year. Our school is nestled in one of the most diverse school districts in Washington State with over 400 home languages spoken throughout the district. With so much diversity, we take time and find the great importance of understanding one another, and most importantly differences shouldn't have any sort of negative connotation. With such different backgrounds, our classroom gives these students a level playing field. Equity, compassion, and trust are some of the pillars of our classroom culture, and these students deserve a little help to be their best selves each day! With more structured play time in kindergarten, these new magnet tiles and alphabet cubes will lend themselves to their imagination as their creative little minds will construct new buildings and creations each day. Each day, their creations will strengthen their fine motor skills, their social skills, and expand their imagination. My classroom with have a bright, colorful and welcoming gathering carpet for our important lessons! The carpet will create independent seating and limit neighboring distractions with spaces in between each child spot. The supplies will promote independence as these students will have their own books in their book bins, accessible to them, and light enough for little kindergarteners to carry.
needStatement: My students need a colorful and welcoming carpet for optimal engagement, individual book bins for when they go book shopping in the classroom library, and blocks and tiles to build creations during our structured play time.

name: Building Love and Tolerance with a Love Seat!
description: My students make me want to teach for a lifetime in this urban environment. They are part of one of the largest urban school districts in MA. There are 52 languages spoken in our school community. We struggle with many of the same issues all urban school struggle with: full classrooms, not enough supplies, the many faces of poverty, but that is not what defines my students! My students are bright young individuals who deserve access to a thriving educational environment that challenges them to examine their own identity and how they can relate to others in this diverse world. Sitting in desks all day is overrated. WE want to create a safe, comfortable space which makes us at ease discussing sometimes uncomfortable topics around race and ethnicity. The addition of a classroom sofa will do just this! I want students to have a place which feels like it is 'theirs.' Students will be encouraged to read and have small conversations in my 'library' area of the classroom. This area is already rich in books, but we want to build a room within a room with a sofa. Students love to have small group discussions and read together, and a new sofa will provide the perfect space for this in our own classroom! In our Race and Ethnicity Course I am continually seeking spaces and opportunities for small group discussion which leads to cultural sensitivity, awareness, and promotes tolerance in our incredibly diverse school. I want to create a sanctuary inside the walls of our classroom where students study their own implicit and explicit bias. This is done through team building, sharing, and reading texts which challenge our social constructs. I also model and lead meditation as a way to begin class and enter our time together, or I may lead a meditation so that we can reflect on the challenges we face as we exit our classroom door and enter a world which is in need of more tolerance and understanding. I am beyond lucky to teach where I do with such brilliant and diverse young people, and to be able to teach course which I am developing called Race and Ethnicity and Gender and Identity. These courses give us an opportunity to ask questions and learn how to speak to and about each other. We are learning the vocabulary of media literacy, and the vocabulary of justice.
needStatement: My students need a love seat for a reading and discussion area, and a chime for group meditation in our diverse classroom which is working to teach tolerance.

name: Crank Up the Volume!
description: Our school is located in St. Paul, Minnesota. It serves students from very diverse backgrounds. My students are very curious about the world that we live in and ask questions like, why is math important? We work hard every day to make sure that they go home having answered that questions. They enjoy interacting with each other and are very tech savvy. They are open to new ideas and challenges and are willing to take risks while learning. Mistakes are something that are valued as learning opportunities. We record our math thinking in audiovisual form. We use this method specifically when solving complex problems that have more than one solution or approach to them. However, the quality of the audio is terrible due to the background noise that naturally happens in the classroom and our class sizes being very large. To be able to share these videos with other students, families and online communities, such as YouTube and on our own class blogs, we need to have good quality audio so that others can understand what the students are saying and can benefit from listening to their explanations and approaches. We need a microphone that hooks up specifically to the students' iPad to cancel out background noise and improve the quality of the audio.
needStatement: My students need a microphone that connects to their iPads to be able to record audio on their iPads without the background noise that happens naturally in a classroom.

name: Students Succeed in Welcoming Classroom!
description: My classroom consists of twenty-five amazing second-grade students. The class is a blend of six nationalities, three languages, and a wide range of learning abilities. Some students rely on the school for supplies, clothes, and food from local churches to take home for their families. Our school is a Title I school with 75% of the students receiving free or reduced-price lunch. About 19% of our student population is receiving services through special education and 11% are receiving services as English Language Learners. My students deserve a classroom environment where they feel welcome from the moment they walk down the hallway towards their lockers. They need an environment that promotes learning and encourages them to try their very best. Each year it costs a lot to prepare my classroom for a new group of students. The expenses can be overwhelming! With the help of this project, I can give my students a classroom that feels welcoming and exciting. My students will be able to receive a postcard from me prior to returning to school in August. I will be able to provide them with a calendar to use during our morning meeting and exciting bulletin board decorations to promote positivity in the classroom. The project will also provide my students with name tags for their lockers, desks, book bins, and cubbies. They will receive bookmarks to use with their library books, pencils to use during class, and folders to use for home/school communication. Please help me provide my students with a positive, inviting classroom environment that encourages a community of learning.
needStatement: My students need a classroom calendar, home/school communication folders, name tags, locker tags, bookmarks, pencils, folders, and welcoming classroom supplies to use throughout the year.

name: Building An Inclusive Classroom.
description: My students are multicultural with a high percent of minority students who live in a small college town. Our school is a Title I school with 100% of our students qualifying for free lunch. My students are interested in coming to school and learning science. They enjoy learning chemistry concepts by programming results from experiments and incorporating them into their learning process. They enjoy drawing pictures to interpret their understanding of the chemistry concept. They are always eager to learn new concepts. My classroom is highly diverse and I perceive the differences by the kinds of relationship that exist between my students. These diversities include but not limited to; gender, ability, socioeconomic class and sexual orientation. My project is about helping my students build relationship that would help them tolerate one another. I want to provide them with the opportunity to celebrate the similarities between themselves. I want my students to be able to celebrate each other’s birthdays and special holidays to help create bond and relationship. I want every student’s birthday celebrated in a special way by having all their classmates sign a card with a message for them. I also want my students to have an opportunity to celebrate special holidays by signing cards for each other. Building relationship involves being tolerant of one another and I believe that sharing each other’s special moment would help my students create respect and also become more sensitive towards each other’s differences. Research has shown that when students put forth efforts to learn something unique about each other, they are better able to relate more and tolerate each other’s uniqueness.
needStatement: My students need birthday cards, birthday stylus pens and holiday cards to build an inclusive relationship.

name: Flexible Seating for the Fun of Learning!
description: The students at my school are loving and have a true desire to learn. I truly believe their education may be the only thing that will allow them to succeed in life. Many of my students come from single parent families. Many of my student's parents are unable to help them based on education level or they do not speak English. My students face many obstacles before they even walk into my classroom. Many have to dress themselves for school and do not have a lot of parental support. My students need the wobble stools to help them stay on task during small group instruction. The stools will be at my small group table so they students can move about while they practice the love of learning to read. Most of my students stand or sit incorrectly in their chairs because they are uncomfortable. The wobble stools will help them get out their wiggles. The chair bands will help students who have problems with sitting still for long periods of time, like most kids that are six and seven. I can't wait to use these new ways of flexible seating to increase student motivation and truly enjoy learning as much I love teaching!
needStatement: My students need wobble stools and chair bands to help improve their concentration and increase their love in learning!

name: Seeing Ourselves in Literature: Building a Diverse 7th Grade Library
description: My Title I English classroom is a place where students can express themselves and discover their place in our community and in our world. The students I teach come from a variety of socio-economic backgrounds, and many of them speak another language at home. Our 7th Graders are becoming teenangers and facing increased social and acadmic pressure. Additionally, many of my students face hardships outside of school, and over half of them come from low-income households. Each day, we take risks together, learning and growing in preparation for the world beyond our classroom door. We learn empathy, travel the world, and find ourselves through the books we read and the words we write. For many of my students, the only books to which they have access are books at school. By building a diverse classroom library in my first year at the junior high level, my students will be able to seamlessly move from book to book. Unlimited access to a large volume of appropriate text will help my students to grow as readers and have experiences they may not have had otherwise. In books, we can find both windows to the world and mirrors of our lives. With your help, our library will expose students to both classic middle grade texts, like The Hobbit, as well as modern best sellers like Everything, Everything by Nicola Yoon. Many of the books on this list have been specifically requested by students or recommended by librarians. Some of these books are even my favorites from when I was in middle school, like The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants series. I will be putting each of these books in a 'spotlight' throughout the year by promoting the book to students at the beginning of class through a book talk, which is like a movie preview. My students will be excited to read each of these books, and I am anticipating a long waiting list for each of them!
needStatement: My students need engaging middle-grade books to build our classroom librabry.

name: Sticking to the Basics
description: My students are a bunch of eager learners, that always come to school with a big smile. They come from a low poverty inner city. My students often come to school with no preschool experience and many of them speak another language at home. Besides all of their challenges, these children work hard in school and make great strides in their learning. Every school year our district is faced with making cuts, and this often comes down to necessary resources and materials for my students. They face challenges outside of the school, and have to deal with limited resources in school. These supplies are the basic materials that the children need to complete all of their work. All of these supplies will help improve the children's fine motor skills. The children will use the pencils and crayons to create beautiful illustrations, and then become writers. The journals will be used daily to see if children understand story elements. The children will eventually write words, sentences, and stories with these supplies. The glue sticks will help students with independent practice of key concepts that require cut and paste. The glue sticks will also help students create projects, that will showcase their creativity.
needStatement: My students need pencils, crayons, glue sticks, journals, and dry erase markers.

name: Easel Fun!
description: Our students come from many diverse backgrounds and socioeconomic statuses. Many of our students are English Language Learners and have completely immersed themselves into learning a new language. Our students mainly come from sections of Staten Island that have pockets of poverty. All students receive free breakfast and lunch. Our school is part of the NYC Pre-K for All initiative. This is the second year this program has been implemented. As educators, we take pride in being pioneers of this new initiative; however, with the lack of materials, it hinders our ability to provide a quality Pre-K program to all students. We work collaboratively to make it possible, but feel our students could achieve so much more with the necessary tools. We want our students to be prepared and successful in their future school endeavors. I would like the Store & Display Teaching Easel so that I can use it as a tool for my students to be able to do more learning on the carpet. I would like to also use the easel for small and large group instruction. I am so excited to see what my kids can do with more tools to be able to use in the classroom to enhance their learning and expand their knowledge. The Easel will make a huge difference in my classroom by helping the students who need more one-on-one instruction and also the students who need to be challenged. This would mean the world to my students and myself and help so much.
needStatement: My students need The Store & Display Teaching Cart for whole group instruction!

name: Building a Library to Build Character
description: Our school is a Title 1 School, as well as every school in our district. We are an extremely low income school, all of our students receive free lunch. My students are young and are learning to understand one another. My students are very young learners, we are learning to be compassionate and understanding of others. Our younger students are building character, as well as their self esteem by reading and listening to a variety of stories and videos. Technology is a must have tool to help implement such skills to the students.  Integrating technology to young students is nothing new. Kids are becoming more tech savvy than most adults. Unfortunately for teachers, this is making it harder to keep a child's attention. As a teacher, keeping students engaged is very tough. With the help of an iPad, teachers can gain a child's attention to engage them in learning. Building character and a child's self esteem is crucial at this age. Students will be able to listen or watch stories and videos on what it means to become a good friend, never bullying, and simply being compassionate to others. By watching and listening, students will be able to get a better understanding and the extra reinforcement needed.
needStatement: My students need iPads to incorporate technology in the classroom, as a way to help my students build character and an understanding of why they are important. Visual aids are crucial in a young child.

name: We Are Ready To Go Green!
description: Hello and welcome to our school. We are located in the East Rogers Park area of the City of Chicago. 95% of the students population receives free or reduced lunch. Because of this, money is spent on the necessities and not on technology. This means my students do not have the same access to technology in the classroom as other schools and other students. My middle school students are eager to learn and excited to share what they have already learned. Technology in the classroom provides us with endless opportunities to both share what we have learned and to continue to learn. My goal is to prepare my middle school students for what comes after they leave my classroom and this school. In order to do that I must provide them with the tools and the opportunities to use technology on a regular basis. Ensuring that supplies such as pens, pencils, erasers, paper, and textbooks are readily available for my students is a constant battle. There are never enough of the most important things we need in order to produce our best work. Luckily enough, there is a solution to this pesky problem. We would like to make our classroom green, how will we do this? By becoming a Google Classroom, classroom! The Chromebooks we are hoping to receive from Donorschoose, will allow us to be a paperless classroom. This means that there will no longer be a mad dash for the last pencil or a wrestling match for the novel that is in the best shape, because we will have access to the materials we need through various on-line resources.
needStatement: My students need Chromebooks to make our classroom a paperless room!

name: Tolerance Through Tall
description: My students are awesome! They deserve all the resources to help them achieve success. My students attend a Title I school that is considered high poverty. We have almost 50% of our students receiving free or reduced price breakfasts and lunches each day. We even have a weekend food program too. My students are working extremely hard to be successful with the Common Core curriculum and I want to get them all the resources to achieve this. I appreciate how hard they work for me each day, and I know they'd appreciate any support you could give them. The best way I've found that students can build tolerance is through conversations with their fellow classmates. These conversations are elevated when they are sitting at a table. Long gone are desks in my room. They've been replaced with tables and stools. I'm asking for two more cafe tables and tall stools to make my class complete. My students love to move around the classroom. These cafe tables and chairs allow them to relax and have deeper conversations to understand each other better. I've listened to more cooperative discussions at these tables. They'll use them to sit at during class lessons, working on projects, wordprocessing on their Chromebooks. I can only hear the conversations now with two more tables and stools. They'll be conversations about classwork but mainly about each other and respecting each other's opinion and valuing their information as they develop their tolerance for one another.
needStatement: My students need two cafe tables with tall stools to allow them to develop tolerance for their classmates.

name: Wiggle While You Work
description: My students are some of the sweetest and most hardworking children I have ever met and they deserve more than my pocketbook can provide them. They are a good mix of experienced readers and students who are still mastering their use of the English language and they all love to learn, to play, and to grow. I'm less worried about who my second graders will become and more focused on who they are right this minute. My hope is that while they are with me, I have provided them with exactly the educational experience they each need to instill a life long love of learning. Learning these days is all about choice and part of that choice should include a comfortable learning environment with plenty of options on where a student can complete their work. Sitting at a desk all day isn't necessarily the best option for anyone, let alone a room full of 8-year olds. I want my classroom to reflect the seating choices an adult might be offered if they choose to go somewhere like Starbucks to complete some work or enjoy a good book. Not only with this help foster a more positive classroom community, but research has also shown the positive impact this type of learning environment can have on a child.
needStatement: My students need an assortment of seating choices to work effectively in the classroom.

name: Paint and Tools for Costume and Set Designers!
description: My students are difficult to sum up. They are diverse and quirky. They come from different backgrounds and a wide range of socioeconomic circumstances.
