They also have a wide range of interests. Some of them are passionate about the history of theater and classics, others are interested in acting, playwriting, directing or design. What they all have in common is that they are intensely thoughtful, creative, critical thinkers who are passionate about learning and excited by opportunities to participate in all aspects of their educations. My theater students take a two year long intensive theater course, where they learn, among other things, how to approach theater texts through the lens of a costume or set designer. In order to give the an authentic experience, we need materials that the kids can work with, in order to create physical representations of their designs. These tools, paints and most significantly, pieces of foam core, will allow them to move their creativity from their minds, and on to our stage and into our classroom. An essential step for having the full experience of acting as a set or costume designer!
needStatement: My students need to refill our set and costume design supplies, tools, paint and foam core, for next term!

name: Generosity Today...Smiles Tomorrow!
description: I teach 120 delightful 6th graders who are in need of a comfy place where they can read and relax in the classroom. I want my students to love reading as much as I do and I know being able to 'get away' with a good book would help them to love reading more. Your generous donation will allow my students the materials they need to make their learning more rewarding. I work in a Title I school and my students don't always have the supplies they need to achieve success. We also have very few copy machines and therefore my students are not able to write and mark on their papers because they have to share them with other classes. Please help my students reach their full academic potential by providing them with a classroom that has the amenities they need to be successful students and people. Thank you for your support. Teaching in a Title I school has its rewards. However, it also has its obstacles. These supplies will assist my students in being able to create effective work, as well as, help to keep them organized. A lot of my students don't have computers at home. I would like them to be able to print and copy things in their classroom therefore having a printer copy machine would benefit them. My students also do a lot of independent group work, having the lap boards would help them be able to communicate in a way that's not only verbal but also visual. I find it very useful to use technology in the classroom and watching videos on specific educational websites are paramount in my teaching. Having a set of speakers will make it so my students can hear the videos that I play in the classroom. My students also help me create bulletin boards and other displays in the classroom. I feel that having some of the materials that I've asked for will help them to be successful in creating their visions. When students don't have the proper resources now, it's difficult for them to be truly effective in the future. Time management and good organizational skills are something every effective student needs. When my students have access to these resources and materials, they will feel a sense of independence and ownership of their learning. These resources will help my students considerably. Thank you for your donations.
needStatement: My students need technology and classroom supplies for a productive school year. Thank you.

name: Watch the Text Come to Life!
description: Students at our school come from a variety of backgrounds. Many of them are English Language Learners, receive free or reduced-price lunch, and have very little or no resources at home. For a majority of my students, school is their favorite part of the day. These students don't always have the opportunity for enrichment activities outside of school. We need to provide opportunities for students to experience the same story elements we see in books through diverse media, such as film and audio. First grade students work hard on phonics skills and reading fluency to become good readers. More importantly, they learn how to identify story elements in a book. We spend the entire year practicing this vital skill that will lead to strong reading comprehension. The common core standards push our students more than ever before. Students are required to compare and contrast a book with another form of diverse media, such as film or audio. These DVDs will give our students the opportunity to watch engaging stories as they come to life. We are expecting so much from these little learners, so we try to make it fun to learn.
needStatement: My students need DVD movies so they can experience literature through diverse media.

name: Sensory Corner
description: My students attend a Title I school in North Carolina. They range from kindergarten to 5th grade and have disabilities such as learning disabilities, ADHD, and autism. They are some of the sweetest and most loving kids you'll ever meet! They love to come into the room and play games and learn skills that will help them be more successful in their regular classroom. They enjoy hands-on activities that will keep them interested in subjects such as reading, writing, and math. Please help support my kiddos!Students with disabilities sometimes need a sensory corner. We want flexible seating options for students to take a break or to read a good book when they come into the room. Students deserve a place they feel that they can go to when they are overwhelmed or when they want to share something with their friends. We want them to feel comfortable while still learning important academic and daily living skills. Students deserve a place where they feel safe and comfortable. With the opportunity of bean bag chairs and squishy pillows, students can relax and learn in a safe place outside of their regular classroom.
needStatement: My students need comfy seating where they can relax and recharge for the day.

name: New School Year Needs New Inspirations
description: I have been teaching math for the past 17 years in my current school. I have been teaching Math and recently ELL in special education department. It is the end of the year and I am trying to come up with some good ideas to decorate my classroom in August to welcome my new students for the new school year 2017-2018. I need new math and encouragment posters as well as bulletin board borders and a 'Presenter Clicker Pointer Remote Control'. The students enjoy a welcoming class and math hints on the wall. Technology is essential and the sooner they can be exposed to it, the more comfortable they are in the future. It is never too early to plan for next school year. Thank you for your support. The students like the class when is cheerful and welcoming. The students need inspiration to study and behave. We all do need reminders to do well every day. The students want to feel good and if a few hints on the wall help them to feel good, I want to make sure I provide them those hints to make them feel good. When they students feel good, they are more positive, more participant in class, and, for sure, they are more successful in class. My students may forget very simple daily math skills, and it is my job to provide them with written and verbal assistance to make them feel good about learning.
needStatement: My students need inspirational posters and more to create a welcoming math class to be inspired to come every day to do their best. I want my students to be impressed the first day and be inspried every day.

name: Coding and Money Make Our Learning Sunny!
description: The group of students that walk through my door each morning is bright and excitable. They each come from different home settings that create a unique melting pot within our class. Each of them craves positive attention and something new. This group may not have a wealth of background knowledge or resources but they do have the desire to learn. With 100 percent of the students receiving free breakfast and lunch, extra home resources are not always accessible. My students are very tech savvy. And while they may not have a personal tablet or computer in the home, they learn quickly with the resources within our classroom. Screen time is a great motivation for each of them and they truly enjoy learning with technology. With the Osmo kits, students will be able to independently practice second grade standards with self-checking support, while growing their love of technology. Practice is key in any avenue of life. As a teacher, I struggle to find resources that employ the use of current technology and meet the standards. This system is engaging and rigorous while working through real world situations to practice key concepts. My students deserve to learn with current technology. They are growing in exciting ways and sometimes faster than I can keep up with. Adding these tools to our classroom will encourage students to think beyond today and plan for the future. Coding and finance are such integrals part of everyday life. Along with practicing 2nd grade standards, I want my students to experience computer science and accounting in everyday life in hopes of planting a seed for their future career choice.
needStatement: My students need the Ozmo kits to continue developing their coding and money skills in real-world scenarios.

name: Wobble and Learn
description: One-hundred eager kindergarteners walk into my school each day. I smile and greet twenty-three of them as they buzz with excitement and walk into my classroom. Behind their smiles and excitement about school I know that many of them faced struggles at home the night before. My classroom becomes a safe and welcoming place for them each day. My school is a Title I funded school with a high population of students living in poverty. If you spent a day in my classroom you wouldn't noticed the material things my students are lacking in their life, but you would notice how excited they are to learn, how happy they are to create friendships, and how proud they are of their work. My students deserve the very best. I want to provide them a classroom that meets all their unique and wonderful needs. A place where I know that they will thrive. The students in my classroom are so eager to learn and very excited when they begin to understand new concepts. Five and six year olds are capable of so many amazing things such as the ability to look past appearances, love unconditionally, read and write, and having endless energy, just to name a few. This project will provide each and every one of those energetic students the ability to channel that energy in a positive way while promoting productivity and student health. Allowing all of my students a positive and safe outlet for their energy would also help increase positive classroom behavior and decrease negative classroom behavior associated with hyper activity. Children do way too much sitting whether it is in front of the tv or sitting at their desks. My students and I will be grateful for the wobble chairs and a chance to wobble and learn.
needStatement: My students need alternative seating that will allow them to positively channel their energy and increase their productivity.

name: Altos Make the Middle!
description: My students come from all over the world. Our school has one of the most ethnically diverse student bodies in my district. Numbering nearly 400 students, most receive free lunch. Languages represented at my school include Spanish, Arabic, Hindi and Vietnamese, among others. Many students are from first generation families, some are newly arrived in the United States and speak no English. As with many Title I schools, some students have experienced upheaval, trauma, and poverty in their young lives, which can be daunting. However, my students, whom I've just met, have shown great enthusiasm for learning music. I would like them to have opportunity to experience the joy of playing musical instruments. Learning an instrument facilitates students learning self-discipline, requiring focus and repetition, even when it seems tedious. An additional benefit of playing an instrument is it can help build a child's self-esteem. The joy of playing an instrument and becoming a musical being is a feeling all students can recognize, participate in and have fun doing. Carl Orff (composer of Carmina Burana) and Gunild Keetman developed an approach for elementary music called Orff Schulwerk. In the Orff music room, students combine music with movement, speech and drama. Barred instruments, such as xylophones and glockenspiels, are an integral part of an Orff experience. Altos compliment the sopranos and add a warm, rich tone to any song or movement activity. Students love having kinesthetic learning experiences, especially if it's with an instrument. Orff students learn to play steady beat and simple to increasingly complex rhythms on barred instruments through their elementary musical journey. Working with barred instruments like the requested xylophone provides students aural, visual and tactile opportunities, making it more accessible for all learning styles.
needStatement: My students need more xylophones to work on their mad mallet skills!

name: Catch the iPads: So We Can Be the Best!
description: My students are an energetic bunch. They come from various cultural backgrounds and languages which creates a truly unique and diverse classroom. They are innovative, dedicated, brilliant, kind, and inquiring minds who rise to any academic challenge presented to them. They need stimulating and challenging academic exposure in order to help them reach their highest limit. We learn together in a large K-5 school that does the best it can for our population of students. Our school has a large ELL population and high needs for differentiation and authentic learning experiences. Our school is a family of teachers, support staff, and learners that truly care about one another. We work together to deliver the best for each and every one of our students. Finally, we believe that technology in the classroom could be a game changer for our amazing students. iPads would allow my students to be exposed to a wealth of information, applications, books, and resources that are otherwise unavailable to them. I would also be able to monitor their progress through the use of various applications that will allow me to differentiate my instruction and pave the way to academic success and excellence for my students. An iPad helps students who are kinesthetic and visual learners. It opens up the doors of education and individualize their learning experiences. The iPad will become a tool that will help create more authentic learning experiences in the classroom as well as build twenty first century skills that our children need in order to be successful in a quickly evolving technical world. My students will be able to work in centers with the iPads. They will help with writing, reading, and phonemic awareness skills. Finally, iPads will definitely impact and change their learning environment tremendously.
needStatement: My students need Ipads. They would allow my students to be exposed to a wealth of information, applications, books, and resources that are otherwise unavailable to them.

name: Using Picture Dictionaries to Develop English Proficiency
description: Our elementary school is a creative arts magnet school in an urban district that uses interdisciplinary teaching and daily arts instruction to positively affect all students in the school through hands-on, interactive learning experiences. In our overall school population, 81% of our students qualify for free/reduced lunch. The students I work with are English Language Learners who are new to our country and come from diverse backgrounds and experiences. The students are highly motivated to learn but they have a wide range of learning needs. This school year, I worked primarily with small groups of 5th grade learners from El Salvador, Mexico, Ethiopia, Somalia, Myanmar, and Vietnam. These picture dictionaries will be a visual aid for my English as a Second Language (ESL) students to constantly reference when we are learning new words in a small group setting. My students and I create vocabulary charts using a modified version of the Frayer model which uses a graphic organizer to prompt students to understand words within the larger context of a reading selection. Students use the model to understand the definition and characteristics of a word as well as identifying examples and non-examples. The use of the picture dictionaries will help students to activate their prior knowledge of a topic and build connections. Using these picture dictionaries in conjunction with the vocabulary charts will enable students to learn and apply new vocabulary words that are commonly used in English. My goal is to provide students with as much visual support as possible in order for them to develop their English language proficiency, as well as better understand grade level content when they are in the general classroom.
needStatement: My students need picture dictionaries to prepare them for success using English in everyday life, in the community, and in school.

name: READING Gets You EVERYWHERE!
description: My students are from a high poverty area. Not having much in life does not dim the light in their eyes from wanting to learn all that they can. My students are hard workers but lack the funds, transportation or time to get books to read. I would like for my students to have the opportunity to be able to read books for pure enjoyment. It is an amazing thing to watch my students read a book they like, share it with friends and tell me all about it. I like watching them be engrossed in a book and wanting to read it over and over rather than being on the computer.“The more that you read, the more things you will know. The more that you learn, the more places you'll go.” ― Dr. Seuss, I Can Read With My Eyes Shut! My first graders love new books, however my classroom library has books that are falling apart! I would love to have new and updated books for them to read. Students will be able to read them in the classroom, choose what book they want me to read or check them out to read at home. My goal this year is for students to read 100 books during the school year. These books would go a long way to help them reach this goal.
needStatement: My students need a variety of books for a class library so they can enjoy reading not only at school but also at home.

name: 1,2,3,4...Help Us Do Our Math More!
description: My preschoolers are excited to learn and learn best through play and interactive experiences. We make sure all students feel accepted, loved, and valued. As a teacher in a high poverty school, my students are faced with several challenges both in and out of the classroom. Despite the many challenges they face, I am looking to provide my students with an environment that promotes a love for learning through play. I would love to offer my students the materials needed to foster learning and imagination! The math items I'm requesting for my students will make a difference in their daily learning. My students will be able to use the All About Me Family Counters with the math trays to: count, sort, make patterns, and compare. The trays will help keep the counters in place as they work. These items will be used in learning workstations, small group and individual activities where the students will have time to explore math in ways that are fun and will keep them engaged in learning. We will also use the Learning Lacers and Wiki Stix in math activities. These manipulatives will help the children connect to real world things they can interact with. Thank you for helping my students master Pre-K number recognition, counting, sorting and patterning skills through interactive play!
needStatement: My students need Lakeshore Math Trays, Wikki Stix, Learning Lacers, and All About Me Family Counters.

name: Feeding the Brain Part 3
description: 'All I really need to know... I learned in kindergarten.' Robert Fulghum I teach in a low income school where about 90% of our students are on the free and reduced rate lunch program. Our students come from a variety of backgrounds. Many of my students will have never been in a classroom prior to their first day of kindergarten. Some will have attended preschool one year, and others several years. But one thing we all will have in common is the eagerness to learn new things! One of the first things I learned early in my teaching career is that all of the basic needs have to be met before students are able to learn at their fullest potential. Snacks have been an integral part of that idea. Everyday, I make sure students have their basic needs met. Our kindergarten students go a full day and lunch is early. They get hungry towards the end of the day. During summer school, we provided a healthy snack daily and it helped them maintain the energy needed to finish the day strong. Snacks are provided every day to ensure that students are able to focus on learning and not other needs. We have several breaks during the day to help them refocus as well. Since providing this as part of our daily routine, I have seen great improvement with focus, behavior, and learning. After snack, students are required to clean their own table to be ready for the next learning activity. The paper towels and wet wipes will help them be able to clean their own space.
needStatement: My students need snacks and clean-up supplies to help nourish their brains.

name: Supplies for a Needy Kindergarten
description: My students are a wonderful and exciting group of 4-5 year-old boys and girls, in an ICT (integrated collaborative teaching) classroom. This means that 40% of my students are in special education, and the rest are in general education. We are a Title I school and work hard to ensure that everyone learns and succeeds. I want them to have everything they need to make their school year exciting and fun, as well as productive and successful throughout the entire year. September is an exciting time for many. We need the supplies to make sure that excitement stays throughout the entire school year. We need cleaning supplies like Clorox wipes, baby wipes and paper towels to ensure that the classroom stays clean and healthy throughout the school year. Especially because they eat snack each afternoon at their desks. They need water because we don't have a water fountain in our classroom that works. We also need cardstock and colorful paper to help make our room and boards pretty. We need Roaring Spring books for handwriting use throughout the school year. Please help us receive all the materials we need for next year. We want to start the year off on the right foot.
needStatement: My students need cardstock, color paper, water, baby wipes, Clorox Wipes, paper towels, ziploc bags, and composition books so that they can have a healthy, clean and productive classroom.

name: Little Mathematicians at Work
description: I teach all subject areas to second grade students. A cluster of my students are working to learn English. Nearly 10% of the students in my school building are English Language Learners. Believe it or not, these students come from over 23 different countries! At my school, nearly 40% of our students are economically disadvantaged. Many of my students qualify for free or reduced-price lunch. My students come from a variety of backgrounds, and together we create a wonderful second grade family! This will be the first year I am teaching math! I am eager to put my little mathematicians to work with engaging and hands-on materials to practice second grade math skills. My students need multiplication and subtraction flash cards, dice, decks of cards for math games, color counting chips, and timers as tools to enhance their mathematical understanding during independent centers. Additionally, I would like to have a hundreds chart posted in the room for students to use as reference throughout the year. Lastly, I am requesting a Lego storage container to store math building materials and a pocket chart to make rotating weekly student jobs a breeze. We can't wait to get started learning math! Thanks for your support!
needStatement: My students need flash cards, fraction circles, dice and other supplies to practice their math skills.

name: Technology for a 21st Century Math Classroom
description: First and foremost, my students are incredible young people who are intelligent, funny, compassionate and resilient! My students are racially, ethnically, and economically diverse--30% African American, 30% Asian/Pacific Islander, 25% Caucasian, and 15% Hispanic. Free and reduced-price lunch students make up 78% of our total population, 24% of students receive Special Education services and 31% are Multi-Language Learners. My students' family backgrounds are also varied. There are many single-parent households, lower-income families, homeless families, abusive family dynamics, mental health issues, as well as some students with very little trauma in their home lives. Regardless of the advantages or disadvantages at home, many of my students struggle with academics. That is one of the reasons that I am so grateful to share this time with them and to support their growth and independence. We work together to learn, play, grow, and create a community of hope and respect in our classroom. Access to technology is a critical component of classroom learning because 80% of the lessons and 90% of the class work is posted on Schoology. We are a one-to-one iPad classroom, using apps like: Schoology, IXL, Buzzmath, Quizlet, etc. Students are learning to be responsible for their iPads, but they need access to a charging station, stylus', and a document camera to foster a more interactive learning experience. These tools will allow them to more readily explain their reasoning and share the logic behind their problem solving with their peers. Students succeed best at mathematics when they can observe how to set up an interactive math notebook, take Cornell notes, and use notes to complete their class work and study for tests. The document camera will make it easier to model how to do these things, as well as helping students prepare for quizzes and tests. These additional tools will allow easy access to technology while creating a positive and collaborative classroom learning environment where all function equally as students, explorers, and teachers to grow as a math learners.
needStatement: My students need access to the following technologies to foster a more interactive classroom learning environment where they can share their work: iPad charging station, iPad stylus' and a document camera.

name: Reliable News Stories in the Fake-News Era
description: My fifth graders are a curious bunch of learners. They love learning new concepts in science, and they love talking about the world around them. Especially when it comes to issues that hit home with them, from race politics to school lunches. Our school is in a poor urban neighborhood, so students don't have a lot of reading material at home, and internet access is spotty, usually on a tiny cellphone. Most of them don't have the opportunity to take many vacations beyond the borders of our state, so we have to rely on books, magazines and the internet to broaden their understanding of the world. My students spend hours on the internet without necessarily thinking critically about what they read, see, and hear. They have many misconceptions about science and current events, and we are able to use Scholastic News magazine to tackle some of these misconceptions, as well as hone reading comprehension skills. We are requesting a class subscription to Scholastic News. Scholastic News does an excellent job of factual journalism for kids. Having this print resource is invaluable in our fifth grade classroom to keep up with what's really going on in the world. The teacher lesson plans and reading comprehension questions that come along with the magazine provide a standards-aligned starting point. The students love the digital edition and news extras that come with the subscription. The computer will even read the issue aloud, which is essential for my students who cannot read it for themselves.
needStatement: My students need engaging print reading materials to make meaningful connections to literacy.

name: First Week of School = Hungry and Hot!
description: This is by far the sweetest group of students that I've ever had! They have such kind hearts. They all have a zest for learning and always put in their best effort. My students are all from low-income households, with close to 100% receiving free lunch. Some of the families struggle to provide basic needs for the children. Even with the struggles that their families face, these first graders are happy, positive learners! I find myself going 'the extra mile' for my students. I want to make learning fun for them because they bring so much joy to my heart! My students need pre-packaged snacks for the first week of school and reusable water bottles to use throughout the school year. What's worse than being hot, hungry, and unhappy on those LONG days during the first week of school? Most of my Kindergartners will be experiencing a full day of school for the first time - in the August heat! Many of them will come to school without breakfast and lunch. Luckily, the school provides that! But come late afternoon, my poor Kindergartners are going to be tired, cranky, and hungry! In addition, they come back to school in mid-August - at the peak of Cleveland heat! Unfortunately, we don't have air conditioning in the building, so we try to tough it out by staying hydrated! With this project, not only will my Kindergartners have full bellies, they will also get their very own reusable water bottle to stay hydrated through the school year! The snacks will ensure that every student has a snack. In addition, I'll be able to send home granola bars to students to have as a snack over teh weekend. I'm not sure which students will be getting a full meal for dinner when they get home, so I want to make sure I'm able to have something to give them. In addition, the water bottles will ensure that all of my students are in class, learning, and bonding with their classmates - not going to the other side of the building for a drink of water! I just want to make sure my Kindergartners are happy, not hungry, and hydrated. I need to make sure those basic needs are met before I even attempt to teach anything! With this project, I won't have to worry if my students are hot, hungry, or unhappy!
needStatement: My students need snacks for the first week of school, reusable water bottles, and adhesive labels to label the water bottles with names.

name: Little minds at Work!
description: I teach 3 and 4 year olds in a Head Start setting. These little lovelies are so full of life and excitement I love receiving hugs and good mornings when they walk in. Head Start services children with disabilities as well as under privilaged children. 80% or more of our students come from homes that qualify for financial aid of some sort and will qualify for free and reduced lunches upon entering the public school system. They come to us for a little boost in social emotional skills, exposure to literacy and math skills, extra exposure to laguage and speech, and many other things on a daily basis. We love our students dearly and want to provide them with the background knowledge and skills that will help them to succeed in public school and beyond.I teach 3 and 4 year olds in a Head Start. They come to me already behind in many areas of their gross and fine motor, academic, and cognitive developments. The materials requested will expand their experiences in building, counting, 1-1 correspondence, sorting, classifying, and so much more. By using these manipulatives during whole group, small group, and independently; my students will begin to build their number awareness which is a critical foundation for mathematics. Your generous donation helps my students to fill the gap and enter school on par with their peers. It also helps to enrich their lives by giving them a positive first experience with school concepts.
needStatement: My students need exposure to manipulatives to encourage growth in math skills, fine motor skills, and cognitive skills.

name: Let's Play Ball!
description: My PreK scholars are amazing! The are the only full day class in our school. They are eager to learn and love being in school. Our school is very diverse and takes pride in welcoming and engaging all scholars and families. We are committed to creating a school where kids feel safe, loved, and motivated. As a school, we take pride in creating an environment where we celebrate diversity, discuss and study racial equity, and 'inspire all scholars to reach high levels of social and academic achievement and to become future leaders through a collaborative system of support' (our School's Mission Statement).I would like to set up an area in my classroom for scholars to play games. My hope is for these games to be fun, encourage cooperative play/movement, and also connect with my scholars interests! Movement throughout the day is so important for all children. I know that if I have an area in my room for scholars to visit if they are needing extra movement, it will help them learn. A trampoline will be perfect for the scholars to get some jumping in inside of the classroom. I plan to use the basketball hoop in several ways. I look forward to encouraging my scholars to make a basket everyday, and teach about the importance or team work, good sportsmanship, and taking turns. It is not very often you see a basketball hoop INSIDE the classroom. I can't wait to see the reaction of my scholars. The indoor football target and beanbag toss will also be a great addition to the movement area in the room. The scholars will have several choices. I will also be able to switch games out when needed. I am so excited to add some movement to my classroom. I know it will help my scholars to be even more successful.
needStatement: My students need a trampoline, an indoor football target, a beanbag toss and a basketball hoop to play in the classroom to practice taking turns, get in some movement during the day, and to have fun!

name: Moving Minds and Bodies!
description: Our school has a population of about 650 students with many coming from homes with little monetary and academic support. The focus in our school is Animation, Creation, and Design which has opened up the door to so many students who previously had struggled in school. With the programs we offer, it has engaged so many students and they have found strengths where they didn't know existed. My students come from diverse backgrounds, however, they all have one thing in common- their creativity and conscientious attitude in the classroom. I teach a group of academically advanced 2nd graders which means they are working above their current grade level. With my students' minds working at such a fast pace, it is evident that their bodies want to do the same. They all have such unique personalities and bring so much life to our classroom. My students' minds amaze me each and every day. They are such creative thinkers and are constantly thinking outside the box. However, their little bodies need to be moving. They need to be comfortable. I have been researching the idea of flexible seating and am ready to implement it into my classroom. The idea scared me at first but if my students can think outside the box, so can I! Throughout this past year, I continued to notice how much the students wanted and needed to be moving around while they are working. They loved sitting around the room over sitting in their chairs. Students showed so much more on task behavior and creativity in their work- I was amazed! This would give them the opportunity to work in a more comfortable and conducive environment to showcase their work. Currently, we have enough flexible seating for four students along with carpet squares. The stools that I'm requesting will help with my fidgety students who like to move while they work due to the wobbling ability of the stool. The comfy floor seat gives students who still want to sit in a traditional chair a more comfortable way of doing so while still completing their work on clipboards. We also do a lot of collaborative work and each of the groups need to spread out in order to have enough space to work cooperatively. The soft seats will allow the groups who are on the floor a space to complete their group work. All of the items will work wonderfully to give the students a comfortable spot while reading independently. I want to give the opportunity of a comfortable work space to more of my students. They deserve it!
needStatement: My students need flexible seating to match the level of constant movement in both their bodies and their minds!

name: Seating to Keep the Wiggles Away!
description: My students walk into our classroom every day full of life, ready to learn, and excited for what is in store for them that day. I teach at a Title I school in North Carolina where 100 percent of our students receive free breakfast and lunch. Many of my students receive backpack food on the weekend. Quiet a few need to visit our district's clothing closet, just to be able to come to school in appropriate clothing. There have been a few who aren't sure where home will be at the end of the day. Despite so many hardships, my students are eager to learn and do their best. They want to be in school because they want to learn all they can so they can be successful one day. The bean bag chairs, yoga balls, wobble seats and portable desk will help my students who find it impossible to sit quietly and listen or complete independent work. These materials will not directly teach my students new skills, but they will help prime my students for learning in all content areas. For example, while I'm teaching a math lesson my students who usually are unable to sit still and quiet can use the wobble seat to help keep them selves focused while getting out their bottled up energy without being an interruption to others . The donations for this project will improve my classroom by reducing the amount of behavioral issues, because I will be able to provide the appropriate stimulation that my students need. With less behavioral issues, we can increase our learning and time on task. I'm looking forward to seeing my students happier and ready to learn.
needStatement: My students need alternatives to sitting at a traditional desk with wobble chairs, lap trays, and bean bag chairs. Alternative seating will help my students who need to move and wiggle to stay focused and on task.

name: Books That Make Me Want To Read!
description: 'Is it time to go home already?!' The children I work with love coming to school! Our school is one of the most culturally diverse and welcoming schools in the St. Paul Public Schools district. Our demographics are American Indian 22 % Asian American 33% African American 25% Hispanic American 14% Caucasian American7%. Many of our children come from difficult lives, filled with trauma and uncertainty. School is a safe place that provides 100% free meals, loving care and dedicated teachers. We strive for a warm community of understanding, between all of our school's cultures. We are all related! This Ojibwe teaching is a common belief at our school. Given the diverse backgrounds we all come from, our classroom community is so strong and each child has a voice! In turn, the children take their education seriously. They understand that educating themselves is the foundation for the rest of their lives. The books and magazines I have chosen from Scholastic, are updated and filled with multicultural examples of people in them. The Dynamath Magazine for example, uses current real world situations and problems that my students can fully engage in. I want my students to see themselves in the illustrations when learning about math and science and reading itself! I have older books about careers, but the new set I am requesting is at a reading level many of my students need and is filled with multicultural images. The text and trade books currently in my classroom, are outdated and need more diversity.
needStatement: My students need subscriptions to DynaMath magazine and high-interest books at their individual reading levels. Many of the books in my classroom are outdated. I want to meet the individual reading needs of my students, while keeping them engaged!

name: Student Choice
description: Mexican, Salvadorian, Guatemalan, Colombiano, Japanese, these are a few of the cultures my students bring to our school. My students are eager to learn, excited to be at school, but also have faced many hardships at such a young age. I teach at a title 1 school, where 85% of our students qualify for free and reduce lunch. For some students, the school is the only safe place for them. I try to provide a safe place where learning is fun! These materials will be used to give options for student for working in the classroom. Many of my students work best when standing up or sitting on the floor. Standing desks, stability balls, and floor cushions will provide options for my students to learn the best way they can! Research has shown that students need to be given options for seating. Not all students learn best when sitting at your 'typical desk' but learn better and can focus more when standing up or sitting on the floor. I hope that by providing options for them, they will be more successful!
needStatement: My students need flexible seating in order to be successful on their academics. By providing options and spaces for them to sit at, it will increase the chances for them to be successful!

name: Wild About Learning and Reading!
description: My students are from an inner-city public school that is Title 1 and are predominantly Hispanic students. I have many students who are from foster care parents and/or 1 parent families. My students and parents care about their education and we all work together to make their student's education a positive experience. My students love to do hands-on projects and get up moving out of their seats! I want to do more community building activities and want this to become a daily part of our classroom routine. I think when students feel safe, valued, and know that learning can be fun; then, students feel empowered and know they can achieve anything!This rug will make a huge difference for my students as we love to get up out of our seats and do movement activities as well as all sit together to do community building time. My students currently have to sit on really old linoleum tile that is usually not the cleanest in our room. This rug will make it so much easier to get on the floor and do some cool hands-on projects as well allow for a clean and comfortable place for reading! My students become my family during the school year and I want to make them feel safe and have a fun and comfortable area to go for our class to have carpet time! I plan on incorporating community building projects to help foster my relationships with my students so they know that everyone in our class has a purpose and is cared and valued by everyone!!
needStatement: My students need this rug for our interactive time while we do hands-on activities, doing community activities, reading with a partner, or me reading to my class!

name: Teaching Tolerance Through Flexible Seating Choices (Part 2)
description: Every morning, my sweet students come to me from low-income to mid-income neighborhoods. Some are hungry. Some are tired. And, some just want a hug. Home life can be stressful, but at school, they can look forward to learning, friendships, food, and plenty of encouragement. For some of my students, our classroom is the one place they can count on for routine, safety, and community. Let's work together to bring these sweet students some joy in their education by creating a safe place for them to be innovative, creative, and think outside of the box!I am requesting several different choices of seating arrangements for the students in my Writing and Social Studies classroom in order to meet their physical needs. I would love to do away with standard school chairs and replace them with ways for my students to get their bodies and minds moving such as bouncy bands and stools. Every child in my classroom has different physical needs, and I desire to create an environment of acceptance and tolerance through flexible seating. Whether it's a case of the wiggles or an itch to move, my students would greatly benefit from stools, a computer chair, a bench, and bouncy bands. For the past five years of my teaching career, I have seen kids 'eye' other students who have to stand during class or need to go on a quick walk to move around. I have heard comments made under their breaths about the differences in how students work. This was made possible by having conventional desks and chairs where any slight difference for one or two students is very noticeable. This cannot continue. I have to change my classroom environment. I would love to help students understand that everyone has different physical needs, and that is totally okay! Over the past few months I have been collecting exercise balls, standing desks, and bicycle peddlers in an attempt to create an accepting environment. But, I still need more supplies to make this dream come true! I am asking for your help in creating a classroom where everyone is able to learn in their own way. I am asking for your help in creating a classroom where students can feel safe, comfortable, and normal. I am asking for your help in creating a classroom of tolerance. Thank you!
needStatement: My students need a computer chair, a bench, bouncy bands, and a stool to meet physical needs and help teach tolerance of differences between peers.

name: STEM in Pre-K
description: I teach in a Title I school where all students receive free lunch. My school was one that was affected by Hurricane Matthew. We are trying to rebuild and expand their horizons with hands on activities. These children have been through so much with being displaced and losing everything they had, to being out of school for weeks at the time. They are in the process of rebuilding the community in which the children reside and hopefully some of the residents will move back in the area. My students will benefit from the items by being able to apply Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math. They will be able to build social skills and even build literacy. The centers will have more to offer with the STEM kits and the students will have more to choose from. The wobble chairs will be in the STEM center so that the students won't have to sit still while using the design and build engineering centers. The stand up design board will be used along with the engineer a coaster kit and the create a path magnetic center. The children will learn by trial and error of how the position of the track affects the disk. The store it all rotating caddies will be used for each center so that the children have the supplies they need right at their fingertips.
needStatement: My students need these items, such as wobble chairs, discovery tubes, and engineering center activities, to start focusing on STEM projects.

name: Help Us Start the Year Out Right With New Supplies!
description: Do you remember going school supply shopping? The excitement of a new year, picking out the perfect notebook and the cool pencil case? For many of my students, this is not a reality. Many of my students come to school with no school supplies. We are a community of thirty 4th Grade Scholars in a Title I school in Oregon. We are excited and eager to learn. Our school population is 100% free and reduced-price lunch. With shrinking school budgets it is getting harder and harder to provide students with the basic school supplies that are needed to learn. My students will be using these materials daily, they do not always get new materials so having new and unused materials to start out the year will be amazing! Markers, crayons, colored pencils, pencils, erasers, oil pastels, paint brushes, mini stamp markers, graph paper and glue are essential supplies to any classroom. These supplies will be used in every aspect of the classroom. My students will use these materials during math, reading, writing, art and so many other areas throughout the year. Every student deserves to have the basic supplies to help them achieve their full potential. By supporting this project you are giving my students what they need to have a successful 4th-grade year.
needStatement: My students need pencils, markers, crayons and other supplies to help them have a successful school year.

name: Super Seating for Sensational Scholars!
description: The learners in my classroom come with many varied experiences. Many come from homes around the world including Philippines, Eritrea, Morocco, Mexico, China, and Ethiopia. This diverse group of learners come with varied needs and individualized learning goals. Some students are just learning English while others are leading the class in mathematics. They like to move, discover, and interact. I make our classroom as inviting as possible and let them know that our classroom is a safe place where they are heard. Most of our parents work and living in Las Vegas means they work 24 hours a day. Many students rarely see their parents because they work swing shift. This means I am often the stable adult in their lives and I take that responsibility seriously. Being a parent myself, I do all I can to help the parents and the children in our school community. Students spend six hours a day in our classroom and I believe it is important to move often and work in different groups daily. Throughout the day we work individually, with partners, in small groups with the teacher, and in groups with other students. Finding where to sit in a small portable classroom makes all of these activities more difficult, and time is wasted in transitions as students wander looking for a place to settle. By donating to our project, you will allow our students to transition quickly, get to work, and have the opportunity to collaborate with their peers and teacher. First, the stools will allow group work at the small table either with the teacher or their classmates. Next, the sit spots allow easier grouping of students on the floor with partners. Lastly, the inflatable chair pads and chair bands help my wigglers stay focused when they are working at their desks individually, and helps them stay in their seat when they need to get down to business. All of these items will help with classroom management and will assist students so they can focus on increasing their learning.
needStatement: My students need seating for our new classroom in a portable. Our space will be limited so using stools and sit spots will help tremendously. Also, my wigglers will appreciate chair bands and wobble cushions.

name: Mapping With Ozobots
description: In August, I will begin my 21st year in education. It is a blessing to spend my days at this beautiful community school in the spectacular mountains of western North Carolina. My drive to work is full of beautiful landscapes. My school is small (kindergarten through fifth grade), with fewer than 150 students. We may be small, but our dreams are big. The community is deeply invested in the education and the nurturing of each student. Economic status does not provide a barrier to learning, instead, it provides a challenge this school accepts on a daily basis. With your help, we can give these deserving students everything they need!Ozobot Bit is the world’s smallest smart robot. This right brain – left brain integrating bot builds both creativity and coding skills in children. It is my plan to have my students advance from basic color coding to intermediate block-based programming with Bit. Students can draw lines with the special markers, create obstacles and create color codes to control the Ozobots. This project is inspired by a project previously created by Ms. Mundt. Students will use the markers and chart paper to create a map of North Carolina. They will design the map so that at in each section like the Piedmont or Mountains the Ozobot will follow a code and spin or rapidly flash its lights. Fourth grade students will need to create their path so the Ozobot turns at the appropriate times and makes its way from one section of the map to the next.
needStatement: My students need an Ozobot dual pack with markers and unruled chart paper.

name: Bringing STEM Outreach To Pre-K
description: I have the privilege of teaching 20 pre-K students in a general education setting. My classroom is made up of 20 eager pre-Kindergarten students. My class is made up of three and four-year-old sweeties. We are singers, readers, writers, mathematicians, and lovers of technology. My students require individualized instruction to succeed in their learning. One of the biggest challenges to teaching students in pre-K is their need for individualized visual schedules and adapted learning materials. I do small groups daily to improve language, reading, and math skills. This project will bring educators from NYSCI to our classroom so my students can experience creative, hands-on activities as they investigate the basic science behind mixing colors and camouflage. My students will investigate mixing colors, explore the colors of the visible spectrum through hands-on experiments, and learn the differences between primary and secondary colors. They will participate in an interactive story time and make a colorful collage to take home. In the Camouflage program, my students will learn about animal adaptations and how animals keep themselves safe from predators. My students will create an animal that will hide in its environment using camouflage. An interactive story time is included in this workshop. This project will give my students the opportunity to do hands-on learning, giving them the chance to interact with various materials. This will open up a world of discovery for my students and bring science to our classroom.
needStatement: My students need educators from NYSCI to visit our classroom so my students have the opportunity to learn and interact with various materials and many programs including the investigation of the basic science of mixing colors and camouflage.

name: Morning Tubs: A Way to Promote Creativity and Social Skills
description: My students come from very diverse backgrounds. Close to 70% of my students live below the Federal Poverty Level. When my 1st grade students walk into my classroom I strive to provide for them an inviting, caring, and exciting learning experience. With so many personalities and such diverse home lives it can be difficult to make the transition to a learning environment. Yet once they are comfortable, they can work at something that seemed so difficult to them at first and then it happens...they get it! Now they are motivated to work hard and learn more. There is nothing more rewarding than the look of accomplishment on a 1st grade child's face. Each day after coming into the classroom my students put their belongings in their cubbies, have breakfast, and complete a morning warm up activity. After the activity is completed they are able to work with a Morning Tub. Morning Tubs allow students to work together while learning. My students need to learn how to interact with each other...many are very good at individual activities, but they need to learn how to share materials and ideas. Morning Tubs are a big part of this process. Each tub has materials inside that promote student socialization, collaboration, and creative learning. Morning Tubs offer a play-based opportunity for students to explore, create, and communicate. My class is divided into four groups (red, yellow, green, and blue), the morning tubs have a color code on the front. Each week I switch out the tubs so everyone gets a turn at each activity. The materials I requested will enhance student learning and build social skills as they work together on different activities. Rory’s Story Cubes have pictures with different themes like verbs, ways to move, places to visit. The students will roll 2-3 of the cubes and using the pictures along with their imagination they will combine them into a story. The Magna-Tiles are sized just right for little hands and easy to use to create a design on a flat surface or building in 3-D. Magna-Tiles develops patterning, shape recognition, building, and motor skills. The WonderFoam Dominos will be used for number tile matching games, sorting, counting, addition, and subtraction practice. I think the AGARE Brain Flakes will be a favorite. This is a set of interlocking snowflake shaped plastic disks. Students can build and learn. My students are excited about starting their day with these activities. They really love Morning Tubs!
needStatement: My students need materials to fill our morning tubs like Brain Flakes, Legos, and Magna-Tiles to promote student interaction and creativity.

name: Active Learners Need Bouncy Bands To Stay Focused
description: What makes my classroom special? Well, it's the students and the community that I serve. When I came to this school it had just received an F, which meant it was a failing school. In my classroom, at least half of my students were one to three grade levels behind. Coming from low socio-economic backgrounds they come to my classroom missing background knowledge and experiences. However, I teach my students to dream and aspire to be more than their current circumstances.I teach my students that no matter what kind of neighborhood you grow up in, they too can leave a great impact on the world. I grew up in the same neighborhood and came back after going to college to make a difference. Many of my students have difficulty focusing and sitting their seat. Brain research shows that these types of students greatly benefit from alternate seating. I want to provide each one of my students with their very own bouncy band. Bouncy bands allow students to move while completing their work. Students will stay focused in class better when they have a way to get some relief when they feel hyperactive, anxious, stressed or frustrated. Using up excess energy improves metabolism, increases motivation and engagement, creating a better oxygen flow to the brain. Physical activity is linked to higher academic performance, better health, and improved behavior. It is also great for students with ADD and ADHD. I believe the bouncy bands will create a better learning environment for my students.
needStatement: My students need Bouncy Bands to help them release extra energy, anxiety, and tension while they work quietly at their desk. Students have fun working when they can move!

name: Reading is Resistance!
description: My students are awesome! These Pre-K through eighth grade students come from a culturally rich community in the heart of central Portland. What makes this school so special is that many families have been apart of this school community for generations which means our school holds special meaning in the lives of these families. Our school is a Mandarin immersion school that also includes African Dance, international baccalaureate, right brain initiative (art), and rich cultural diversity. We have great community supports and partnerships as well. In our classroom, we have 23 students who weave a colorful fabric of different languages, racial and economic diversity, as well as athletic and artistic talents. My students bring to the classroom a wealth of cultural, linguistic, racial, religious, socioeconomic and academic differences. It is therefor important for these students to not only be able to identify with characters in the books they are reading but expose themselves to the differences in others. I want to empower my students with knowledge as well as compassion and advocacy for others. By providing socially and culturally diverse literature at varied levels, a wide range of students will be able to access the material and ideally find a number of different books that meet them at their reading level and also challenge them appropriately.
needStatement: My students need a variety of leveled books that represent not only themselves but others.

name: Literacy Liberty
description: The United States has been called, 'The Land of Opportunity.' Most citizens can describe the traditional 'American Dream' as the right and ability to carve out any life you choose. Unfortunately, for children, not all opportunities are equal. My students are the picture of America. They come from a wide range of ethnic backgrounds and vastly varied, socioeconomic lifestyles. Each child comes with their own life experiences, strengths, and weaknesses. They all want to feel safe and successful, and every one of them brings the need and desire to be loved. My students are curious, humorous, and zealous. They enjoy learning with their eyes, ears, and hands. As a classroom family, students work together, learn from each other, and strive for personal goals of personal best. Often times, students believe that reading is restricted to books. This can be overwhelming for students who lack confidence. This project will bring a bit of liberty to the classroom. Reading is reading. Building literacy requires more than an accomplished list of book titles. When time, stamina, or even interest is limited, many students simply choose not to read. My hope is that adding a fresh supply of kid friendly magazines will remove some of that pressure. Perhaps a novel full of chapters seems too daunting. Start with an article! Maybe sports heroes are more motivational that fantasy characters! So they can read Sports Illustrated Kids. Why not start your animal research with some fun facts from a sidebar in Zoobooks? The goal, at any age is to inspire a love of learning in my students. Instead of imposing restrictions, I hope to open young minds by offering choices and the freedom to make them.
needStatement: My students need kid friendly magazine options for their classroom library.

name: Run Run as Fast as You Can!
description: My students are amazing! We are a two time National School of Character and our students exhibit this every day. Our students lead assemblies, have classroom jobs and leadership roles. They love to learn and connect their learning to the real world. We like to make learning hands-on and fun! We are dedicated to finding new ways to get my kids excited about learning. I know that creating lifelong learners is a huge part of my job. By making learning FUN, I can foster a love of learning in my young students. These resources will help my students become better runners. We have to get ready for our track meet, and these materials will get them running. The cones and mats will be used to create starting points and obstacles. The balls will be used to create a variety of games to get them moving. The chalk will be used to write times, and create more running games on pavement. My kids love to move! I know these materials will get our team up and moving, which will make us faster and better riunners. The variety will allow us to get creative with our activities and keep kiddos excited for practice. I can't wait to get them started and to see how we do in our final competition.
needStatement: My students need spot markers, balls, and cones for running training.

name: Resistance and Redemption: Unraveling The 'March' Trilogy
description: We are a very small school: 100 students. The reason DCS is so small is because we are, in essence, a modern-day, one-room schoolhouse. Our students are taught every subject in mixed-grade classes. We find, with the right amount of differentiating the material for the older and younger students, the students mentor one another, find role models, observe what struggle and humility look like. Our students are on a constant search to nurture and satisfy their sense of intellectual curiosity. To them and their families, education is the first priority in life. Because of the economic hardships many of our families face, they understand the connection between receiving a high-quality education and achieving success in life. We consider our school's curriculum to be extremely rigorous, and our expectations of our students are high. Our school represents the rich ethnic and racial spectrum of the city of Newark. Our students and staff are African-American, Caribbean, Caucasian, Hispanic and Middle Eastern: Muslim, Protestant, Jewish and Catholic. There are students whose families have been in Newark for decades, and students whose families have just arrived here from abroad: all-in-all our school community represents over 30 countries from around the world.DCS kicks off the coming school year with a school-wide, interdisciplinary unit of study on our city: Newark, NJ. The title of the unit is 'Newark: Revolution, Rebellion and Rebirth'. One of the periods we will focus on in-depth is the Newark Riots of 1967, also known as the Newark Rebellion. I am seeking literature to teach in English Language Arts which will enrich the students' knowledge of that period in American history, specifically as it relates to the African-American's struggle for civil rights in the 1960s. The 'March' Trilogy is a perfect vehicle to teach my students one man's real-life account of social rebellion in the 1960s, written in a format to which they can relate easily. 'March' is a graphic novel, presented in three parts, the story of the life of Rep. John Lewis. The format of a graphic novel will gain critical buy-in from my students and give them an immediate feeling that the material is in an accessible format. The use of 'comic book' conventions, will naturally convey the urgency and drama of the events. I am positive that the combination of the powerful content of John Lewis' story and the inviting design of the graphic novel will give my students a vivid context through which to view what happened in Newark in July of 1967: how it could happen in America and why it had to happen.
needStatement: My students need to study the 'March' trilogy, so they may analyze the trajectory of a life steeped in the social activism and racial turmoil of 1960s America.

name: High-Interest Lessons Lead to Engaged and Confident Readers
description: Our school serves students in grades K-5 and focuses on working together to develop lifelong learners and responsible citizens. We provide special education, academic intervention, Title I, and ESL services. As a fifth grade educator, I have observed many success stories of students who challenge themselves, raising their expectations to higher levels, take on more responsibility, and become independent students. My goal is to prepare my students for middle school, leaving them with a passion, excitement for learning, and confidence. My diverse fifth grade classroom molds together 28 unique students, many of who come from bilingual households and receive free and reduced-price breakfast and lunch. My students come to school every day eager to learn and put their trust in me. Every student has a unique learning ability, and I want to give each individual the best learning experience by adapting my lessons to meet their individual needs. Incorporating engaging resources and hands-on manipulatives allows my students to work through self-discovery, ultimately leading to abstract reasoning. This educational philosophy, I believe, will promote not only good decision-making in the classroom, but also establish a fundamental lifelong skill. Our classroom is in need of reading materials to help our daily guided reading groups become more successful and engaging. The materials listed are examples of high-interest literature, which leads to confident and enthusiastic readers. Students will have a variety of genres to choose from while practicing state standard fiction and non-fiction reading skills. Students will be practicing skills such as cause and effect, close reading, comparing and contrasting texts, context clues, identifying theme and main idea, sequencing, reading for details, and making inferences. All of these materials will be used as an extension from our whole class mini lesson, and many of the resources also offer an interactive piece allowing students to complete a graphic organizer and other hands-on approaches for those visual learners. I am confident I will be able to meet the needs of my students by integrating and supplementing the interactive resources into our daily curriculum.
needStatement: My students need high-interest reading materials to support both struggling and confident readers during our daily guided reading groups.

name: Reading to Our Families
description: I teach a wonderful group of first graders. Our school is in a vibrant and diverse neighborhood. Each year students are eager to become excellent readers. When the book they want to read is too hard, we always say it isn't a 'just right' book for them YET. They know if they read, read, read, soon that book will be easy for them. Learning to read is one of the most exciting things for the students. I find it pretty great too! 🙂 When they can move up a level they are so excited to discover new books. They just devour any new book they can read. In first grade learning to read is our biggest and most exciting job. Early readers can't just pick up any book at a library and have it be helpful in their goal of reading. It is most helpful to have a book at their 'just right' level. We have a leveled Read At Home Library that allows students to check out books at their level to read to their families. Our Read At Home Library helps promote reading and family involvement. Students love showing off their current skills. Families love having this resource to help their students. Our current library has books that are way past their use. Most are torn or taped. They have been well used and well loved. We want to keep this awesome resource going. We want to promote family involvement and the love of reading.
needStatement: My students need leveled books to take home. Students love to borrow a book at their level to take home and read to their families.

name: Let's Find Out:Tolerance in The Classroom
description: My students and I are part of this wonderful Title I school. We are a very diverse school with many different backgrounds in one. Many students come in not speaking any English and some parents require translators to communicate. Our goal here is to meet the needs of our students. To assist us in meeting these needs, we provide classes for parents to teach them the English language. In September, my children will enter eager yet unsure of what to expect. I will be there to assure them each day that the year will be fun. Each day will be different from the day before, but each day incredibly inspiring as we learn and grow together! These children will make me smile just as much as I make them laugh. I love what I do and look forward to providing them with many opportunities to succeed in the future. My goal is to help my superstars succeed!My children need different seating options to promote tolerance and acceptance of different learning styles. We currently have some Hokki Stools but the addition of these cushions will help build attention for my young learners. I want to create a classroom where everyone can learn in their own way and feel safe and comfortable while doing it. Whether it's a case of the wiggles or an itch to move, my students would greatly benefit from this seating option as they learn and grow with one another. My children also need to learn about the world around them. Holidays, cultures and traditions are briefly touched upon in our current Social Studies program. As a teacher I feel it is very important to teach children to connect to the world as well as others around them. My children need to learn that not everyone celebrates, eats and acts the same way and that is ok. With the help of Scholastic's Let's Find Out magazine subscription each child will have a year worth of nonfiction articles that will enable me to supplement and extent topics in our current program. Children will make connections, ask questions and discuss many topics in detail. It is my hope is that I can help build tolerance within children beginning with my students! Remember they are MY students but OUR future!
needStatement: My students need a subscription of Let's Find Out magazines and wobbly cushions.

name: Subitizing! Number Sense! Addition and Subtraction Facts!
description: My 1st grade students are awesome! We are a caring community of learners who watch out for each other, encourage each other, and show compassion for each other. We are excited to learn about our world and love acquiring new knowledge about how we are connected with our environment. We have a growth mindset in class, which means we might not be able to do something yet, but that doesn't mean we will never be able to do it or learn it. We work like scholars by sticking to the task and having a thirst for knowledge. We spend a lot of time developing number sense in first grade. Having a class set of sturdy Rekenraks will help my math lessons run more smoothly. In the past, I had the students make their own Rekenraks using cardboard, pipe cleaners, and red and white pony beads. However, they don't hold up very well because we use them a lot. I would have to stop the lesson to help a child put their handmade Rekenrak back together. It took precious time away from the lesson. Rekenraks will help my students develop the number sense they need to become fluent mathematicians. Rekenraks will help my students subitize, build a strong sense of 5 and 10, and learn about the relationships among numbers and operations. I know my students will benefit greatly by having a class set and for me a teacher demonstration Rekenrak.
needStatement: My students need a class set of Rekenreks to build their number sense and learn their addition and subtraction math facts.

name: Teaching Tolerance
description: My students are very energetic and love to do hands-on activities. They are very social and are still learning how to interact with their peers. My students love to learn through movement and play. Although my students differ in where they are with their educational needs, they are very supportive and push their peers to be the best they can be. As a class, we love learning together in fun and engaging ways. We love our Kindergarten family and all the fun things that we do! My students need fiction and nonfiction books focused around teaching tolerance. These books will help my students make text to text, text to self, and text to world connections. Through these books, my students can learn skills such as empathy, acceptance, patience and understanding. These books follow specific lessons that teach life long skills. The skills that they learn from these books will transfer into their everyday lives, teaching my students to be kind and caring to one another. With students putting themselves in other peoples shoes and learning tolerance, we can create a classroom built around empathy. We can treat others the way we want to be treated.
needStatement: My students need fiction and nonfiction books that teach them tolerance.

name: Wobble Chairs For Wiggly Students
description: Our students come from a variety of diverse backgrounds, but our elementary school acts as an all-inclusive family to meet the social and academic needs of our learners. Over 60 percent of our scholars are English Language Learners, and over 95 percent of students identify themselves as African American, Asian American, or Hispanic. Over 90 percent of our students qualify for the USDA's Free and Reduced Price School Meals program, meaning that over 250 of our approximately 277 students come from families whose incomes are below the poverty level. A classroom set of Wobble Chairs will allow my students to stay engaged while learning. Our school serves students with a variety of learning needs, and Wobble Chairs allow children with ADHD and Autism to get the movement they need while simultaneously completing classroom work. These chairs rock and spin on a domed base, encouraging active sitting. Our school has very small classrooms. Most rooms are half the size of a regular classroom due to walls that were constructed as enrollment increased. These chairs are lightweight and portable, giving students the freedom to move to a learning space that best suits their needs. Students will be able to move their chairs into the hallway for small group work, take a chair over to our library for independent reading, or form a small learning area for English Language Learners. Wobble Chairs will help these learners take the initiative they need to learn in the unique way that best suits their needs.
needStatement: My students need a classroom set of Wobble Chairs to help them stay engaged while working. These stools give kids an outlet for their energy, and working is no longer sedentary.

name: My Buddy and Me!
description: My students and I are part of this wonderful Title I school. We are a very diverse school with many different backgrounds in one. Many students come in not speaking any English and some parents require translators to communicate. Our goal here is to meet the needs of our students. To assist us in meeting these needs, we provide classes for parents to teach them the English language. In September, my children will enter eager yet unsure of what to expect. I will be there to assure them each day that the year will be fun. Each day will be different from the day before, but each day incredibly inspiring as we learn and grow together! These children will make me smile just as much as I make them laugh. I love what I do and look forward to providing them with many opportunities to succeed in the future. My goal is to help my superstars succeed!Part of teaching tolerance also includes helping my students learn social-emotional skills for regulating emotions and being sensitive to others, as well as building on friendships. This year I plan to do just that with the help of a buddy system. I plan to randomly pair up two children each week for them to get to know each other. They will spend time together as they eat lunch, have fun together during brain breaks and explore during center time. Weekly buddy pairs and pictures will be displayed in the requested pocket charts. With your help buddies can select from the requested center manipulatives to explore together. Buddies can choose from the Alphabet Rockets, Geostix, Gumball Grab, retelling kits and puppets, Snap and Slide math center or the Kinetic Sand Ice Cream center. Each day children will be given brain breaks and explore time where they will be able to share the above mentioned materials with their buddy. As they explore in centers they will learn about one another, share and build friendships. Building tolerance and acceptance of others as well as developing friendships are all important skills that my children will learn with my new weekly buddy system.
