Current literacy research states, '...using authentic texts and giving children choices are powerful and necessary conditions in the development of thinking, learning, and autonomy.' We have super, awesome students at our school who deserve only the BEST!The New York Times #1 Bestseller, WONDER, by R.J.Palacio swept through middle schools lighting a fire of enlightenment. Kids everywhere became aware and tolerant of those with kids with unusual disabilities. WONDER provided an authentic hero who dealt with abuse and intolerance with phenomenal courage. But how did the other children deal with Augie's facial disfigurement? What is their perspective? How did Augie's teacher support him? The additional stories, AUGIE AND ME, THREE WONDER STORIES, will enhance WONDER, help children make connections across texts, and highlight acceptance of differences as opposed to bullying and ostracism. The stories enable children to connect literacy and personal experiences in a realistic manner that will support positive change in our lives. I want them to become proud of who they are, and the contributions that they will eventually make to improve their communities. After completing each novel, the students will create an art project that displays their understandings and interpretations of the novel. 'Tech-to-Stretch' is one project where the children represent their comprehension via an iMovie or Keynote. Another project,'Sketch-to-Stretch' empowers kids to represent their thinking with colors, shapes and symbols. Literacy research has shown that when we 'recast' our thinking in another media we greatly enhance our critical skills.
needStatement: My students need to learn more kindness, tolerance, and acceptance from Augie, the extraordinary child in the NY Times Best-Selling novel WONDER. Let's empower students by reading the perspectives of three classmates and his awesome teacher!

name: Picture Me Learning
description: As a teacher in a low-income/high poverty school district, my students are faced with several challenges both in and out of the classroom. Despite the many challenges they face, I want to give my students an opportunity to learn with technology. Our children are growing up with the expectation of being proficient users of technology. My children are four and five year olds who are excited to explore the world. I want to 'Picture them Learning' by giving them the opportunity to showcase their work with technology. My students use technology a lot in our class. When it is time to print, it's always in black and white. This color printer, ink cartridges, and photo paper will allow my students to print their art projects in color versus me sending them to the print shop and paying money for every color page for every project. An all-in-one printer and ink cartridges would allow my students to bring their artwork to life. They can display their artwork throughout the classroom and take their masterpieces home to share with their families and friends. Having a printer and ink to print out student work in color will amplify their visions. With younger students you have to do all you can to grab and keep their attention. Their work will be displayed in the classroom for all to enjoy, allowing the students to take pride in their accomplishment. The color printer and ink will also allow us to print newsletters and pictures to send home to families. Having a classroom printer is a must in today's world to help students express their creativity through technology. The Clorox Disinfecting Wipes will be used to ensure that the materials that the students are using are properly cleaned and sanitized.
needStatement: My students need a color printer, ink cartridges, and photo paper so they can be 'Pictured Learning.'

name: Exceptional Literacy for Exceptional Learners
description: I teach an exceptional group of first through third graders in Baltimore City in a combined self-contained and resource special education classroom. Most of my students are in my class for the majority of the day, and need significant support in reading and mathematics. We are fortunate to have ample technology, opportunities for creative learning, and field trips at our school. My students are sweet, kind, and excited about learning; I am excited to teach them using the best tools I can find. Planning literacy lessons in a multi-grade special education classroom is challenging, with students at wildly different skill levels, and with wildly different needs. I am seeking professional development to help me meet the needs of all the readers in my room, with engaging materials and activities, and a consistent structure. The Orton-Gillingham approach focuses on every aspect of literacy in a concise, consistent, and engaging way. Students will be able to experience literacy through exploration, touch, and sound, playing while learning. Struggling readers flourish under this research-based, highly recognized system. This professional development, and the tools that I will be able to use because of it, will help me to be a better teacher, and help my students to be better readers and writers.
needStatement: I need professional development to learn highly effective strategies and tools to teach literacy in my self-contained special education classroom.

name: Books and Shelving for Learning!
description: Every morning my students come into my classroom full of life and ready to learn. They like to move, they love to read and they love lots of positive attention from their parents, friends and myself! Despite the many types of challenges each student may face, I am looking to keep things simple and provide my students with creative and meaningful learning experiences. Each student contributes something different within our learning community. As a classroom teacher, I want to provide each one of those students with books that fit their interests. This amazing class wants to be in school every day because they want to learn so that they all can be successful one day! I am asking for different books for my tight knit classroom reading community and bookshelves . Having a diverse population within my class, I have to carefully select a variety of book titles to add to my library. With each book, I have aimed to meet the needs of each skilled reader so they can find a book that they are able to relate to. If these books are donated to our ever-growing classroom, you will not only help to improve students' attention and focus when reading but also promote life long readers. Our library is the center of learning in our diverse population and I can’t wait to see where our learning will take us!
needStatement: My students need books at their independent reading level and two bookshelves to easily access our classroom library .

name: Growing Plants and Young Minds!
description: All children are special! I have a special place in my heart for the children I have taught and are teaching this year. My class this year is diverse. Diverse learners with diverse needs. These are the children I teach. My class is full of readers, thinkers, artists, athletes, musicians, social butterflies, singers, quiet thinkers, and loud talkers. Growing humans from all walks of life. They are wonderful individuals, with amazingly different personalities. They bring interesting and creative pieces to our classroom climate. Each one an important part of the whole. 3rd grade has a big science unit every spring...we grow plants as part of our plant life cycle unit. Students love this unit! In past years, we have had mixed success relying on the weather. In order to grow plants effectively, our classroom desperately needs plant grow lights and gardening supplies. These supplies will enable two 3rd-grade classes to grow squash seeds in the classroom under artificial light, transplant the seedlings, and eventually take the plants home to share with their family! The final goal of the project is for the students to literally have a taste of their hard work! This project will help my students develop a meaningful and real-life understanding of plant life cycles while providing hands-on learning. Studying plants is not only important for 3rd-grade science standards. It's crucial life knowledge. Almost everything we eat comes from plants. Understanding plants is an important step in better understanding health, nutrition, the environment, and the bigger picture of the importance of plants in our world.
needStatement: My students need plant grow lights and gardening supplies to explore our plant life cycle science unit.

name: Urban Kids Get Outside!
description: I teach in a little neighborhood school in a very diverse major city. Our district has one of the largest achievement gaps in the nation. Of the 400+ students in our school, 53% are children of color and 20% receive English Language Learning services. All of our students receive free breakfast at school to help ensure they are ready to learn, and close to half receive free lunch from school. My students are kind, creative, and energized. They fiercely love our school and our community. At recess you hear a variety of languages spoken by our kids. We have students whose parents came to our city, in the past decade, from East Africa playing with Hmong children whose parents made a refugee journey of their own 30 years ago. While our school works hard on academics, we also take time to focus on helping our students be all around good citizens. We practice friendship skills, empathy, and helping your neighbor. We have a strong focus on engaging families through events like our Science Fair, Family Fitness Night, Literacy Night, and a School Carnival. Our 5th grade students will participate in a two night and three day environmental camp. They will learn about local geology, pond ecology and native Minnesota wildlife. My students will spend three days and two nights in the great outdoors and screen free. This field trip will help to combat Nature Deficit Disorder. It will get our students outside, connected with nature, and feeling a connection to the earth and each other. In addition to the science lessons, they will build self confidence through participation in low and high ropes challenge courses, teambuilding with their classmates, taking a night hike under the stars and roasting marshmallow under the stars. This increase in self confidence and increased connection with each other will return them to my classroom more engaged with each other ready to learn.
needStatement: My students need bus transportation to an Environmental Learning Center to learn geology, ecology and leadership skills.

name: A Book a Day Feeds Our Growing Minds!
description: As a teacher in a mixed income from low-income/high poverty to middle class, my students are faced with several challenges both in and out of the classroom. Despite the many challenges and differences my students present, I look to give each one of them a high quality learning experience that will set the tone for their later years in school. My students are thinkers and creators. They like to move, they love to read and love lots of positive attention. Many of them are being raised in single parent households and receive a free breakfast and lunch based on their socioeconomic status. These things may hinder them from getting ahead early in life and may not provide them with the life experiences many of us see as 'typical'. From the minute, they walk in the door of my classroom I focus on their social and surrounding learning. I may not be able to control their home lives, however, I can certainly control their experience during the school day. By doing this in a creative and positive way, I am hopeful to inspire even our earliest learners to continue on a path of academic excellence. The books will enhance the library in our classroom. We are a wide range of learners and have limited resources. Having a plethora of books readily available will help us become better readers but more importantly want to read. As an avid reader, I understand the importance of choices in titles and with these books; my students will open their minds and enjoy books. These books will enhance their reading stamina, interest and set the platform for later years in education. The Magic Tree House books will take the students on an imaginative journey into other worlds. This project I have done yearly and my students always love tracking where Jack and Annie go next. The books will enhance their science and social studies knowledge. The leveled reading sets will give my students the opportunity to have fiction and nonfiction books at their disposal so they are ready for any genre. It will increase their reading levels and make the year more enjoyable. In order to be a successful classroom, it needs to have the tools to learn. These tools will increase that for my students.
needStatement: My students need books to help them soar and become better readers!

name: It's 2017-We Need Computers!
description: I work at a Title I school located in Tacoma, Washington. My class is filled with bright students from diverse backgrounds who come to school excited to learn every day. My students are future engineers, teachers, and politicians, and we are working hard in second grade to prepare for college, career, and citizenship. Because of our diverse backgrounds, my students have diverse strengths and needs. I work hard to plan exciting activities and experiences to meet their needs every day. Seriously though. I do everything on my computer, and my students need to start learning to navigate them in safe and meaningful settings. Students are expected to be proficient with computer use, but don't have access to enough quality technology at home, or in the classroom. Authentic and integrated experiences with technology are only possible if we have access to it. Students will use these Chromebooks to improve math fluency, read relevant nonfiction articles, publish their writing, create art, write code, and more. The possibilities are endless, and so are the opportunities that having access to this technology will open up for my students.
needStatement: My students need 8 quality but affordable Chromebooks to help bring us into the 21st century.

name: Financial Literacy:Freedom for the Future
description: My students are from a low income and high poverty area with parents that strive to provide a quality education for their children. They may come with disadvantages but they deserve the most out of their education that I can provide them. They are mostly on free and reduced lunch . They are kids eager to learn and thirst for knowledge. Many of our students were affected by Hurricane Harvey, but continue to come to school eager for a safe place to learn and grow. Reading books about introducing money to low income students is important to build a foundation of what money is and how it is used correctly on a daily basis. Many children are not taught the correct way to save, borrow, spend and make money. Reading books about all the different ways money is used and how we are consumers, borrowers and lenders are all important things to teach children early on. Children need good role models to help them see good examples of all the ways to use money. They games that will be used will help them count, borrow, spend and use different coins together to learn how money is used in our everyday world.
needStatement: My students need financial literacy books and games to help them become more productive in society.

name: Flexible Seating And Movement Options!
description: My students come from all backgrounds. Our school has a sixty-three percent rate of free or reduced price lunch. Thirty-six percent of our learners are English Language Learners. We also have a population of seventeen percent which are Special Education Students. Arts residencies, partnership and field trips, along with multiple art performances and exhibits in our school are all a part of the Linwood Monroe Arts Plus model. The students at LMAP enjoy showing their learning through art, dancing, singing and various other ways that match their learning styles. It is a fabulous school to attend where everyone is welcome!These materials will impact my students' learning in fabulous ways. Students will be able to choose their flexible seat, standing desk, etc. in order to help them with their focusing and maintaining attention. My students benefit from moving and being able to sit in a chair or choose the desk that best fits their needs. Flexible seating and standing desks give my students an opportunity to stay engaged and meet their needs at the same time. Most often when I see my students in the afternoon, they are tired of sitting. Having these other options to offer my students would increase student engagement and motivation in class. If my students would have the option of which ergonomic chair they'd like to sit on, or be able to work at a standing desk, they would have the motivation to stay engaged and complete their work.
needStatement: My students need flexible seating options such as an exercise ball, a Kore teen chair, a standing desk and a bungee chair.

name: Future Builders of America
description: I teach at a fantastic elementary school, and my students are amazing. They are such hard workers and approach the world around them with such curiosity and intensity. My students are all unique individuals who all want the opportunity to thrive in today’s fast paced world. They come from many backgrounds, walks of life, and face many economic barriers. Seventy percent of my school's student body qualifies for free or reduced price lunch. Simply stated, that means that many of my students come from households at or near the poverty line. Poverty generates instability and fear and simultaneously robs students of many enriching experiences their more stable, wealthier counterparts are able to receive. My students are bold, eager learners. My students are dedicated. My students are important! There is a quote by the great education reformer Horace Mann that truly sums up the importance of education. “Education…beyond all other devices of human origin, is a great equalizer of conditions of men--the balance wheel of the social machinery…It does better than to disarm the poor of their hostility towards the rich, it prevents being poor.'We spent many days inside due to bad air quality already this year and then many days indoors because of winter weather for an entire month the playground was covered in ice and we were forced to have indoor recess every day. I want my students to have the opportunity to build, collaborate, and create. Magna Tiles are wonderful manipulatives that help students learn to make creative designs. Brain Flakes are wonderful too! These are are also tools that help you build and these really encourage imagination and help develop spatial thinking. Building is a great way to develop hand strength and it's also a ton of fun too. In the school setting students need hand strength to use their pencils for writing or their fingers for typing classwork.
needStatement: My students need Magna Tiles and Brain Flakes to help them work on being creative builders and to give them something to do during the many indoor recesses they'll have.

name: Learning Through Music for Early Childhood Special Education
description: The students in our class are 3-5 year olds with special needs. They are from many different races and cultures. There are many different languages spoken by the students and their families. Our school is located in the inner city and many families are low income or poverty level. The children in our class have very low or no verbal language. Many of their other developmental skills: cognitive, fine motor, self care, and social/emotional/behavioral development are also well below age level. While we use music in the classroom, the money from this project will give the students an opportunity to work with teaching artists that are also board certified music therapists and have experience working with children with special needs. Donations to this project will help fund Learning Through Music groups for 15 weeks in our classroom. During Learning Through Music, students will learn academic and arts concepts that are embedded into the music activities (instrument play, singing, finger plays, sensory/relaxation, and movement). The students will also have the opportunity to transfer skills practiced and learned during music group to the classroom as the teacher and special education aides will also participate in the learning. While we use music in the classroom, the money from this project will give the students an opportunity to work with teaching artists that are also board certified music therapists and have experience working with children with special needs.
needStatement: My students need donations for direct service hours for the teaching artists to come into our classroom.

name: Dream Chasers Wear Sneakers
description: I work with 50 amazing Kindergarten students as an EL (English Learners) teacher. I co-teach content areas with two outstanding classroom teachers, and I also pull small groups of beginning level English speakers out for targeted instruction. My school is comprised of ~70% EL students. Many of our children are recent immigrants and are also adjusting to their new life in the U.S. All students at my school receive free breakfast and lunch, and we rely on community partners to help provide school uniforms and supplies to families in need. My students are eager to learn about the world around them and are hard workers! Ill-fitting shoes are no fun! Each day I see my students wearing shoes that are too big, too small, too stiff, too worn or too stinky. Many of them have sores and blisters from improper footwear. How can they be expected to do their best learning with sore feet? Cinderella is proof that a new pair of shoes can change your life. Many of my students are new to the country. Their families arrive here with very little and parents usually have to provide their child(ren) with used shoes. All students deserve a new pair of shoes that are the correct size, sturdy, comfortable and have a velcro closure. Please help me provide simple athletic shoes to my Kindergarten students!
needStatement: My students need sturdy, velcro, athletic shoes that are the correct size for them.

name: Books and Foot Bands and Fidgets, Oh MY!
description: This year I am honored to be teaching 14 4th graders. It has only been a month into school and already they have taught me so much about who they are and what they are going to need in order to be successful this school year. My students are so grateful and find pleasure in anything that is gifted to them. Most of my students are from lower income home and share these homes with other siblings and family. You may think of a fourth grader as still a young child, which really they are, but you would be so shocked at some of the responsibilities my students take on in their day to day life. The are my fantastic fourth grade and I know their hearts would be so much more full is this project was funded. We encourage our children to read and share their reading with others. That is what I am hoping to achieve through the class set of Tale of Despereaux. This is one of my favorite books and if funded I would love to share it with my students. There are so many different literary elements within this novel so it is a great teaching resource. Each child learns differently and needs materials in order for them to be successful. Their success is my main goal. With the foot bands and sensory fidgets, my students will be able to focus and learn and apply all of the wonderful knowledge they have stored.
needStatement: My students need the book: Tale of Despereaux to explore a world of new adventure outside of the classroom in their mind. They also need foot bands and fidgets so they can focus and become successful.

name: New York City Elementary School Students Breathe for Change
description: This is my 16th year as an educator. I started my career as a special education classroom teacher and have been working as school social worker for the past 10. As a trained mental health professional I assist with mental health concerns, behavioral concerns, positive behavioral support, academic and classroom support, consultation with teachers, parents and administrators as well as provide individual and group counseling/therapy. My school is a high poverty school in New York City. All of our students receive free lunch. Ninety-seven percent of our student population is Black or Latino; many are first generation Americans. Our students are faced with many challenges inside and outside the classroom. They struggle personally and academically. Thirty percent of our students receive Special Education services. Despite the challenges they face daily, my students are happy and motivated to learn. Working with the children and families has truly been a highlight of my career. A few months ago, I began a personal mindfulness and yoga practice which allowed me a glimpse of the joyful and free person I could be. This joy was a result of my increased ability to be present and respond to my environment, which included my students, parents and co-workers. My sessions became more calm and productive as I learned to really be present for my students. Since then, I’ve tried to facilitate a mindfulness practice for my students, but I would love the opportunity to be trained in how to do this more effectively.I have been accepted to attend teacher training via Breathe For Change. The Breathe For Change values give educators a framework to lead with love in their lives, relationships and communities. Breathe For Change training draws upon the growing body of research linking mind-body wellness practices such as mindfulness and yoga to stress reduction, enhanced executive function, and increased emotional regulation. Executive function, which encompasses working memory and higher order thinking tasks, can be disrupted due to emotional dysregulation. Mindfulness promotes our ability to regulate emotion, which is key to coming back into control when strong emotions arise. In situations where children are stressed or experiencing anxiety, learning is difficult, if not impossible. Participation in this training will allow me the opportunity to earn the RYT 200 certification so I can safely support the social emotional needs of students who might not otherwise have access to mindfulness and yoga. After seeing how much my personal practice changed my personal and professional life, I can only imagine the transformation that would occur if my students had a regular mindfulness and yoga practice as well.
needStatement: I need financial assistance for a 200-hour wellness and yoga teacher training designed specifically for educators.

name: Rock, Paper, Scissors...Kindle Fires!
description: We love to learn! My first graders are working hard every day, and so am I! These six and seven year olds are learning to read, have become writers and have made big gains in math. We are busy all day long, and there's still much to do. My students are in first grade, and love coming to school to learn!They come from a wide variety of living situations. Some come from two parent homes, some from single parents, and some with multiple generations, or multiple families living in one apartment. Some of my students speak English fluently, and some do not. Some of my students come from families who support public education and encourage their students to do their best while at school. While at school, I hold high expectations for each student in their behavior and their academics, no matter their home life. We learn together, we work through problems together, and we celebrate successes together. Helping my students learn the skills of reading and math will help them for their entire lives.I am asking for two Kindle Fires kids Editions. These come with a free year of Amazon Free Time Unlimited and a kids proof case. We will be able to use this for reading and math practice. There are many apps available such as books that are read to the students to help them learn fluency, and math games that can reinforce skills taught in class. I plan to use these during reading and math groups. This donation of 2 Kindle Fires will allow my students to practice important academic skills and be exposed to using a touch screen, building their technology skills too. These materials will allow the students more time with technology, and will help prepare them for tests, as well as giving them time to practice reading and math activities. . Some students have little or no access to technology in their homes, so the practice at school is critical to help them prepare to show what they know on the state assessments.
needStatement: My students need more experience with technology, these Kindle Fires, will help improve their reading, math and technology skills.

name: The ABC's Are the Magic Key!
description: For almost all of my students, PreK is their very first experience in a school and I am their first teacher. I want my students to develop a deep love of learning. My school serves almost all low-income students, with many students speaking English as their second language. I believe it is my duty as a teacher to help close the achievement gap. One of the ways to do that is to make school a fun and inviting place. However, this requires resources that go beyond my teacher's income. I love my scholars and they deserve the best! One of the most critical academic pieces that I teach my PreK scholars is letter recognition. Children must be able to recognize letters (upper and lower case) as it enables pre-readers to make the connection between words on paper (text) and our verbal communication. Children need to see letters in a variety of contexts to internalize their individual shape, name and sound. All of the materials that I put on my wish list will help me teach my scholars letter recognition in a hands-on and motivating way! The letter tubs will help children see the connection between letters and their individual sounds by seeing different objects that start with the letter. They will be able to touch and play with the objects while repeating the letter name and sound. I also put on my wish list letter cards that the children can use expo markers to practice writing letters and can easily wipe off and begin again. My scholars love play-doh and when I saw the play-doh letter cards I knew that my young scholars would want to practice making letters all day long with these cards and play-doh! The ABC's are the magic key to opening the door to reading and we must make sure all children are given every opportunity to succeed.
needStatement: My students need alphabet manipulatives and games to learn to visually recognize letters and identify them, as this opens the door to reading.

name: Math supplies for EL students
description: My students are 64% free and reduced lunch and 35% are English language learners. I work at an arts magnet school in inner city Saint Paul. Students take classes in visual arts, band, dance, and performing arts. In one of my classes, all 15 of the students who I am teaching math to are new to the country. Watching these students understand the English to be able to access the math is exciting. Each and every day they come with excitement to learn and grow. I'm requesting Original Judy Clocks, digital timers, and Time Timers. Students need to learn foundational skills such as telling time to be able to fill out planners and for time management alongside their peers. The students also need Numeracy Building Fraction Fluency and Magnet Beginning Fractions kits. We'll use the Power Practice Pre-Algebra, Algebra Puzzles, and math flash cards to practice mental math. With these types of materials math facts can become automatic and develop foundational skills. Students are able to take materials and work with other students without having a teacher directly with them in a cooperative learning situation at the same time of practicing speaking. These supplies can also be used by EL teachers in different classrooms to reach the needs of our varying student needs. Materials will be able to be passed between classrooms and to be used in future years. It is important for these students to learn foundational skills to have the ability to access grade level material. I am also requesting some resource materials that I can use to print and have the students work at stations with. I want the students to have visuals to practice the skills but also space to practice the language component of math with. The timers that I requested are so that again we can attach a visual as the students are learning time. Additionally, it will be used as they are rotating around to different stations. One resource that I am particularly excited about is the book about problem solving with struggling readers. We know that if students can't understand a word problem from reading it there is no way that they are able to access applying the math knowledge that they know. Finally, I have requested three standing desks. These are to have in my classroom for students that need to move, need to not be confined to sitting, and for those students who have unique needs and need their own learning space.
needStatement: My students need Judy Clocks, fraction kits and other materials for new ideas on how to approach learning math and to develop foundational skills.

name: Sewing Club
description: We are a title one school in North Fort Myers, Florida. Our students are low income and live in a pretty tough area. All of our students are on the free breakfast and lunch program. Our teachers do what it takes to make our students successful. Being a title one school is a challenge; many of our students are from broken homes where a single mom or dad has to work most of the time just to pay the rent and put food on the table. We try to make our school their second home; a safe place to spend eight hours a day, eat breakfast and lunch and experience opportunities that they otherwise wouldn't have means to do at home. Students will learn to sew on sewing machines to make various projects including t-shirt bags and dresses. The project will end with students making a dress for themselves as well as dresses to Dress a Girl Around the World. By having sewing machines, t-shirts, and material to actually learn to sew with will become an experience that will carry them through life. Dress a Girl Around the World is an organization to protect girls from Human Trafficking. 'We dream of a world in which every girl has at least one new dress. We want girls to know that they are worthy and respected...,'
needStatement: My students need Singer 4423 heavy duty model sewing machines, t-shirts, material, and supplies.

name: The Digital Art Room
description: We come from a small, rural community in SC. I grew up in the same town and attended the same school. I know where all these kids come from and where they are capable of going. They are smart, creative, and energetic. I teach art to about 175 ninth through twelfth grade students each year. These students vary dramatically in ability level and socioeconomic status. Recently, our budget was cut and we are very unsure about what we will be able to do in the art room next year. My students need tablets to help them photograph their work and submit it to their online digital portfolios. They will also be able to use apps that help them edit photos, create digital pieces of art, and research ideas for future pieces. Having access to the internet, art apps, and photo-taking capabilities right in the classroom will dramatically increase our productivity and raise interest in our projects. A state standard in Visual Arts Education is for students to keep and maintain a portfolio of their work. With full class loads, minimal room, and students creating larger pieces of art it makes the art teacher's life so much easier to use a digital platform for storing work. Teachers are even able to grade this work faster and are able to provide much more effective feedback to students.
needStatement: My students need three android style tablets and supplies to protect the tablets from frequent student-use.

name: Book Sets for Special Needs Students
description: My school is an urban option school that parents can choose for their children. My students are an enthusiastic group of second and third graders who are excited about learning. Many of my students, however, face significant learning challenges. I have students who face the challenge of dyslexia, ADHD, autism, visual tracking issues, and other learning disabilities. These special needs can impact their ability to access the skills and concepts I am teaching. Watching my students succeed and become confident learners inspires me to find more ways to support them. When reading is a significant challenge, high interest books are essential! My students need interesting low-level book sets, including fiction and non-fiction. I want my students to be able to read books that are interesting to them, no matter what their reading level. Learning to read can be frustrating when all the 'good books' seem to be out of your range. These high-interest books are at levels that struggling readers can access and enjoy! My students will use these sets of books at guided reading time where they get support in a small group from a teacher. Because the book sets are at a variety of levels, I will be able to work with students at their just-right level. These books will also be used at independent reading time. By having five of each book kids will be able to support each other as they learn to read. With your support my students' lives will be forever changed by learning to love reading!
needStatement: My students need fun and interesting books at their just-right reading levels!

name: Music Folders
description: Our band and choir students are dedicated to pursuing excellence. My students are working diligently, and I tell them as often as I can how proud I am to be their teacher. We are a small community near Springfield, and the number of students participating in music is growing. We have a combined junior high and high school band working together to learn music for our concert. My students and I are excited for an amazing year, and I know they can accomplish great things. We are looking to start traveling to perform. The students are proud of the work they're accomplishing, and we would like to participate in festivals, observe other groups perform, and work with clinicians from across the United States. These music folders would ensure that the students' music is safe during transport. Music folders will help students feel comfortable bringing their music to and from school for practice and transporting music when we start performing at new venues. These folders will have our school's name written on the outside, and students will feel proud not only of their musical progress but also of being a member of our school.
needStatement: My students need durable music folders to stay organized, protect music, and give a professional appearance.

name: Learning Through Performance Arts
description: Every day I have the opportunity to work with talented actors, singers, dancers, engineers, and artists. I am not referring to my colleagues. I am referring to my 7th and 8th grade students. I teach musical theatre at an under-served Title 1 School in Pennsylvania. My musical theatre class helps students build healthy relationships and build self-esteem. My class is a place for students to cultivate their skills and it gives students the confidence to break out of their comfort zone and be a part of an inclusive environment, conducive to both their academic and social growth. I introduce my students to various aspects of theatre. My students are exposed to both the art (dancing, singing, make-up, costume design) and science (music technology, lighting, stage crew, prop production) of musical theatre. Despite the challenges that my students face inside and outside the classroom, they arrive to class excited to create, but they need the resources and technology to make their creative ideas come to life. These materials will make a difference in my students learning by providing them with the necessary materials that they need to explore various aspects of theater, and give my students insight on the work that goes into the theatrical process. These materials will also allow my students to foster their creativity. The glue guns and spray paint that I requested will be used to create props and set pieces. My students will plan, design and construct the set pieces. They will use wood and the plastruct styrene sheets to build a set. They will also have the opportunity to experiment with various fabrics to create costumes. The scissors with helps them make precise cuts on fabric and other materials. The Bluetooth speakers will allow students to rehearse choreography and music. The speakers are portable and can go from classroom to performance area - expanding my classroom and students' learning beyond my classroom and onto the stage. These materials will also allow my students to combine the arts with science, literature, and technology. This project is part of a cross curriculum learning experience that will culminate into a production that my students will be proud of because they are involve in every aspect of this creation. The students will benefit from this project by gaining hands on experience with technology, set design, and construction. This project will expand my students’ thinking and will show them that arts and science can combine to create magic. I want my students to know that anything is possible with hard work and imagination.
needStatement: My students need these items for their theater class and theatrical production. We will use them to create costumes, set design and construction.

name: Chromebooks for Learning
description: My third grade students love to learn new things and use technology in the classroom. We are fortunate that we are one of the few one to one laptop classrooms in our school which allows us to incorporate technology in all subjects. We are a STEAM Academy where the focus is on science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics. Most of my students are low income and don't have the ability to use technology at home. They are are coming from the surrounding areas to attend a school that is often times better than their neighborhood school. Las Vegas also tends to have a very transient population, and many kids are constantly moving either into, out of, or around the city. As our classroom technology becomes outdated we need to continuously update our technology to provide learning opportunities for our students. We have several schoolwide programs such as ST math, Reading Plus, and Star Reading that require access to the internet. The chromebooks will be used several times throughout the day to access our schoolwide programs and to create online projects. As we are teaching 21st-century skills such as coding the students need technology that can keep pace with the skills they are learning. Having access to technology that is updated and current help students complete projects quicker and improves their experience using technology.
needStatement: My students need two Asus Chromebooks to replace outdated classroom technology.

name: Fantastic Flexible Seating for a Fun Classroom
description: Like many first grade classrooms, my students all come with their own unique set of strengths and challenges. Most of my students have a lot of energy and tend to be more productive when moving around while learning. Children, like most adults, are not able to sit still all day. These children should have productive and safe ways to move so they are able to do their best work. In our district, like many others in the area, funding is limited for materials that are not considered essential supplies. My students need wobble chairs, wobble cushions, bean bag chairs, and stability balls to provide them constructive and safe ways to use their energy while learning. My students are always excited to be at school each day. They come in full of energy to learn and throughout the day, this energy never fades. I have found that these children are much more productive and remember what they are learning when given opportunities to move throughout the day. Students will be able to move in a constructive and safe ways while doing their work, which will allow for students to spend more time learning and having academic successes and spend less time focused on needing to sit still. Implementing flexible seating allows students to sit in a type of seat that is best for them. It gives students a choice about their seat and when students have choices, they take more ownership of the classroom and their personal decisions. Using alternative seating will help reduce distractions because students will have the opportunity to, and be encouraged to, move around during the day while getting their work done. Children are not all the same and their needs for different seating options are as diverse as each student is.
needStatement: My students need wobble stools, wobble cushions, bean bag chairs, chair bands and stability balls to provide positive, safe and constructive movement in the classroom.

name: Best Seat in the Room!
description: Take a seat! I need alternative seating in my classroom to accommodate different student learning styles. I have been a public school teacher in a suburban area for thirty-one years. Currently, I have the privilege of teaching a diverse group of gifted and talented third grade students. My wish is to provide each of my students with alternative seating that will increase student activity and student motivation! Alternative seating keeps students mentally and physically engaged by burning more calories, using up excess energy, improving metabolism, creating a better oxygen flow to the brain, and improving core strength and overall posture. In fact, physical activity is linked to higher academic performance, better health, and improved behavior! The stability ball and Wobble seats all increase physical activity in the classroom! ENGAGEMENT! I am requesting stability balls and Wobble chairs because research shows that students are more focused on learning when their brain is stimulated. When students seat on chairs that require students to keep their bodies centered on the balls and chairs it stimulates their brain. When the brain is stimulated, it's more focused on learning! Not only is the brain better suited to processing new information, young minds are also better able to concentrate on exams, note-taking, class discussions, and other aspects of classroom learning! For students that struggle with focusing, the active engagement provided by the stability balls and Wobble chairs are invaluable to keeping their attention on classroom instruction!
needStatement: My students need Wobble chairs and stability balls to actively engage in classroom learning.

name: Let There Be Light
description: Light Cube, Braille books, white canes, iPads, and magnification domes. All of these words help describe some of the equipment my students might use during their school day. All of my students have some type of visual impairment. They attend a public school in a district with 38,000 students where 72 languages are spoken. There is a large immigrant population, of which my students are no exception. Braille, American Sign Language (ASL), and various types of assistive technology are just some tools my students use during their school day. Ranging in ages from ages 5-17 years of age, each student has individual methods to how they view educational materials. Some use magnification tools to enlarge the print size. Some need low light conditions while others need the brightest lights possible. Several are learning to read braille. During the school week, I travel to many schools to provide one-on-one instruction. My car looks like a gypsie wagon, packed full with items like a Light Cube, braille books, white canes and magnification domes. Thomas Edison produced the first commercially viable light bulb, an invention that literally changed the way we live after dark. For many of my students, increased light helps them visually attend to printed educational materials. Last year, generous donations were made through Donors Choose which provided a Light Cube to be used by several of my students. This cube is a BIG hit. So, taking a great success story to the next level, I found another source of bright light. Designed much like a flat screen television, the Tabletop Light is placed on top of a student’s desk. The student can independently adjust the amount of light used to view educational material. I like the Tabletop Light because it lays flat on top of the student’s desk, is portable, light weight, and can be adjusted to a very bright setting. An accessory human x-ray kit can be purchased as additional classroom material. While the x-rays are just really fun to look at, the kit does meet STEM standards. My students need this tabletop light panel to become another addition to my gypsie wagon so they can use bright light to visually attend to educational materials.
needStatement: My students need this Tabletop Light Panel and Human X-Ray set to become another addition to my gypsie wagon so they can use bright light to visually attend to educational materials.

name: 'Moulding' Young Minds
description: My students are bright and full of energy, and they love school! They will walk into my classroom in the fall, never have gone to school before! By the end of each year, I am always amazed on how much they have learned and grown! They walk in the door everyday with a smile on their faces and ready to learn! Ninety-eight percent of the students at my school are from single parent, low socio-economic homes who receive free or reduced price lunches. I firmly believe that a child's background does not predict his/her future, and all children are capable of learning, including each of my pre-schoolers!Play dough is not only fun, but it is also very fundamental in an early childhood classroom environment! I am requesting play dough and play dough tools to mainly help develop and strengthen my student's fine motor skills. Play dough also fosters cooperative play. My students will learn the importance of sharing while playing with the play dough. They can discuss what has been made which helps build communication skills and develops their imagination. Play dough is such an 'open ended toy.' Play dough can be ANYTHING...food, animals, faces, shapes, numbers, letter etc...the possibilities are endless! Please help 'MOLD' our minds!
needStatement: My students need play dough, play dough tools and alphabet play dough mats so my student's can utilize their creativity while developing their dexterity, physical, cognitive, and fine motor skills.

name: Magic Reading Carpet
description: I have the best job in the world! I am super fortunate to work with wonderful children who are eager to learn! Our classroom is a place where we are free to make mistakes and we learn from each other. ! We are one big family! We are a diverse school located in the suburbs of NY. I am constantly learning from my students each day. They have taught me so much and I believe they make me a better person because of it! A student who has been having some difficulties in school and Home asked me yesterday if I would be his Mom. There is so much more to teaching than just academics, many times we are so much more to these beautiful children. This carpet will impact the children in a positive way. Every classroom needs an inviting, cozy area where the children can come together to learn. I would place the carpet in front of the smart board where a lot of our interactive activities take place. This “magical” carpet will be the focal point of our classroom. It will be where the children can read independently, listen to engaging stories, collaborate with a writing partner, solve math problems, conduct science experiments. The list is endless!!! The design of the carpet is awesome and each student can choose a particular square to sit on. That in itself prevents anyone from complaining that they are squished! It would be a wonderful addition to our Reader’s Workshop Area! In addition, it would be a nice area for the students in my class that need a break from traditional seating.
needStatement: My students need a classroom rug where they can read independently and share ideas with each other.

name: Takin' it to the Hoop!
description: My students are lower socio-economic students that love to play games of all sorts! We're a diverse school and have a small gym to use and a large field when it's nice out, although it can be challenging in Minnesota winters. What we are striving for is smaller pieces of equipment that can supply 25-30 students, a class of mainly primary students. I teach 22 classes and new equipment will go a long way to our supplies. We truly appreciate any and all support!My students need ten additional basketballs and a tape measure for activities during and after school activities. These basketballs will be used for our primary students and elementary students in a pinch. The focus is to work on dribbling and hand-eye coordination. Our current basketballs are worn and old so these 10 would be an immense improvement. The tape measure is going to be used for our track and field day. Our current one is not usable for our long jump/rubber chicken throw and a new one will 'go far' for the students! Being a former track and field coach, a good tape measure is a need to show students their progress and validate how they're doing. Thank you!
needStatement: My students need ten additional basketballs and a tape measure for activities during and after school activities.

name: The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian Class Set
description: I work with a diverse group of 4th and 5th graders. They are curious, creative, and determined. My students are passionate about learning about the world around them. We are small urban school serving approximately 320 students in grades PreK through 5. The school has been part of the community for 125 years. Our families are dedicated to the success of their child, former students now teach at our school or send their children and grandchildren to learn in the same community they did. Children are affected by what they see around them, and it helps them to grow. For white children, they also suffer from not seeing the true nature of the world around them. It can distort the world around them and their connections to other humans. All children can learn from the richness of culture. The 4th and 5th grade teachers need a classroom set of The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian to improve literacy and expose our students to diverse characters that represent the students that are in our classrooms. When students are able to see characters that represent their diverse cultures, they become more invested in reading and get to learn about different cultures.
needStatement: My students need engaging books that represent characters with diverse backgrounds.

name: We Take Pride in Our Work
description: Our Spanish Dual Immersion class is a unique, creative and cheerful bunch. We are a smaller community of mostly students from Central America, Mexico and mixed ethnicities in a Korean community in Los Angeles. We treasure and welcome diversity. Despite of the various socio-emotional and financial hardships they face on their daily lives, they remain positive and enthusiastic about experiencing the world through their own eyes. As a class, we virtually enjoy traveling to other countries by learning about their history, government, geography, religion, economy, daily challenges and more. We look forward to working on projects that increase their academic understanding and showcase their work.A multipurpose laser jet printer will support the students' creativity by making their projects more visually enhanced in color. Both classroom bulletin boards, in the classroom and in the hall will be more attractive and colorful. Currently, the students report having difficulty accessing color printers in their homes. They will now be able to print their work, projects and assignments in class. In addition, we will be able to print on-going correspondence to the parents by printing logs, charts, notifications and newsletters with pictures of their children participating in instruction, their work and on-going learning. As a teacher, I will be able to use my time more efficiently by making copies without leaving the classroom.
needStatement: My students need a color printer to showcase their creativity in their academic work.

name: Inspire STEM Learning
description: We love to learn! My first graders are working hard every day, and so am I! These six and seven year olds are learning to read, have become writers and have made big gains in math. We are busy all day long, and there's still much to do. My students are in first grade, and love coming to school to learn!They come from a wide variety of living situations. Some come from two parent homes, some from single parents, and some with multiple generations, or multiple families living in one apartment. Some of my students speak English fluently, and some do not. Some of my students come from families who support public education and encourage their students to do their best while at school. While at school, I hold high expectations for each student in their behavior and their academics, no matter their home life. We learn together, we work through problems together, and we celebrate successes together. Helping my students learn the skills of reading and math will help them for their entire lives.STEM learning conveys how science, technology, engineering and mathematics work together in the real world. Science is everywhere in the world around us, while technology is continuously expanding into most areas of our lives. Engineering is the basic design of roads, dams & bridges, but also tackles the challenges of reaching farther into space and using solar energy. Mathematics is essential for most occupations. By exposing students to STEM learning and giving them opportunities to explore STEM-related concepts, they will hopefully develop a passion for it while they are young that will carry into their adult lives. STEM education creates critical thinkers, increases science literacy, and enables the next generation of innovators.STEM activities provide hands-on and minds-on lessons for the student. Making math and science both fun and interesting helps the student to do much more than just learn, and allows creativity and problem solving. This teacher's guide, and picture books will help teach 15 kid-friendly lessons that convey how science, technology, engineering, and mathematics intersect in the real world. Reading comprehension strategies are embedded into the STEM subjects and English language arts through high-quality picture books. I will help my students engage in STEM activities while learning to read and reading to learn.
needStatement: My students need the lessons found in this Picture-Perfect STEM collection to help build their minds in Science, Math, Engineering & Technology skills!

name: Kindergarteners Seeking Crisp Fall Books
description: I work with a classroom full of motivated and kind children. They are lively Kindergarteners living in St. Paul, Minnesota. We are a school with entirely free lunch and breakfast. It is a school that offers unique programming to fit the needs of our population. We are constantly in need of new hands on materials, especially books! My urban Kindergarten scholars are successful when they share their voice and choice! I'm hoping to better supply my classroom for their needs. My class is in need of new books that reflect the diversity of my students. These books will be used for whole group instruction and will be read by students independently in our classroom library. My students deserve a classroom library that has stories about children of all races living, loving, and learning. We are in need of books that tell stories of leadership and how our environment is always changing. Our fall unit of study involves learning why seasons change and how we use our routines in school to learn best, the books on my list will help teach these important lessons!
needStatement: My students need books that reflect our study of change and the diversity in our classroom!

name: Traveling Through a Good Book
description: My students are eager learners. They welcome every challenge and risk to increase their learning. Many of students have challenges that are out of their control. However, they try to be productive and learn in a steadfast, globalizing and technology-centered generation. The students at my school and in my class receive free lunch and are Title I students; this means that many them are without books, computers and other resources that can help them to be successful in their education. However, despite these odds, my students continue to think, believe, create, and inspire me, themselves and the other students in the school. These kiddos have the potential to be great leaders of the community as they grow up and become adults. These books will my students to enhance their reading skills. Also, these books will help my students to develop a love of reading. Students will be encouraged to check out the books, so they can use true print materials at home to read and not just worksheets. Due to my students being Title One school, many of my students do not have books at home. Also, my school does not allow students to check out and take books home. These books will be a great asset as students build their word knowledge and comprehension skills. Plus, the books can help students to learn how words are used in print in a hands-on manner.
needStatement: My students need a variety of books that are on their level so that they can grow as readers and learn to enjoy reading.

name: We Are Mighty, Like Freak the Mighty!
description: My students are incredible. I could never describe them in one word. They are students that come from low-income families and have a wide range of special needs. These students never let their disability stop them from reaching their goals. They work hard, harder than an average student. We have a lot of fun together and they truly are 'my kids.' They make me want to be a better teacher every day and I am always looking for ways to help them. Best friends are really important, especially to children in middle school. Appearances are also extremely important. So what happens when your best friend is some one who looks different from everyone else?Freak the Mighty is an extraordinary story about two friends who beat the odds and form an amazing bond and we need to read this story! My class needs a class set of this amazing book so we can read the story together in book clubs. Right now we only have one copy and it is very hard for my students to follow along. Please help us get a class set of this amazing book.
needStatement: My students need a class set of the wonderful book Freak the Mighty.

name: Eager Musicians Need Instruments
description: When my students pick up an instrument for the first time, they have no idea where it will take them or the joy playing will bring them. They're just excited to try something new. We are an urban school in Minnesota with bright, creative students. Our band program has been expanding so quickly that I do not have enough instruments for my students. Since starting at my school in 2012, the number of students in band has grown from 38 to over 200! This is a great problem to have, but even after years of generous donations by countless individuals, finding affordable used instruments, and borrowing/trading with other schools, we still don't have enough instruments for every student who wants to be in band. These trumpets would mean three students who can't otherwise afford an instrument will be able to participate in band. These instruments will not only give the students that play them an enriching opportunity to learn the trumpet, it will give them a chance to identify as musicians. Playing one of these trumpets could give a student who might struggle in other academic areas a chance to shine. Making music is special. Studies have shown a link between reading and math scores and making music. This project will bring three trumpets into my classroom and into the hands of students who wouldn't otherwise be able to afford this experience. Please help me create an amazing experience for my students!
needStatement: My students need trumpets in order to support a growing band program.

name: Books to Build On
description: My students are young moms or moms-to-be. They come to our school for extra support for their academics, life situation, health, and planning for their future and the future of their children. One hundred percent of our students qualify for free lunch. Most of the students we serve are from the African American, Latina, Hmong, and Karen community in St. Paul. My students are motivated to create a better life for themselves and their child (or children). They want to be good role models and encourage their children to read. I always tell them that if they don't like reading, it is because they haven't found the right book. I believe this is true, and I work hard to get the right book into their hands. Finding the right book for a student that believes she hates reading is not easy. Over the last few years, I have discovered the secret formula to get everyone in my school reading. It is simple: just buy the books they ask for. When I do this, my students get very excited about reading, and they tell their friends to read 'their' books. Once they have discovered that they actually do enjoy reading, they do branch out and read other titles. We do not have a library or librarian in our small school for pregnant and parenting teens, so these books will make a big difference. After these books are read by the student who requested them, they will become part of my classroom library. I have also requested multiple copies of very popular books that students always seem to 'forget' to return. Though in a typical library this loss might be seen as a problem, I see it differently. These books are now in the homes and homeless shelters where my students live.
needStatement: My students need books that they are interested in reading; these are books that they have requested.

name: Listening and Learning
description: We are a classroom of exceptional 3rd, 4th, and 5th graders. Our students have various disabilities including Autism, Down Syndrome, Intellectual Disabilities, Traumatic Brain Injuries, and Developmental Delays. Our students love to learn, sing, dance, and play. We love to read and love to have fun while learning. Our students learn best hands-on and when their curriculum is personalized and individualized. We try to cater to each students' individual educational, emotional, and social needs. We are in a Title I school. My students need headphones in order to successfully access their iPads in class. We use so many different apps in the classroom to enhance student learning and practice new skills. Due to the nature of our special education classroom, it can get very noisy while students are using these resources. Having these headphones would provide a comfortable and quiet environment for my students to use technology to learn, and would prevent disruptions. Students would be able to focus on the task at hand instead of processing all of the sounds from both students around them and iPads being used near them.
needStatement: My students need headphones to use while learning on their iPads.

name: Math Book Bonanza!
description: My class is filled with second and third graders that are active and enthusiastic learners. Over 30% of my classroom has special education needs. The special learning needs in my classroom vary, but include dyslexia, autism, and sensory processing disorders. Project based learning is a school-wide emphasis. Students learn by studying a topic deeply so that they can make many connections and synthesize information. Students extend their learning by engaging in projects with a variety of entry points. We often role play and go on an expedition!Your donation of fun and exciting picture books that are connected to math will benefit my second and third graders. Books that relate to math concepts engage students and have them see math patterns in new and different ways. A variety of math concepts are in picture books: measurement, number patterns like doubling, shapes, and addition. My students will use these books during our math block. Students read math books at stations as one of their choices. I also read aloud some of the stories to the whole class. Enjoying these books together builds our reading community and our math knowledge.
needStatement: My students need math themed books to inspire their love of math.

name: Falling Into Books!
description: I teach 2nd grade in a high poverty school in St. Paul. My class is made up of many different cultural backgrounds: Hmong, Hispanic, African American, Native American and Karen. Some students have been in the U.S. for only a year or two. I have a wide range of readers in my class. Some students that are just starting to read to above grade level readers. The needs of my readers is very broad. The students in my class have a lot of different interests. As I set up my classroom this fall, I noticed that my leveled books at L and M did not contain as many books as some of my other levels. It is important to have a wide variety of books, both fiction and nonfiction, as well as including different cultures. Getting books into the students hands, helps them become better readers. The more they read, the more practice they get at becoming a better reader. I think it is important for them to see different cultures represented in some of the books. It is nice for them to see books with characters that are of the same ethnicity as students in our class and school.
needStatement: My students need some leveled books, both fiction and nonfiction, including titles from different cultures.

name: Get Coding with OzoBots at the Library
description: Students at our school learn so much more than the 3Rs. As an international school, students spend half the day in Spanish or Mandarin language immersion classroom, and half in English Language Arts. Add to that the cultural and economic diversity of our families and you've got the recipe for a great education of what makes our multicultural society a magnet for people from around the world. Our library and information technology program inspires students and staff to integrate learning by every means available. As an International school, our library strives to introduce new resources into lives of students that reflect their home cultures and experiences bridging their family's home culture and dreams for success in America. Having a strong Library and Information Technology program helps open a world of learning. Thanks. In addition to all the print literacy activities we've come to expect in libraries, libraries are a great place for diving into digital literacy, too. OzoBots are a delightful starting place for introducing students to coding and robotics in the library. This starter kit gives us enough to provide an introduction for all students in our preK-5 public elementary school and a springboard to further investigation and instruction. Getting started coding using OzoBots lets our students enjoy the same interest-driven learning during school in ways that are too often left for after-school enrichment in more affluent communities. Our commitment to equity demands that we go the extra mile to provide rich learning experiences for all students. Thanks for helping us in accomplishing that goal.
needStatement: My students need a simple entry into coding and robotics and Ozobot provides just that. The Ozobot Evo is a fun robot toy with a multi-step on-ramp to coding, appealing to a wide range of age.

name: Reading + Doing = Learning
description: The students who visit my library range from military kids who have traveled widely and had many cultural experiences to poverty-stricken children who have never been more than fifteen miles from home. I have as many special education students as gifted and talented students, and they are involved in a variety of school activities including chorus, step club, sports, and drama. Each student has unique interests and abilities to develop and share, so I want to give them all an opportunity to shine in front of their peers. One way I do that is by providing STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, Math) learning centers that are developed and led by students. They are encouraged to share their findings and creations with one another, and to collaborate for better results. I'm also building a library book collection that allows each child to explore his or her interests while learning about the world beyond our town. I have some students reading on a first grade level, while others are already reading middle school novels. My funding has been severely cut the last two years, so I'm turning to Donor's Choose to provide the resources this diverse group of students needs and deserves. My students have embraced the maker movement in my library, and many of my makerspace centers incorporate interactive projects that emphasize STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, Math) concepts. We use math manipulatives, simple building materials, art supplies, and science kits to put theory into practice. Students have the opportunity and guidance to engage in active learning when they're with me each week, but what happens after they leave the library? Your support of this project will provide additional STEAM instructional books for our library collection so students can continue the hands-on learning at home. When students practice sequencing and symmetry with origami projects, they want to check out origami books so they can do more paper folding at home. When they plan and build catapults using popsicle sticks and rubber bands to see which design throws a marshmallow the furthest, they want books that show them how to build and test other contraptions after school. When they explore patterns and tessellations through zentangle doodling, they clamor for step-by-step drawing books to practice in their spare time. Currently I can't fill the high demand for how-to books that correspond to our makerspace themes, but with your help more kids will have access to the resources they need to experiment with STEAM projects after the school day ends! These books will engage students in creative thinking and hands-on learning activities, helping to develop the next generation of scientists, artists, and engineers.
needStatement: My students need books that will inspire them to engage in hands-on experiments and projects so they can put the STEAM principles they're learning at school into practice at home.

name: Fantastic Flexible Seating!
description: As a teacher in a low-income/high poverty school district, my students are faced with several challenges both in and out of the classroom. Despite the many challenges they face, I am looking to provide my students with creative and meaningful learning experiences through differentiation and flexible seating. I'm a firm believer in keeping the focus on what's really important: the students. If student motivation and higher engagement is truly the desired end game, then we as teachers must adapt right along with our students in our classrooms. Flexible seating will allow my students to have more choice in their first grade learning environment. Students will benefit from additional movement, community building, comfort, collaboration, and sensory input. Thank you for considering making a donation to my flexible seating project. My students and I cannot thank you enough! :) Flexible seating will allow my students a sense of ownership and enabled them to become invested in their own education. My students will use flexible seating throughout the entire school day. The three wobble chairs and two balance ball chairs will be used by individual students who enjoy movement while focusing and learning. The two dorm chairs will be situated in my classroom library for a relaxing space to read and work. The two lap chairs will be available to students who want to work on the floor instead of their desks. Writing, phonics, handwriting, math, reading intervention, social studies, and science are the subjects I teach in my first grade classroom. Flexible seating benefits are profound, due to the fact that the classroom is reorganized to make it more student-centered. My students will no longer enter my classroom and feel like they are out of bounds or that they don’t have a specific space. Flexible seating will benefit the mental and physical improvements of my students with your help! Thank you so much in advance!
needStatement: My students need flexible seating for a more comfortable environment that helps them be their best learning selves.

name: Climbing Up the Literacy Ladder...One Book At a Time
description: From all walks of life, students in Camden City School District have very rich backgrounds and have a multitude of influences. Within one classroom, there are accelerated and developing learners, both eager to accept the learning challenge and persevere against all odds. They have demonstrated a determination to succeed and motivate teachers to push them to higher expectations. On a daily basis, the students come up with tons of ideas for new projects to do, or a bunch of different ways to do the same 'ol tasks rather than doing things the 'normal' way. They use creativity to conquer and achieve greatness no matter what they encounter. Being in any urban setting, it can become easy to develop a narrow world view. In order to see the world through various perspectives, it is imperative to read stories whose authors see the world through different lenses. I am determined to expose my students to a world that is much more vast than their everyday experiences. A wide variety of literature will provide the students with new ways to resolve conflict, embrace diversity, and adapt a new perspective of the world around them. Tablets are the most effective tools to reach a large collection of authors, genres, and contexts for maximum literacy exposure. Tablets would open the door to learning stations using software such as iReady, Anet, and newsela which are scientifically proven to increase lexile levels. Digital books eliminates budgetary roadblocks and allows a greater quantity of selections at a fraction of the cost compared to a class set of textbooks for every student. Exposure to new authors and genres, students will also grow in writing skills. Research has continuously proven that the best way to become an excellent writer is to read the works of other excellent writers. Students will be able to research exemplary writing essays, all while developing skills according to their individual abilities.
